• Catch has fallen since 2012, with poor recruitment resulting in low abundance. Irish quotas have been restrictive for the past three years, while total discards in 2017 were 117 t, 5% by weight.
  • There is a small targeted gillnet fishery for cod off the south-east coast. However, most Irish catches are taken as a minor bycatch throughout the Celtic Sea. This makes it difficult to control the fishing mortality on this stock.
  • Advice for 2018 was 3,076 t, for 2019 the advice is zero tonnes.
  • The 2018 ICES assessment revised the stock size downwards following reduced recruitment and implying that the spawning stock has not recovered to Blim, as was thought in 2017.
  • The zero advice reflects the state of the stock, with erratic, poor recruitment since 2012.
  • With the introduction of the Landing Obligation to the stock in 2019, and all Celtic Sea fleets catching cod to a greater or lesser extent, it is likely to form the primary "choke" and be the limiting stock for all Celtic Sea fleets in 2019.
  • Assuming a zero TAC there would be no Irish quota next year. Based on 2017 quota allocation, if there were to be any TAC an Irish allocation of 25% would be expected.
  • The proposed 7% de minimis exemption would apply to bottom trawls, seines and beam trawls, using ≥ 80mm mesh fishing in ICES divisions 7b-c and 7e-7k and limited to 1 year, with an obligation to submit relevant data to assess the justification to STECF by 31st May 2019.
  • This stock will be benchmarked by ICES in 2020 to align the Celtic Sea haddock, cod and whiting assessments.

Management:
• The assessment area covers 7.e-k, with inclusion of catch from the south Irish Sea (7.a; ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3). This does not correspond to the TAC management area of 7.b-c, 7.e-k, 8, 9 and 10; Union waters of CECAF 34.1.1.
  • Irish landings in 33E2 and 33E3 account for notable proportions of Irish landings from the Irish Sea quota (20 t, 9% in 2018).
  • Since 2005, ICES rectangles 30E4, 31E4, and 32E3 have been closed during the first quarter as part of the Celtic Sea Conservation area (Appendix VI).
  • The proportional quota split in 2019 changed in favour of Ireland, relative to 2018 increasing from 25% to 40% of total TAC; reductions were seen for France (down 13%), Belgium and the UK (both down 1%). This was due to the application of the Hague preferences.
Additional:
• Catch has fallen since 2012, with poor recruitment resulting in low abundance. Quotas (including Irish) were restrictive, however total catch in 2018 (1,565 t) amounted to only 51% of the TAC (3,076 t). Total discards in 2018 were 180 t, 12% of catch by weight.
  • Most Irish catch is taken as a minor bycatch throughout the Celtic Sea. This makes it difficult to control the fishing mortality on the stock.
  • There is a small targeted gillnet fishery for cod off the south-east coast, this has been in decline over recent years.
  • The TAC set at 1,610 t for 2019 is for bycatch only.
  • The 2019 assessment showed a declining trend in SSB, following poor recruitment since 2014. The assessment also revised the stock size down on the 2018 assessment.
  • The zero advice reflects the state of the stock, with poor recruitment since 2012. As cod is widely caught as part of mixed fisheries, it is likely to be the primary "choke" species and be the limiting stock for all Celtic Sea fleets in 2020 under the Landings Obligation.
  • ICES will benchmark this stock in 2020.

Management:
• The EU TAC for spurdog in 2015 is set at zero.
  • A maximum landings size of 100cm was in place in 2009 and 2010 before the TAC was set at zero in 2011.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The 2016 TAC was set at zero. In July 2016 a TAC of 270 t, with a corresponding Irish quota of 53 t was put in place for vessels taking part in a spurdog by-catch avoidance programme.
  • A maximum landings size of 100cm was in place in 2009 and 2010 before the TAC was set at zero in 2011.
Additional:
• The UK ran a pilot spurdog avoidance project from 2013-2016, with some quota allocated to un-avoidable bycatch. This has been expanded to allow other countries to take part. There are specifications within the new TAC as to how this programme is to be managed by each country.
  • Spurdog have low productivity and are vulnerable to fishing because they form dense aggregations that can be easily fished. The stock currently appears stable at a low level, but the recent period of stability is short compared to the longevity of the species. Given this longevity, stock recovery will be very slow (decades).

Management: • The 2016 TAC was set at zero. In July 2016 a TAC of 270 t, with a corresponding Irish quota of 53 t was put in place for vessels taking part in a spurdog bycatch avoidance programme. This TAC also applied in 2017.
Additional:
• The UK ran a pilot spurdog avoidance project from 2013-2016, with some quota allocated to unavoidable bycatch. This has been expanded to allow other countries to take part. There are specifications within the new TAC as to how this programme is to be managed by each country. It has not yet been implemented in Ireland.
  • A maximum landings size of 100cm was in place in 2009 and 2010 before the TAC was set at zero in 2011.
  • Spurdog have low productivity and are vulnerable to fishing because they form dense aggregations that can be easily fished. The stock currently appears stable at a low level, but the recent period of stability is short compared to the longevity of the species. Given this longevity, stock recovery will be very slow (decades).

Management: • A (bycatch) TAC of 270 t, is available for countries that have a specific spurdog avoidance bycatch programme. Ireland was allocated a quota of 53 t under this TAC.
Additional:
• Spurdog have low productivity and are vulnerable to fishing because they form dense aggregations that can be easily fished. The stock currently appears stable at a low level, but the recent period of stability is short compared to the longevity of the species. Given this longevity, stock recovery will be very slow (decades).
  • A maximum landings size of 100cm was in place in 2009 and 2010 before the TAC was set at zero in 2011. This is no longer in place.
  • The UK ran a pilot spurdog avoidance project from 2013-2016, with some quota allocated to unavoidable bycatch. This was expanded in 2017 to allow other countries to take part. There are specifications referred to in the TAC regulation as to how this programme is to be managed by each country. These specifications include detailed reporting, technical and monitoring requirements. It has not been implemented in Ireland.

Management: • A (bycatch) TAC of 270 t, is available for countries that have a specific spurdog avoidance bycatch programme. Ireland was allocated a quota of 53 t under this TAC.
Additional:
• Spurdog have low productivity and are vulnerable to fishing because they form dense aggregations that can be easily fished. The stock currently appears stable at a low level, but the recent period of stability is short compared to the longevity of the species. Given this longevity, stock recovery will be very slow (decades).
  • A maximum landings size of 100cm was in place in 2009 and 2010 before the TAC was set at zero in 2011. This is no longer in place.
  • The UK ran a pilot spurdog avoidance project from 2013-2016, with some quota allocated to unavoidable bycatch. This was expanded in 2017 to allow other countries to take part. There are specifications referred to in the TAC regulation as to how this programme is to be managed by each country. These specifications include detailed reporting, technical and monitoring requirements. It has not been implemented in Ireland.

Management:
• The current management plan for VIa haddock is now obsolete given the merging of haddock in VIa with IV and IIIa. A new management plan needs to be developed and this will require cooperation with Norway.
  • EU has adopted a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks Council Regulation (EC) 1342/2008. This continues to have a large impact on fleets catching haddock in VIa.
  • The 2015 TAC allocated to this stock in VIa and VIb was 4,536 t, with an Irish quota of 743 t.
  • A ''conservation credits'' scheme (see ICES summary) has been in place in Scotland since January 2007.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The current management plan for 6.a haddock is now obsolete given the merging of haddock in 6.a with 4 and 3.a. A new management plan needs to be developed and this will require cooperation with Norway.
  • EU has adopted a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks Council Regulation (EC) 1342/2008. This continues to have a large impact on fleets catching haddock in 6.a.
  • A conservation credits scheme (see ICES summary) has been in place in Scotland since January 2007.
Additional:
• Half of the Irish landings of haddock in areas 3, 4 and 6a come from trips where haddock was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish and other gadoid species.
  • This advice was postponed in June due to difficulties with the haddock assessment that have since been addressed in an Inter-Benchmark process. During this year's process, an error in the advice for fishing opportunities of haddock in North Sea, West of Scotland, Skagerrak stock provided in 2015 (for the fisheries in 2016) was detected. The corrected version of this advice is also now available.

Management:
• The 2017 TAC has been very limiting for haddock in all areas.
  • Gadoid fisheries in 6 and 5.b are subject to the landing obligation for haddock in 2018 (see Appendix VI).
  • EU has adopted a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks Council Regulation (EC) 1342/2008. The plan was amended in 2016 by Council Regulation (EC) 2016/2094.
Additional: • Half of the Irish landings of haddock in areas 3, 4 and 6.a come from trips where haddock was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish and other gadoid species.

Management:
• Gadoid fisheries in areas 6 and 5.b were subject to the landing obligation for haddock in 2018.
  • EU adopted a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks Council Regulation (EC) 1342/2008 expired in January 2018.
Additional:
• Most of the Irish landings of haddock in area 6.a come from trips that target haddock. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish and other gadoid species. A targeted seiner fishery west of Donegal bay normally accounts for 10-20% of the landings.
  • The TAC for this stock is linked to the North Sea and is negotiated as part of the EU Norway agreement.

Management: • Coming into force in July 2018, the EU multiannual plan for demersal stocks in the North Sea applies to this stock in 2019, however with failure to reach agreement with Norway, MSY advice was provided in 2019 for 2020.
Additional:
• Most of the Irish landings of haddock in Division 6.a come from trips that target haddock. The remainder are taken from a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish and other gadoid species. A targeted seine fishery west of Donegal Bay normally accounts for 10-20% of the landings.
  • The TAC for this stock is linked to the North Sea and is negotiated as part of the EU Norway agreement. There is a fixed ratio that splits the TAC.
  • Advice for 2020 is up 23% on last year, owing to a strong incoming recruitment observed in 2019 surveys. Irregular strong recruitments have been a feature of the stock dynamics in the past, resulting in a saw tooth SSB time profile.

Management:
• Since 2004 an autonomous TAC has been set for EU fleets operating in Divisions VIb, and Sub -areas XII and XIV.
  • The 2015 TAC was 2,580 t. The associated Irish quota was 203 t.
  • Part of Division VIb falls (since 1999) within international waters fished by non EU vessels (mainly Russian) which are not subject to a TAC. This allows for an unregulated fishery in the Rockall area.
  • Following the NEAFC agreement in March 2001, NEAFC has maintained an area closure to all fishing (except long-lining) in the SW corner of the Rockall Bank. Data are inadequate to fully evaluate the impact of this measure on the stock status.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• Since 2004 an autonomous TAC has been set for EU fleets operating in Divisions 6.b, and Subareas 12 and 14.
  • Part of Division 6.b falls (since 1999) within international waters fished by non EU vessels (mainly Russian) which are not subject to a TAC. This allows for an unregulated fishery in the Rockall area.
  • Following the NEAFC agreement in March 2001, NEAFC has maintained an area closure to all fishing (except long-lining) in the SW corner of the Rockall Bank. Data are inadequate to fully evaluate the impact of this measure on the stock status.
Additional: • Two-thirds of the Irish landings of Rockall haddock come from trips where haddock was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim and anglerfish.

Management:
• Since 2004 an autonomous TAC has been set for EU fleets operating in Divisions 6.b, and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • Part of Division 6.b falls (since 1999) within international waters fished by non EU vessels (mainly Russian) which are not subject to a TAC. This allows for an unregulated fishery in the Rockall area.
  • Following the NEAFC agreement in March 2001, NEAFC has maintained an area closure to all fishing (except long-lining) in the SW corner of the Rockall Bank. Data are inadequate to fully evaluate the impact of this measure on the stock status.
  • Gadoid fisheries in 6 and 5.b are subject to the landing obligation for haddock in 2018 (see Appendix VI).
Additional: • Two-thirds of the Irish landings of Rockall haddock come from trips where haddock was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim and anglerfish.

Management:
• There is no internationally agreed TAC for haddock in 6.b. Since 2004 an autonomous TAC has been set for EU fleets operating in Divisions 6.b, and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • Part of Division 6.b falls (since 1999) within international waters fished by non EU vessels (mainly Russian).
  • Following the NEAFC agreement in March 2001, NEAFC has maintained an area closure to all fishing (except long-lining) in the SW corner of the Rockall Bank. Data are inadequate to fully evaluate the impact of this measure on the stock status.
Additional:
• Most of the Irish landings of Rockall haddock come from trips where haddock was the dominant species. They are mainly landed with megrim, saithe and anglerfish.
  • In recent years seiners have reported landings of haddock in area 6b.
  • The estimates of stock size in recent years have fluctuated widely, and this has impacted on the catch advice. This year's assessment shows the Rockall haddock SSB to be substantially higher than previously estimated, resulting in an increased advice for 2019 which is about double the 2018 catch advice.

Management:
• There is no internationally agreed TAC for haddock in Division 6.b. Since 2004 an autonomous TAC has been set for EU fleets operating in Division 6.b and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • Part of Division 6.b falls (since 1999) within international waters fished by non EU vessels (mainly Russian).
  • Following the NEAFC agreement in March 2001, NEAFC has maintained an area closure to all fishing except long-lining in the SW corner of the Rockall Bank, this continued in 2019. Data are inadequate to fully evaluate the impact of this measure on the stock status.
Additional:
• Most of the Irish landings of Rockall haddock come from trips where haddock was the dominant species. They are mainly landed with megrim, saithe and anglerfish.
  • Since 2014 seiners have reported landings of haddock in Division 6.b.
  • Estimates of stock size have fluctuated since the late 1990s. From an all-time low in 2014, stock size markedly increased owing to a strong 2017 year class and low fishing pressure. In this year's assessment the SSB is not predicted to further increase giving similar catch advice for 2020 as in 2019.
  • The stock was benchmarked in 2019 and FMSYwas decreased from 0.2 to 0.168.

Management:
• The TAC Area previously covered Sub-areas VII, VIII, IX and X but since 2009 a separate TAC is allocated for Division VIIa.
  • The 2015 TAC for haddock in Division VIIa was 1,181 t with an Irish quota of 511 t.
  • Effort reductions as part of the Cod Long Term Management Plan (EC Reg.1342/2008) will also reduce catch and discarding of haddock in this area.
  • FEAS recommends that management objectives be established and that a management plan be developed and implemented for fisheries catching haddock.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The stock area does not include Irish landings taken or reported in 33E2 and 33E3, these accounted for 64% of the 7.a Irish landings in 2016. The TAC management area covers all of ICES Division 7.a.
  • In 2016 the landings obligation applies for this stock for the first time. According to the delegate regulation (EC, 2015) vessels where more than 25% of their 7.a landings using trawls and seines in the reference years (2013 & 2014) were specified gadoids (Cod, Haddock, Whiting & Saithe) will be covered by the Landings Obligation. This implies that all catches of haddock in the Irish Sea by those vessels must be landed. However a 7% de minimus also applies, meaning that these vessels can discard up to 7% of the haddock they catch. It is difficult to assess how this might impact of the fishery, the stock, the scientific data and the advice given for 2017 at this stage.
  • Effort reductions as part of the Cod Long Term Management Plan (EC Reg.1342/2008) will also reduce catch and discarding of haddock in this area.
Additional:
• Irish landings of Irish Sea haddock are mostly taken in a targeted fishery; nearly 90% of the landings come from trips where haddock was the dominant species landed. The majority of these trips are in the south of 7.a in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3.
  • The haddock stock has increased significantly in 7.a but the ICES advice has not increased as rapidly as the stock due to the fact that this is currently a data limited assessment. Work is underway to improve the assessment and advice basis but in the interim there is an increasing mis-match between stock abundance and the catch advice leading to potential problems with foregone yield and quota related discarding.

Management:
• The stock area does not include Irish landings taken or reported in 33E2 and 33E3, these accounted for 73% of the 7.a Irish landings in 2016. The TAC management area covers all of ICES Division 7.a.
  • Gadoid fisheries in 7.a are subject to the landing obligation for haddock in 2018 (see Appendix VI).
  • Measures established for the recovery of cod in 7.a include multiannual reductions in of fishing effort, technical measures, control and enforcement, accompanying structural measures and market measures have all impacted on haddock fisheries in 7.a.
Additional:
• This stock was benchmarked in 2017. The result of the benchmark was that the stock was changed from a category 3 stock (trend-based assessment) to a category 1 stock (analytical assessment).
  • The new assessment shows the stock to be at the highest levels observed in the time series and the recent fishing mortality to be very low.
  • Irish landings of Irish Sea haddock are mostly taken in a targeted fishery; nearly 90% of the landings come from trips where haddock was the dominant species landed. The majority of these trips are in the south of 7.a in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3 which are not included in this stock assessment.

Management:
• The stock area does not include Irish landings taken or reported in 33E2 and 33E3, these accounted for 63% of the 7.a Irish landings in 2017. The TAC management area covers all of ICES Division 7.a.
  • Measures established for the recovery of cod in 7.a were revoked in January 2018.
Additional:
• The new assessment shows the stock to be at the highest levels observed in the time series and the recent fishing mortality to be very low.
  • Irish landings under the Irish Sea haddock quota are mostly taken in a targeted fishery; nearly 90% of the landings come from trips where haddock was the dominant species landed. The majority of these trips are in the south of 7.a in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3 which are not included in this stock assessment.
  • Preliminary landings figures for 2018 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be below the quota.

Management:
• The stock area of Division 7.a does not include Irish landings taken or reported in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3, which are reallocated from Division 7.a to Division 7.g.
  • This reallocation (from 2 rectangles from the Irish Sea to the Celtic Sea) has increased since first introduced in 2006, peaking in 2017.
  • The 2018 reallocation of 532 t accounted for 21% of Irish Sea (Division 7.a) landings and 7.5% of Celtic Sea (Divisions 7.b-k) landings. The TAC management area covers all of ICES Division 7.a.
  • Limited cod quota is likely to limit haddock catch in the Irish Sea.
Additional:
• The assessment shows stock size to be at a high level since the mid-2010s and fishing mortality to be low over the same period.
  • Irish landings under the Irish Sea haddock quota are mostly taken in a targeted fishery; nearly 70% of the landings come from trips where haddock was the dominant species landed. The majority of these trips are in the south of Division 7.a in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3 which are not included in this stock assessment.
  • The advice for 2020 is lower than the 2019 advice; however, preliminary landings figures for 2019 indicate that uptake by Irish vessels will be below the quota.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions VIIb-k, and Sub-areas VIII, IX and X and EU waters of CECAF 34.1.1. The assessment area covers Divisions VIIb,c,e-k
  • The TAC for 2015 was 8,342 t with an Irish quota of 1,854 t (22%).
  • This stock is taken in a mixed fishery, mainly by otter trawlers from France and Ireland.
  • There is a management plan in development by the NWWRAC for mixed demersal fisheries catching haddock in VIIfg. FEAS supports the development of this plan.
  • Technical Measures initially proposed and developed through the NWWRAC have been introduced since mid-2012 in the Celtic Sea in with the aim of improving selection and reducing discards of haddock and other gadoids. A further voluntary scheme was put into place in 2014.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• Stock area is 7.b,c,e-k and TAC area is 7.b-k, 8, 9 and 10.
  • Effort reductions as part of the Cod Long Term Management Plan (EC Reg.1342/2008) will also reduce catch and discarding of haddock in this area.
  • FEAS recommends that management objectives be established and that a management plan be developed and implemented for fisheries catching haddock.
Additional:
• Haddock are caught in mixed fisheries with cod and whiting; management should take this into account.
  • Poor recruitment after 2009 led to a decrease in the volume of discards, but as the moderately strong 2013 cohort entered the fishery, the discard volume increased again in 2015.
  • Landings in the south of Division 7.a (33E2 and 33E3) are included in the assessment because they are considered to be part of this stock.
  • The TAC has been very restrictive in recent years, which has resulted in increased levels of discarding of fish over the minimum conservation reference size (MCRS).

Management:
• The stock area consists of 7.b,c,e-k and two rectangles in the south of Division 7.a (33E2 and 33E3). This differs to the TAC area, 7.b-k, 8, 9 and 10.
  • The TAC has been very restrictive in recent years, which has resulted in increased levels of discarding of fish over the minimum conservation reference size (MCRS).
Additional:
• Haddock are caught in mixed fisheries with cod and whiting. Mixed fisheries analysis indicates that haddock are the most restrictive species in the Celtic Sea (See Section on Mixed Fisheries).
  • Landings in the south of Division 7.a (33E2 and 33E3) are included in the assessment because they are considered to be part of this stock. Whilst they are a relatively minor component of the catches in this stock they constitute a large component of the 7.a stock.
  • In 2016, the majority of the discards, by weight, were above the MCRS in the main fleets; 92% in the French 7bk OTB fleet, 72% in the UK 7ek OTB fleet and 35% in the Irish OTB 7g fleet.

Management:
• The stock area consists of 7.b,c,e-k and two rectangles in the south of Division 7.a (33E2 and 33E3). This differs to the TAC area, 7.b-k, 8, 9 and 10.
  • The TAC has been very restrictive in recent years, which has resulted in increased levels of discarding of fish over the minimum conservation reference size (MCRS).
Additional:
• Celtic Sea haddock are caught in mixed fisheries with whiting, megrim, anglerfish, Nephrops and other species. They are rarely specifically targeted but they are widely distributed which makes it difficult to control the fishing mortality on this stock.
  • The large reduction in fishing mortality advised for Celtic sea cod in 2019 will result in cod becoming a choke species for all demersal fleets.
  • Landings in the south of Division 7.a (33E2 and 33E3) are included in the assessment because they are considered to be part of this stock. Whilst they are a relatively minor component of the catches in this stock they constitute a large component of the 7.a stock.
  • Discards by weight continued to be high (about 8,000 t) in 2017, comprising 50% of the international catch.
  • The proposed 7% de minimis exemption will apply to bottom trawls, seines and beam trawls, using ≥ 80mm mesh, fishing in ICES divisions 7.b-c and 7.e-k and limited to 1 year, with an obligation to submit relevant data to assess the justification to STECF by 31st May 2019.
  • This stock will be benchmarked by ICES in 2020 to align the Celtic Sea haddock, cod and whiting assessments.

Management:
• The stock area consists of 7.b,c,e-k and two rectangles in the south of Division 7.a (ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3) which are reallocated to 7.g. This differs to the TAC area, 7.b-k, 8, 9 and 10.
  • This reallocation (from 2 rectangles from the Irish Sea to the Celtic Sea) has increased since first introduced in 2006, peaking in 2017. The 2018 reallocation of 532 t accounted for 7.5% of Division 7.b-k landings and 21% of Irish Sea landings (Division 7.a).
  • The TAC has been very restrictive since 2010, which has resulted in increased levels of discarding of fish over the minimum conservation reference size (MCRS). International discarding has averaged at 45% over the last 5 years (2014 to 2018).
Additional:
• The advice for Celtic sea haddock for 2020 is for a 164% increase in catches. This is because of the large 2018 year class which will be recruited to the fishery in 2020.
  • Celtic Sea haddock are caught in mixed fisheries with whiting, megrim, anglerfish, Nephrops and other species. They are rarely specifically targeted but they are widely distributed which makes it difficult to control the fishing mortality on this stock.
  • The large reduction in fishing mortality advised for Celtic sea cod for 2019 and 2020 will result in cod continuing to be a choke species for all demersal fleets.
  • Landings in the south of Division 7.a (33E2 and 33E3) are included in the assessment because they are considered to be part of this stock. Whilst they are a relatively minor component of the catches in this stock they constitute a large component of the 7.a stock.
  • Discarding of the stock is high (43% by weight over the last ten years) and continued so in 2018 (43%).
  • This stock will be benchmarked by ICES in 2020.

Management:
• A long term management plan has been agreed for this fishery since 1999 between the EU, Faroe Islands, Iceland, Norway and Russia. The plan aims at preventing SSB from falling below Blim of 2.5 million tonnes, and restricting the TACs consistent with a fishing mortality of less than 0.125. Provisions are also made to reduce this F, should the SSB fall below Bpa of 5 million tonnes.
  • ICES considers that this agreement is consistent with the precautionary approach.
  • In 2015, the sum of unilaterally allocated TACs was 328,000 t.
  • In 2015 the EU TAC is 18,424 t. The quota for Ireland, including carryover was 1,634 t.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to a small number of vessels on a lottery basis.
  • In recent years, the EU has been granted access to the Norwegian sector where the most fishable aggregations occur. However this access is negotiated on a yearly basis. The Irish quota is not useable without EU access to the Norwegian EEZ.
  • The management plan for Norwegian Spring Spawning Herring has a target fishing mortality rate that is lower than FMSY.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• A long term management plan has been agreed for this fishery since 1999 between the EU, Faroe Islands, Iceland, Norway and Russia. The plan aims at preventing SSB from falling below BLIM of 2.5 million tonnes, and restricting the TACs consistent with a fishing mortality of less than 0.125. Provisions are also made to reduce this F, should the SSB fall below Bpa of 5 million tonnes.
  • ICES considers that this agreement is consistent with the precautionary approach.
  • Since 2013, there has been no agreement by the Coastal States on TAC sharing and the management plan has not been followed. This has led to unilaterally set quotas which together are higher than the TAC indicated by the management plan.
  • In 2016, the sum of the unilaterally allocated quotas is 377,000 t.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to a small number of vessels on a lottery basis.
  • In recent years, the EU has been granted access to the Norwegian sector where the most fishable aggregations occur. However this access is negotiated on a yearly basis. The Irish quota is not useable without EU access to the Norwegian EEZ. Access was granted in 2016 but not in 2015.
  • The management plan for Norwegian Spring Spawning Herring has a target fishing mortality rate that is lower than FMSY.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• A long term management plan has been agreed for this fishery since 1999 between the EU, Faroe Islands, Iceland, Norway and Russia. The plan aims at preventing SSB from falling below Blim of 2.5 million tonnes, and restricting the TAC to values consistent with a fishing mortality of less than 0.125. Provisions are also made to reduce this F, should the SSB fall below Bpa of 5 million tonnes.
  • ICES considers that this management plan is consistent with the precautionary approach.
  • Since 2013, there has been no agreement by the Coastal States on TAC sharing and the management plan has not been followed. This has led to unilaterally set quotas which together are higher than the TAC indicated by the management plan.
  • In 2017, the sum of the declared national quotas is 805,142 t.
  • The stock is declining and estimated to be below MSY Btrigger in 2017.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to a small number of vessels on a lottery basis.
  • In recent years, the EU has been granted access to the Norwegian sector where the most fishable aggregations occur. However this access is negotiated on a yearly basis. The Irish quota is not useable without EU access to the Norwegian EEZ.
  • The management plan for Norwegian Spring Spawning Herring has a target fishing mortality rate that is lower than FMSY.
  • When reporting catches, the Commission require quantities fished in the NEAFC Regulatory Area and Union waters to be reported.
  • Of the Irish quote up to 532 t may be caught in Norwegian waters north of 62° N and the fishery zone around Jan Mayen.
Additional:
• In October 2017, an error was detected in the conversion of acoustic data from the Norwegian acoustic survey on the Norwegian spawning grounds survey index for the period 1988-2008. The error affected both the advice for 2017 (issued in September 2016) and 2018 (issued in September 2017).
  • Applying the long-term management plan results in a 32% downwards revision relative to the previously released catch advice for 2017 and a 30% downwards revision relative to previously released advice for 2018.

Management:
• A long term management strategy (LTMS) was agreed by the EU, the Faroe Islands, Iceland, Norway, and Russia in 2018.
  • ICES considers that the HCR proposed for the LTMS is consistent with the precautionary approach.
  • Since 2013, there has been no agreement by the Coastal States on TAC sharing and the management plan has not been followed. This has led to unilaterally set quotas which together are higher than the TAC indicated by the management plan.
  • In 2018, the sum of the declared national quotas is 546,448 t.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to a small number of vessels on a lottery basis.
  • EU access to the Norwegian sector where the most fishable aggregations occur is negotiated on a yearly basis. The Irish quota is not useable without EU access to the Norwegian EEZ.
  • The LTMS for Norwegian Spring Spawning Herring has a target fishing mortality rate that is lower than FMSY.
  • Quantities fished by EU vessels in the NEAFC Regulatory Area and Union waters must be reported to the Commission.
  • Up to 355 t of the Irish quota may be caught in Norwegian waters north of 62 ° N and the fishery zone around Jan Mayen.
Additional:
• The stock is declining but is estimated to be above MSY Btrigger in 2018.
  • Fishing mortality has been increasing since 2015 and was above FMSY in 2017.
  • The combination of the new (higher) fishing mortality being used as the basis for advice (from the LTMS), and a lower trigger biomass (Bmgt) has resulted in catch advice for 2019 that is 53% higher than for 2018.

Management:
• A long term management strategy (LTMS) was agreed by the EU, the Faroe Islands, Iceland, Norway, and Russia in 2018
  • ICES considers that the HCR proposed for the LTMS is consistent with the precautionary approach.
  • Since 2013, there has been no agreement by the Coastal States on TAC sharing and the management plan has not been followed. This has led to unilaterally set quotas which together are higher than the TAC indicated by the management plan.
  • In 2019, the sum of the declared national quotas is 773,750 t.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to a small number of vessels on a lottery basis.
  • EU access to the Norwegian sector where the most fishable aggregations occur is negotiated on a yearly basis. The Irish quota is not useable without EU access to the Norwegian EEZ.
  • Quantities fished by EU vessels in the NEAFC Regulatory Area and Union waters must be reported to the Commission.
  • Up to 399 t of the Irish quota may be caught in Norwegian waters north of 62° N and the fishery zone around Jan Mayen.
Additional:
• The stock is declining but is estimated to be above MSY Btrigger in 2019.
  • Fishing mortality has increased since 2015 but is estimated to be below FMSY in 2018.
  • Catch advice for 2020 is 11% lower than that for 2019. This is due to a decline in the stock.
  • Recruitment is estimated to be average or low since 2007.

Management:
• The EU TAC for VIaN in 2015 is 22,690 t. The Irish share of the EU quota was 3,427 t. The EU TAC for VIaS and VIIbc is 0 t in 2015.
  • The EU adopted a management plan for VIaN in December 2008. In VIaS/VIIbc the EC Council followed a proposed long term plan for TAC setting for 2014 and 2015.
  • Irish and Dutch vessels are not allowed to fish herring inside the UK (Scottish) 6-12 mile limits, including the outlying Hebridean Islands. German and French vessels have access to herring fishing between 6 and 12 miles in Scottish waters, in most areas, though not the mainland limits east of the Butt of Lewis.
  • There is an annual seasonal closure of the Butt of Lewis spawning area from the 15th August to the 15th September each year.
  • It is noted that the proposed rebuilding plan for northwest Ireland herring contains an exclusion zone between 56oN and 57o30 N for Irish vessels only.
  • The Irish herring fishery in VIa opens on the 1st October each season. This is an appropriate opening date for the VIaS/VIIbc stock, but not for the VIaN stock, where the main fishing season begins in August. The 1st October opening date incentivises Irish vessels to target fish along the 56oN boundary with VIaS, with a high risk of catching of VIaS/VIIbc herring against the VIaN quota (see also West of Scotland Herring).
  • The 56oN boundary between this stock unit and herring in VIaN is not biologically meaningful. It was created in 1981, and corresponds roughly to the boundary of the Irish and UK fishery patrol zones, or ''EEZs''. The boundary cuts through both the summer feeding grounds and the winter spawning grounds, and thus the fishing grounds too.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• ICES now gives one advice for the combined area 6.aN, 6.aS, and 7.b-c. ICES still considers two separate stocks exist, but it is not currently possible to segregate them in commercial catches or surveys.
  • A scientific monitoring fishery was proposed to allow the collection of fishery dependent data for the two stocks. For 2016 a TAC of 5,800 t was agreed for 5.b, 6.b, 6.aN, 6.aS and 7.b-c. This is slightly in excess of the advice obtained from ICES.
  • The Irish herring fishery in 6.a opens on the 1st October each season. This is an appropriate opening date for the 6.aS/7.b-c stock, but not for the 6.aN stock, where the main fishing season begins in August. The 1st October opening date incentivises Irish vessels to target fish along the 56oN boundary with 6.aS, with a high risk of catching 6.aS/7.b-c herring against the 6.aN quota.
  • Irish and Dutch vessels are not allowed to fish herring inside the UK (Scottish) 6-12 mile limits, including the outlying Hebridean Islands. German and French vessels have access to herring fishing between 6 and 12 miles in Scottish waters, in most areas, though not the mainland limits east of the Butt of Lewis.
  • There is an annual seasonal closure of the Butt of Lewis spawning area from the 15th August to the 15th September each year.
  • The 56oN boundary between 6.aS/7.b-c and 6.aN is not biologically meaningful. It was created in 1981, and corresponds roughly to the boundary of the Irish and UK fishery patrol zones, or ''EEZs''. The boundary cuts through both the summer feeding grounds and the winter spawning grounds, and thus the fishing grounds also.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• Since 2016 ICES gives one advice for the combined area 6.aN, 6.aS, and 7.b-c. ICES still considers two separate stocks exist, but it is not currently possible to segregate them in commercial catches or surveys.
  • A scientific monitoring fishery was proposed to allow the collection of fishery dependent data for the two stocks and continue the time series.
  • For 2017 a TAC of 5,800t was agreed for 5.b, 6.b, 6.aN, 6.aS and 7.b-c. This is slightly in excess of the advice obtained from ICES.
  • The Irish herring fishery in 6.a opens on the 1st October each season. This is an appropriate opening date for the 6.aS/7.b-c stock, but not for the 6.aN stock, where the main fishing season begins in August. The 1st October opening date incentivises Irish vessels to target fish along the 56oN boundary with 6.aS, with a high risk of catching 6.aS/7.b-c herring against the 6.aN quota.
  • Irish and Dutch vessels are not allowed to fish herring inside the UK (Scottish) 6-12 nautical mile limits, including the outlying Hebridean Islands (Appendix II). German and French vessels have access to herring fishing between 6 and 12 nautical miles in Scottish waters in most areas, though not the mainland limits east of the Butt of Lewis.
  • There is an annual seasonal closure of the Butt of Lewis spawning area from the 15th August to the 15th September each year.
  • The 56oN boundary between 6.aS/7.b-c and 6.aN is not biologically meaningful. Created in 1981, it corresponds roughly to the boundary of the Irish and UK fishery patrol zones, or EEZs. The boundary cuts through both the summer feeding grounds and the winter spawning grounds, and thus the fishing grounds also.
  • All targeted herring fishing is prohibited in the part of the ICES zones subject to this TAC between 56° N and 57° 30minutes N, with the exception of a six nautical mile belt measured from the baseline of the United Kingdoms territorial sea.
  • Currently the landing obligation only applies to pelagic gears (pelagic trawls, pair trawls).
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• Since 2016 ICES gives one advice for the combined area 6.aN, 6.aS, and 7.b-c. ICES still considers two separate stocks exist, but it is not currently possible to segregate them in commercial catches or surveys. The 56 ° N boundary between 6.aS/7.b-c and 6.aN is not biologically meaningful. Created in 1981, it corresponds roughly to the boundary of the Irish and UK fishery patrol zones, or "EEZs". The boundary cuts through both the summer feeding grounds and the winter spawning grounds, and thus the fishing grounds also.
  • Since 2015 all targeted herring fishing is prohibited in the part of the ICES zones subject to this TAC between 56 ° N and 57 ° 30'N, with the exception of a six nautical mile belt measured from the baseline of the United Kingdom's territorial sea.
  • In 2016 a scientific monitoring fishery, with a TAC of 4,840 t, was proposed to allow the collection of samples for the two stocks and continue the time series.
  • Since 2016 a TAC of 5,800 t was agreed for 5.b, 6.b, 6.aN, 6.aS and 7.b-c. This TAC is split for 5.b, 6.b and 6.aN (4,170 t 72%) and 6.aS and 7.b-c (1,630 t 28%).
  • Irish quota in 6.aS, 7b-c is allocated to vessels in 5 different size categories.
  • Irish herring fishery in 6.a opens on the 1st October each season. This is an appropriate opening date for the 6.aS/7.b-c stock, but not for the 6.aN stock, where the main fishing season begins in August. There is an annual seasonal closure of the Butt of Lewis spawning area from the 15th August to the 15th September each year.
  • Irish and Dutch vessels are not allowed to fish herring inside the UK (Scottish) 6-12 nautical mile limits, including the outlying Hebridean Islands (Appendix II). German and French vessels have access to herring fishing between 6 and 12 nautical miles in Scottish waters in most areas, though not the mainland limits east of the Butt of Lewis.
Additional:
• SSB has been below Blim (250,000 t) since 2013. Recruitment has been at unprecedented low levels since 2013.
  • A rebuilding plan was developed by the Pelagic AC and evaluated by ICES in 2017 and found not to be precautionary. A revised rebuilding plan was proposed by the Pelagic AC in 2018 but has not been evaluated. ICES stated that further work on the assessment was required in order to run the simulations to test the management plan.
  • In 2016, a stock identification project was initiated which aims to develop a genetic method to distinguish the 6.aS and 6.aN spawning stocks. This work is ongoing and will be completed and a report produced in 2020.

Management:
• Since 2016, ICES gives one advice for the combined area 6.aN, 6.aS, and 7.b-c. ICES still considers two separate stocks exist, but it is not currently possible to segregate them in commercial catches or surveys. The 56° N boundary between 6.aS/7.b-c and 6.aN is not biologically meaningful. Created in 1981, it corresponds roughly to the boundary of the Irish and UK fishery patrol zones, or "EEZs". The boundary cuts through both the summer feeding grounds and the winter spawning grounds, and thus the fishing grounds also.
  • Since 2015 all targeted herring fishing is prohibited in the part of the ICES zones subject to this TAC between 56° N and 57° 30°N, with the exception of a six nautical mile limit measured from the baseline of the United Kingdom's territorial sea.
  • In 2016 a scientific monitoring fishery (4,840 t) was considered appropriate by ICES to allow the collection of samples for the two stocks and continue the time series.
  • Since 2016 a TAC of 5,800 t was agreed for 5.b, 6.b, 6.aN, 6.aS and 7.b-c. This TAC is split for 5.b, 6.b and 6.aN (4,170 t 72%) and 6.aS and 7.b-c (1,630 t 28%).
  • Irish quota in 6.aS, 7.b-c is allocated to vessels in 4 different size categories.
  • The Irish herring fishery in 6.a opened on 28 October 2019. This opening date coincides with the historical fishing period for the 6.aS, 7.b-c stock. There is an annual seasonal closure of the Butt of Lewis spawning area from the 15th August to the 15th September each year.
  • Irish and Dutch vessels are not allowed to fish herring inside the UK (Scottish) 6-12 nautical mile limits, including the outlying Hebridean Islands. German and French vessels have access to herring fishing between 6 and 12 nautical miles in Scottish waters in most areas, though not the mainland limits east of the Butt of Lewis.
Additional:
• An interbenchmark was held at the start of 2019 to address the retrospective bias that was observed in the assessment. The interbenchmark could not conclude a Category 1 assessment for the stock and the assessment is now Category 3, which is indicative of trends.
  • The trends based assessment gives a new perception of the stock with SSB revised downwards and F revised upwards since the early 1990s. A decrease in F can be seen since the reduction of the TACs in 6.aS, 7.b, 7.c and 6.aN, 5.b, 6.b in 2016.
  • SSB is now at its lowest level in the time series. Recruitment has been very low since 2013.
  • A rebuilding plan was developed by the Pelagic AC, evaluated by ICES in 2017 and found not to be precautionary. A revised rebuilding plan was proposed by the Pelagic AC in 2018 but has not been evaluated because the quality of the assessment and stock mixing need to be resolved before the evaluation can be conducted.
  • In 2016, a stock identification project was initiated which aims to develop genetic and morphometric methods to distinguish the 6.aS and 6.aN stocks. This work will be completed and a report produced in 2020.

Management:
• The long term management plan for Celtic Sea Herring was agreed by the Pelagic RAC in 2011. It was evaluated by ICES in 2012 and was found to be precautionary. It has not been agreed by all parties; therefore, ICES advises on the basis of the MSY approach.
  • The TAC is set on an annual basis but the assessments are carried out on a seasonal basis (1st April - 31st March).
  • The TAC in 2015 is 15,652 t, with an Irish quota of 13,527 t.
  • In 2015, up to 25% unused quota was allowed to be carried over from 2014. This was in response to the closure of the Russian market to EC fish products which negatively impacted the price of Irish herring. This carryover amounted to 4,223 t in 2015. ICES assumed that this will be caught in 2015. This assumption is included in the revised forecast provided in September 2015 and leads to a lower TAC in 2016 than was advised in June.
  • The Irish quota accounts for 86.4% of the total TAC.
  • The closure of Spawning Box C (Division VIIaS), to protect first time spawners was instituted by Irish statute in 2008. This fishery is confined to vessels of no more than 50 feet length. A maximum catch limitation of 11% of the Irish quota is exclusively allocated to this sentinel fishery.
  • In 2015/2016, spawning box B will be closed as part of the triennial box closures that are enshrined in EC legislation.
  • The UK, Netherlands, France and Germany are allowed to fish for herring to varying extents in the Irish territorial limits from 6-12 nm. However in recent years they have not availed of this right.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The long term management plan for Celtic Sea Herring was agreed by the Pelagic RAC in 2011 and has been the basis for TAC setting ever since. It was evaluated by ICES in 2012 and was found to be precautionary. It has not been agreed by all parties; therefore, ICES advises on the basis of the MSY approach.
  • The TAC is set on an annual basis but the assessments are carried out on a seasonal basis (1st April - 31st March).
  • The Irish quota accounts for 86.4% of the total TAC.
  • The closure of Spawning Box C (Division 7.aS), to protect first time spawners was instituted by Irish statute in 2008. This fishery is confined to vessels of no more than 50 feet in length. A maximum catch limitation of 11% of the Irish quota is exclusively allocated to this sentinel fishery.
  • In 2016/2017, spawning box B will be closed as part of the triennial box closures that are enshrined in EC legislation (see Appendix III).
  • The UK, Netherlands, France and Germany are allowed to fish for herring to varying extents in the Irish territorial limits from 6-12 nm. However in recent years they have not availed of this right.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to individual vessels on a weekly basis in two pools, one for the main fishery and one for the small boat fishery in Sub Division 7.aS.
Additional: • Juveniles of this stock are present in the Irish Sea. Management of the Irish Sea herring fishery should ensure that catches of Celtic Sea juveniles are avoided.

Management:
• The long term management plan for Celtic Sea Herring was agreed by the Pelagic RAC in 2011 and has been the basis for TAC setting ever since. It was evaluated by ICES in 2012 and was found to be precautionary. It has not been agreed by all parties; therefore, ICES advises on the basis of the MSY approach. FEAS notes an ambiguity in the management plan. The plan specifies that recruitment impairment [Blim] occurs at Bchangepoint; SSB = 41,000 t. However the latest value of Blim is 33,000 t. ICES and FEAS consider this revised value of Blim as being most appropriate in interpreting the plan.
  • The TAC is set on an annual basis but the assessments are carried out on a seasonal basis (1st April - 31st March).
  • The closure of Spawning Box C (Division 7.aS), to protect first time spawners was instituted by Irish statute in 2008. This fishery is confined to vessels of no more than 50 feet in length. A maximum catch limitation of 11% of the Irish quota is exclusively allocated to this sentinel fishery (see Appendix III).
  • In 2017/2018, Spawning Box C (see Appendix III) will be closed as part of the triennial box closures that are enshrined in EC legislation.
  • The UK, Netherlands, France and Germany are allowed to fish for herring to varying extents in the Irish territorial limits from 6-12 nm. However in recent years they have not availed of this right.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to individual vessels on a weekly basis in two pools, one for the main fishery and one for the small boat fishery in Sub-division 7.aS.
  • Currently the landing obligation only applies to pelagic gears (pelagic otter trawls, pair trawls).
Additional: • Juveniles and adults of this stock are present in the Irish Sea. Management of the Irish Sea herring fishery should ensure that catches of Celtic Sea fish in the Irish Sea are avoided.

Management:
• ICES evaluated the long term management plan in 2018 and advises that the harvest control rule is no longer consistent with the precautionary approach.
  • The plan was agreed by the Pelagic RAC in 2011 and was followed as the basis for setting TAC until 2018.
  • The Celtic Sea Herring Management Committee was established in 2005 to provide management advice to Irish administration.
  • The closure of Spawning Box C (Division 7.aS), to protect first time spawners was instituted by Irish statute in 2008. This fishery is confined to vessels of no more than 50 feet in length. A maximum catch limitation of 11% of the Irish quota is exclusively allocated to this sentinel fishery (see Appendix III).
  • In 2018/2019, Spawning Box A (see Appendix III) will be closed as part of the triennial box closures that are enshrined in EC legislation.
  • The UK, Netherlands, France and Germany are allowed to fish for herring to varying extents in the Irish territorial limits from 6-12 nm. However, in recent years they have not availed of this right.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to individual vessels on a weekly basis in two pools, one for the main fishery and one for the small boat fishery in Sub-division 7.aS.
  • The TAC is set annually but the assessment is carried out for the period 1st April - 31st March.
Additional:
• Recruitment has been below average since 2013.
  • An inter-benchmark was carried out on this stock in 2018. Revisions improved the assessment and there was little change in the perception of current stock status, which is just above Blim.
  • Since 2014, herring have been observed close to the seabed and are less reliably estimated by the acoustic survey. The 2017 survey was not included in the assessment because of low encounter rate of herring and biological sampling which was not representative of the stock.
  • Juveniles and adults of this stock are present in the Irish Sea. Management of the Irish Sea herring fishery should ensure that catches of Celtic Sea Herring in the Irish Sea are quantified.
  • Genetic work with UCD on stock mixing between the Irish Sea and Celtic Sea herring commenced in 2018.

Management:
• The advice and the TAC for 2019 are based on the MSY approach.
  • The Celtic Sea Herring Management Committee was established in 2005 to provide Industry input to the management of the Irish Celtic Sea herring fishery.
  • Spawning Box B will be closed from 1-16 November 2019 as part of the triennial spawning box closures that are enshrined in EC legislation.
  • The fishery in Division 7.aS is confined to vessels of no more than 17 m LOA. A maximum catch limitation of 11% of the Irish quota is exclusively allocated to this sentinel fishery.
  • The UK, Netherlands, France and Germany can fish for herring in the Irish territorial limits from 6-12 nm, however, in recent years they have not fished in this area.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to individual vessels on a weekly basis in two pools, one for the main fishery and one for the sentinel fishery in Division 7.aS.
  • The TAC is set by calendar year but the assessment is carried out for the period 1st April - 31st March.
  • The fishery for the main fleet opened on 15 September. The fishery was closed on 19 September following reports of high proportion of fish < MCRS in the catch. Two pairs of vessels were allowed to fish from 6-8 October to assess the size of the herring. As there was no evidence of high number of schools in which 90% fish > MCRS, the main fleet fishery was closed.
Additional:
• Recruitment has been below average since 2013. SSB has been below Blim since 2017.
  • Since 2014, herring have been observed close to the seabed and are less reliably estimated by the acoustic survey.
  • The 2017 survey was excluded from the assessment because of the low encounter rate of herring and biological sampling which was not representative of the stock.
  • The 2018 acoustic survey estimate is the lowest in the time series.
  • The addition of the 2018 catch and survey data to the assessment revised the SSB downwards and the mean F upwards.
  • In the past juveniles and adults of this stock were shown to be present in the Irish Sea. Genetic work on stock identification of the Irish Sea and Celtic Sea herring commenced in 2018. Tools to identify fish from each stock and information on the presence of Celtic Sea herring in the Irish Sea are expected by the end of 2019.
  • In response to an EU request to advise on minimum catch levels to support the assessment on a similar basis, ICES advised a total catch of 869 t.

Management:
• The TAC for this stock is set by EU and was 4,854 t for 2015. The Irish share of the TAC was 1,264 t (26%).
  • There are two closed areas in operation to protect the spawning stock during part of the spawning season and to prevent exploitation of juveniles. These measures were introduced during the period of the industrial fishery in the Irish Sea (1969 - 1979). The area off Counties Louth and Down is closed from the 21st September - 31st December and the Douglas Bank area, east of the Isle of Man is closed from 21st September until 15th November.
  • Vessels of less than 40 feet in length may fish within the Down-Louth seasonal closed box, but only using driftnets of mesh size ≥ 54 mm.
  • Republic of Ireland vessels are not permitted to fish herring in any part of the 0-12 mile limits off England, Wales, Scotland or the Isle of Man. This was established under the terms of the London Fisheries Agreement, 1964.
  • Republic of Ireland vessels are permitted to fish within the territorial limits of Northern Ireland under the ''Voisinage'' understanding. The ''Voisinage'' understanding provides a mechanism for reciprocal access to territorial limits by vessels from each jurisdiction within Ireland.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.a North.
  • There are two closed areas in operation to protect the spawning stock during part of the spawning season and to prevent exploitation of juveniles. These measures were introduced during the period of the industrial fishery in the Irish Sea (1969 - 1979). The area off Counties Louth and Down is closed from the 21st September - 31st December and the Douglas Bank area, east of the Isle of Man is closed from 21st September until 15th November.
  • Vessels of less than 40 feet in length may fish within the Down-Louth seasonal closed box, but only using driftnets of mesh size ≥ 54 mm.
  • Republic of Ireland vessels are not permitted to fish herring in any part of the 0-12 mile limits off England, Wales, Scotland or the Isle of Man. This was established under the terms of the London Fisheries Agreement, 1964.
  • Republic of Ireland vessels are permitted to fish within the territorial limits of Northern Ireland under Voisinage. This understanding provides a mechanism for reciprocal access to territorial limits by vessels from each jurisdiction within Ireland.
Additional:
• The assessment is performed on a mixed stock (including juveniles from the Celtic Sea), which effects the estimates of younger ages.
  • Management of the Irish Sea herring fishery should ensure that catches of Celtic Sea juveniles are avoided.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.a N.
  • There are two closed areas in operation to protect the spawning stock during part of the spawning season and to prevent exploitation of juveniles. These measures were introduced during the period of the industrial fishery in the Irish Sea (1969 - 1979). The area off County Louth and County Down is closed from the 21st September - 31st December and the Douglas Bank area, east of the Isle of Man is closed from 21st September until 15th November (Appendix II).
  • Vessels of less than 40 feet in length may fish within the Down- Louth seasonal closed box, but only using driftnets of mesh size \u2265 54 mm.
  • Republic of Ireland vessels are not permitted to fish herring in any part of the 0-12 nautical mile limits off England, Wales, Scotland or east of the Isle of Man. Irish vessels are permitted to fish in waters between 6-12 nautical miles, west of the Isle of Man.
  • Currently the landing obligation only applies to pelagic gears (pelagic otter trawls, pair trawls).
Additional:
• The assessment does not consider the degree of mixing of Celtic Sea and Irish Sea herring in the Irish Sea.
  • Management of the Irish Sea herring fishery should take into account mixing of Celtic Sea and Irish Sea herring in the Irish Sea.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.aN.
  • There are two closed areas in operation to protect the spawning stock during part of the spawning season and to prevent exploitation of juveniles. These measures were introduced during the period of the industrial fishery in the Irish Sea (1969 - 1979). The area off County Louth and County Down is closed from the 21st September - 31st December and the Douglas Bank area, east of the Isle of Man is closed from 21st September until 15th November (Appendix II).
  • Vessels of less than 40 feet in length may fish within the Down-Louth seasonal closed box, but only using driftnets of mesh size \u2265 54 mm.
  • Republic of Ireland vessels are not permitted to fish herring in any part of the 0-12 nautical mile limits off England, Wales, Scotland or east of the Isle of Man. Republic of Ireland vessels are permitted to fish in waters between 6-12 nautical miles, west of the Isle of Man.
Additional:
• Catches have been stable since 2005. SSB has been above the reference points and F has been below the reference points since 2007.
  • The 2017 benchmark changed the perception of the stock with upward revisions of SSB and downward revisions of F.
  • The assessment is carried out on a mixed stock and includes juveniles from the Celtic Sea.
  • The assessment may overestimate the Irish Sea stock due to the presence of herring from other socks.
  • Genetic work with UCD on stock mixing between the Irish Sea and Celtic Sea herring commenced in 2018. More information on the level of migration of Celtic Sea herring in the Irish Sea are expected by the end of 2020.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.aN.
  • There are two closed areas in operation to protect the spawning stock during part of the spawning season and to prevent exploitation of juveniles. These measures were introduced during the period of the industrial fishery in the Irish Sea (1969 - 1979). The area off County Louth and County Down is closed from the 21st September - 31st December and the Douglas Bank area, east of the Isle of Man is closed from 21st September until 15th November.
  • Vessels of less than 40 feet in length may fish within the Down-Louth seasonal closed box, but only using driftnets of mesh size ≥ 54 mm.
  • Republic of Ireland vessels are not permitted to fish herring in any part of the 0-12 nautical mile limits off England, Wales, Scotland or east of the Isle of Man. Republic of Ireland vessels are permitted to fish in waters between 6-12 nautical miles, west of the Isle of Man.
Additional:
• SSB has been above the reference points and F has been below the reference points since 2007.
  • Catches were stable from 2005-2017. In 2018, the catch increased due to an increase in TAC. It was the first time since 2006 that Irish vessels caught their herring quota in the Irish Sea.
  • The 2017 benchmark changed the perception of the stock with upward revisions of SSB and downward revisions of F.
  • The assessment is carried out on a mixed stock and includes juveniles from the Celtic Sea.
  • The assessment may overestimate the Irish Sea stock due to the presence of herring from other stocks.
  • Genetic work on stock identification of the Irish Sea and Celtic Sea herring commenced in 2018. Tools to identify fish from each stock and information on the presence of Celtic Sea herring in the Irish Sea in 2017 and 2018 are expected by the end of 2019.

Management:
• The Northern hake was managed for several years by means of a recovery plan in 2004 (EC 811/2004). The stock has recovered and a new stock assessment methodology is in place so there is a need to develop a new multiannual plan with new reference points and targets for this stock.
  • The current assessment area covers IIIa, IV, VI, VII and VIIIa,b,d. This overlaps with four TAC areas (see Table above). Ireland only has a quota for the TAC area VIb, VI, VII, XII, XIV. In 2015 the TAC in this area was 50,944 t with an associated Irish quota of 2,810 t
  • The combined TAC has been overshot considerably in recent years.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The assessment area overlaps with four TAC areas but Ireland only has quota for the 6, 7, 5.b, 12 and 14 TAC area.
  • About two thirds of the landings in the TAC area are taken in Irish waters; however Ireland only has a 6% TAC share.
  • Some fleets fishing this stock are under the EU landing obligation since 2016.
  • The minimum conservation reference size is 27cm (which is the same as the historic minimum landing size).
Additional:
• The Irish landings of hake are mainly taken in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, megrim, haddock and other gadoid species. However, 20% of the landings come from trips where hake was the dominant species.
  • The stock size has increased dramatically since 2008 and is now well above MSY BTRIGGER, while fishing mortality has decreased and is now below FMSY.
  • The assessment model is very sensitive to the settings used and suffers from a strong retrospective bias.

Management:
• The assessment area overlaps with four TAC areas but Ireland only has quota for the 6, 7, 5.b, 12 and 14 TAC area. Several inter-area flexibilities are allowed within the overall all TAC of 11,9765 t.
  • About two thirds of the landings in the TAC area are taken in Irish waters; however Ireland only has a 6% TAC share.
  • For trawls and seines where the total landings per vessel of all species in 2015 and 2016 consist of more than 10% of hake, the landing obligation shall apply to hake in 2018 (see Appendix VI).
  • For gill nets and long lines all catches of hake shall be subject to the landing obligation in 2018.
Additional:
• The Irish landings of hake are mainly taken in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, megrim, haddock and other gadoid species. However, 20% of the landings come from trips where hake was the dominant species.
  • The stock size has increased dramatically since 2008 and is now well above MSY Btrigger, while fishing mortality has decreased and is now below FMSY.

Management:
• The assessment area overlaps with three TAC areas but Ireland only has quota for the 6, 7, 5.b, 12 and 14 TAC area (shown in the pie chart). Several inter-area flexibilities are allowed within the overall TAC of 119,765 t.
  • About two thirds of the landings in the TAC area are taken in Irish waters; however, Ireland only has a 6% TAC share.
Additional:
• Irish trawlers in Sub-area 7 do not seem to target hake but take them as a by-catch in mixed fisheries with anglerfish, megrim, haddock and whiting. In Sub-area 6 trawlers target hake along the edge of the continental shelf. There are also targeted gillnet and seine fisheries for hake in Sub-area 7.
  • The spawning stock biomass has increased dramatically since 2006 and remains very high. In the last two years, the biomass decreased slightly, leading to a reduction in the TAC for 2018. However, the two most recent recruitment estimates are above-average so the biomass is expected to increase again, resulting in an increase in the catch advice.
  • The estimates of stock size in recent years have fluctuated widely, indicating that there is considerable uncertainty in the assessment.
  • International discard rates of hake in 2017 were about 6% of the total catch. However, Irish fleets have higher discard rates than most other countries. With the full introduction of the landing obligation, these unwanted catches will be deductible from the quota.

Management:
• The assessment area overlaps with three TAC areas but Ireland only has quota for the 6, 7, 5.b, 12 and 14 TAC area (shown in the pie chart). Several inter-area flexibilities are allowed within the TAC areas.
  • About two-thirds of the landings in the TAC area are taken in Irish waters; however, Ireland only has a 6% TAC share.
Additional:
• Most Irish trawlers in Sub-area 7 do not seem to target hake but take them as a bycatch in mixed fisheries with anglerfish, megrim, haddock and whiting. In Sub-area 6 trawlers target hake along the edge of the continental shelf. There are also targeted Irish gillnet and seine fisheries for hake in Sub-area 7.
  • The spawning-stock biomass (SSB) has increased substantially since 2006. In 2016 it reached the maximum in the time series, and since then it has declined slightly. Fishing mortality (F) decreased markedly between 2005 and 2012, and has been stable below FMSY since then.
  • Recruitment is variable without trend and the recent values estimated by the assessment were replaced by a mean because the assessment estimates were considered uncertain.
  • The estimates of stock size in recent years have fluctuated somewhat, indicating that the assessment is not very precise, however there is no evidence to suggest the assessment is biased.
  • International discard rates of hake in 2018 were just below 7% of the total catch. However, Irish fleets have higher discard rates than most other countries with an average of 24% in 2018.

Management:
• The TAC only applies to EU waters. There are fisheries outside the TAC areas that are not limited by the TAC.
  • Since 2005, when it was determined that catches from Division VIIIc were from the western stock, the ICES advice for the western stock has included Division VIIIc. The EU however continues to set a separate TAC for VIIIc.
  • The sum of the agreed TAC's for 2015 in Sub-areas VI, and Divisions IIa, IVa, VIIa-c, VIIe-k and VIII was 99,304 t, of which the Irish quota was 21,621 t.
  • The TAC's proposed by the commission only cover EU waters whereas the ICES advice covers all waters where the stock is fished.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The TAC only applies to EU waters. There are fisheries outside the TAC area that are not limited by the TAC.
  • The Faroe Islands have an additional allocation of 1,700 t, bringing the total TAC to 108,868 t.
  • Since 2005, advice for the Western Stock has included division 8.c. although the EU continues to set a separate TAC for division 8.c.
  • A long term management strategy is under development by Irish, UK and Dutch scientists and the Pelagic Advisory Council. This work will be informed by the benchmark assessment, planned for 2017.
Additional:
• The stock is currently below the MSY BTRIGGER and consequently the FMSY value used in the calculation of the advice for 2017 is reduced (to 0.09).
  • The stock and fishery are dependent on occasional high recruitments. Recruitment has been low since 2002 and SSB in 2016 is the lowest in the time series. Without strong recruitment, the stock and fishing opportunities will fall in the immediate future.
  • The 2017 advice implies an Irish quota of approximately 15,150 t.
  • A benchmark assessment is planned for 2017.

Management:
• The TAC only applies to EU waters. There are occasional fisheries outside the TAC area that are not limited by the TAC.
  • Since 2005, advice for the Western Stock has included division 8.c. although the EU continues to set a separate TAC for division 8.c.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may be fished in EU waters of 2.a and 4.a before 30th June and counted against the North Sea Horse Mackerel quota.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel. Should this provision be used, no interspecies flexibility may be used in respect of the bycatch species.
  • A long term management strategy is under development by the Pelagic Advisory Council. This work will be informed by the recent benchmark assessment.
  • The landing obligation has applied to horse mackerel directed fisheries in 5.b, 6 and 7 since 2015.
Additional:
• The assessment was benchmarked in 2017 and a new assessment model was implemented. This resulted in an upward revision of the SSB in recent years. The overall trajectory remains consistent with that given by the previous assessment with the stock currently at a historical low.
  • The stock is currently below the MSY Btrigger and consequently the FMSY value used in the calculation of the advice for 2018 is reduced (to 0.097).
  • In the past, the stock and fishery have been dependent on occasional high recruitments. There are indications of above average recruitment in recent years although it is not yet possible to determine the effect on future stock development.

Management:
• The TAC only applies to EU waters. There are occasional fisheries outside the TAC area that are not limited by the TAC.
  • Since 2005, ICES advice for the Western Stock has included division 8.c, although the EU continues to set a separate TAC for division 8.c.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may be fished in EU waters of 2.a and 4.a before 30th June and counted against the North Sea Horse Mackerel quota.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel. Should this provision be used, no interspecies flexibility may be used in respect of the bycatch species.
  • A long term management strategy is under development by the Pelagic Advisory Council.
Additional:
• The assessment was benchmarked in 2017 and a new assessment model was implemented. The new assessment has rescaled SSB and F upwards, although the overall decreasing stock trajectory remains consistent with that given by the previous assessment with the stock currently at an historical low.
  • In the past, the stock and fishery have been dependent on occasional high recruitments. There are indications of above average recruitment in recent years although it is not yet possible to determine the effect on future stock development.
  • An inter-benchmark exercise is scheduled for 2019 to consider the appropriateness of the current reference point values and their basis and to revise if necessary.

Management:
• The TAC only applies to EU waters. There are occasional fisheries outside the TAC area that are not limited by the TAC.
  • Since 2005, ICES advice for the Western Stock has included Division 8.c, although the EU continues to set a separate TAC for Division 8.c.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may be fished in EU waters of Divisions 2.a and 4.a before 30th June and counted against the North Sea Horse Mackerel quota.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel provided that, in combination with provisions for other bycatch species, the total does not exceed 9% of the quota.
  • A long term management strategy is under development by the Pelagic Advisory Council
Additional:
• The assessment was benchmarked in 2017 and a new assessment model was implemented. The benchmarked assessment rescaled SSB and F, although the overall decreasing stock trajectory remains consistent with that given previously, with the stock currently close to the historical low.
  • In the past, the stock and fishery have been dependent on occasional high recruitments. There are indications of above average recruitment in recent years although it is not yet possible to determine the effect on future stock development.
  • An interbenchmark in 2019 revised the PA and MSY reference points.

Management:
• The stock distribution area is Divisions IIIa, IVb,c, VIId and IVa in quarters 1 & 2.
  • New stock abundance indices and a management plan for the fishery are being developed.
  • The agreed TAC applies to EU waters in Division IVb,c and VIId. There is no TAC covering Norwegian waters or the small EU fisheries in IIIa.
  • The agreed TAC for 2015 in Division IVb,c and VIId was 15,200 t, of which the EU TAC was 11,650 t and Irish quota was 347 t.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The stock distribution area is divisions 3.a, 4b-c, 7.d and also 4.a in quarters 1 and 2.
  • The agreed TAC covers 4.b-c and 7.d. There is no TAC covering Norwegian waters or the fisheries in division 3.a.
  • Quota uptake has increased in recent years as the TAC has been reduced.
Additional:
• The stock is considered to be stable but at a low level.
  • Work is ongoing to develop survey based indices and an appropriate assessment method for the stock.
  • A benchmark assessment will take place in 2017.

Management:
• The stock distribution area is divisions 3.a, 4b-c, 7.d and also 4.a in quarters 1 and 2.
  • The agreed TAC covers 4.b-c and 7.d. There is no TAC covering Norwegian waters or the fisheries in divisions 3.a and 4.a (quarters 1 and 2).
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel. Should this provision be used, no interspecies flexibility may be used in respect of the bycatch species.
  • Quota uptake has increased in recent years as the TAC has been reduced. The largest proportion of catch is taken in division 7.d.
  • The landing obligation has applied to horse mackerel directed fisheries in 3.a and 4 since 2015.
Additional:
• The stock is considered to remain at a low level, although some signs of recovery are seen.
  • The stock was benchmarked in 2017 and an abundance index based on groundfish surveys in the North Sea was developed. Consequently, the stock is now in category 3 and the index is used to provide catch advice.
  • Discarding from demersal fleets is considered to be non-negligible but data is incomplete for years prior to 2015.

Management:
• The stock distribution area is divisions 3.a, 4b-c, 7.d and also 4.a in quarters 1 and 2.
  • The agreed TAC covers 4.b-c and 7.d. There is no TAC covering Norwegian waters or the fisheries in divisions 3.a and 4.a (quarters 1 and 2).
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel. Should this provision be used, no interspecies flexibility may be used in respect of the bycatch species.
  • Quota uptake has increased in recent years as the TAC has been reduced. The largest proportion of catch is taken in division 7.d where a large proportion of the catch consists of juvenile fish.
Additional:
• Advice for this stock is biennial. ICES advice was last issued in 2017.
  • The stock is considered to remain at a low level, although some signs of recovery are seen.
  • The stock was benchmarked in 2017 and an abundance index based on groundfish surveys in the North Sea was developed. Consequently, the stock is now in category 3 and the index is used to provide catch advice.
  • Data for 2015-2017 indicates that discarding from demersal fleets operating in Division 7.d accounted for approximately 10% of the total catch. Data is incomplete prior to 2015.

Management:
• The stock distribution area is Divisions 3.a, 4.b-c, 7.d and also 4.a in quarters 1 and 2.
  • The agreed TAC covers 4.b-c and 7.d. There is no TAC covering Norwegian waters or the fisheries in Divisions 3.a and 4.a (quarters 1 and 2).
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel provided that, in combination with provisions for other bycatch species, the total does not exceed 9% of the quota.
  • Quota uptake has increased in recent years as the TAC has been reduced. The largest proportion of catch is taken in Division 7.d where a large proportion of the catch consists of juvenile fish.
