Additional: • Irish landings of plaice in this area are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, whiting and megrim.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 and Division 5.b.
  • There are no explicit management plans for this stock.
  • The Emergency Measures (EC 43/2009) limits the mesh size of bottom trawls (TR1) in this area to >120 mm.
Additional: • Irish landings of plaice in this area are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, whiting and megrim.

Management:
• The TAC for 2015 was 1,098 t with an associated Irish quota of 768 t. The Hague preference agreement enables Ireland to claim an enhanced share of the TAC.
  • The disparity between minimum landing size and mesh size of the gear being used is evidenced by very high discard rates (up to 80% by number).
  • Effort reductions as part of the Cod Long Term Management Plan (EC Reg.1342/2008) will also reduce catch and discarding of plaice in this area.
  • FEAS recommends that management objectives be established and that a management plan be developed and implemented for fisheries catching plaice.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The disparity between minimum landing size and mesh size of the gear being used is evidenced by very high discard rates (up to 70% by number).
  • Effort reductions as part of the Cod Long Term Management Plan (EC Reg.1342/2008) will also reduce catch and discarding of plaice in this area.
  • FEAS recommends that management objectives be established and that a management plan be developed and implemented for fisheries catching plaice.
Additional:
• A quarter of Irish landings of Irish Sea plaice come from trips where plaice was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with rays and haddock.
  • Discards have increased in recent years and now 70% of the catch is discarded, posing challenges for implementation of the landings obligation.

Management:
• The disparity between minimum landing size and mesh size of the gear being used is evidenced by very high discard rates (up to 70% by number).
  • The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
Additional:
• A quarter of Irish landings of Irish Sea plaice come from trips where plaice was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with rays and haddock.
  • The majority of Irish otter trawl discards are between 15-30cm (the MCRS is 27cm). The majority of discards for this stock are from otter trawls. It is likely that a proportion of the discards survive, however studies should be done to confirm this.
  • Discards have increased in recent years and now 70% of the catch is discarded, posing challenges for implementation of the landing obligation.

Management:
• The disparity between minimum landing size and mesh size of the gear being used is evidenced by very high discard rates (up to 82% by number).
  • The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
Additional:
• Stock size has shown a continuing upward trend, with SSB above MSY Btrigger since 2013, and F is below FMSY since 2011.
  • Irish landings of this stock are caught as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery, and are mainly landed with Nephrops and haddock.
  • Landings from Irish fleets have increased in recent years in line with the increased biomass, although they are still well below the quota.
  • Discards have increased in recent years, with 60% (by weight) of the catch being discarded in 2017.
  • Discards of plaice are considered to have a survivability of about 40%. Under the Landing Obligation Irish sea plaice have a high survivability exemption. This exemption applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kW) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (≤ 221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel. This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
  • In 2018 Ireland had 73% of the landings. In 2019 Ireland retained the largest share of the quota, despite dropping from 70% (2018) to 49% (2019). Conversely the UK quota increased from 26% to 44%. This however relates to an increase in quota, from 1,255 t to 1,488 t.
Additional:
• Stock size has shown a continuing upward trend, with SSB above MSY Btrigger since 2013, and F is below FMSY since 2011.
  • Irish landings of this stock are caught as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery, and are mainly landed with Nephrops and haddock.
  • Landings from Irish fleets have increased in recent years in line with the increased biomass, although they are still well below the quota.
  • Discards have increased in recent years, with 48% (by weight) of the catch being discarded in 2018.
  • Discards of plaice are considered to have a survivability of about 40%. Under the Landing Obligation Irish Sea plaice have a high survivability exemption. This exemption applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kW) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel. This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The TAC covers Divisions VIIb and VIIc. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
  • The 2015 TAC was 74 t with an associated Irish quota of 63 t (79%). Ireland was allocated the largest share of the TAC.
  • This stock is mainly caught within coastal mixed fisheries by Irish otter trawlers.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and although recent landings have been below the TAC. If it is further reduced, the TAC might become restrictive.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The TAC covers Divisions 7.b and 7.c. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
  • Ireland was allocated the largest share of the TAC.
  • This stock is mainly caught within coastal mixed fisheries by Irish otter trawlers.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and although recent landings have been below the TAC. If it is further reduced, the TAC might become restrictive.
Additional: • Irish landings of West of Ireland plaice are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, whiting and megrim.

Management:
• The TAC covers Divisions 7.b and 7.c. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
  • This stock is mainly caught within coastal mixed fisheries by Irish otter trawlers.
  • The stock is managed by TAC although recent landings have been below the TAC. If it is further reduced, the TAC might become restrictive.
Additional: • Irish landings of West of Ireland plaice are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, whiting and megrim.

Management:
• The TAC covers Divisions 7.b and 7.c. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
  • Recent landings have been well below the TAC.
Additional:
• Irish landings of this stock are caught by otter trawlers, as a minor bycatch in a mixed fisheries, mainly targeting rays. In some years there has also been a more targeted gillnet fishery (but not since 2012).
  • Discards in these fisheries are unknown.
  • As a result of the documented high survivability of discarded plaice, a proposed high survivability exemption may be implemented in 2019. This exemption would apply to beam trawls (≤ 221kW) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (≤ 221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel. This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
  • Recent landings have been well below the TAC.
Additional:
• Irish landings of this stock are caught by otter trawlers, as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery, mainly targeting rays. In some years there has also been a more targeted gillnet fishery (but not since 2012).
  • Discarded plaice are considered to have a survivability of approximately 40%. An exemption to the Landing Obligation applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kW) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel (2019/7048 & 2018/190) in ICES division 7a to 7k. This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions VIIfg. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
  • The 2015 TAC was 461 t with an associated Irish quota of 202 t.
  • There are no explicit management objectives or plans for this stock. The NWWRAC is developing a mixed fisheries management plan for VIIfg.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions 7.f-g. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
  • There are no explicit management objectives or plans for this stock.
Additional:
• Irish landings of Celtic Sea plaice are taken as a minor by-catch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with whiting, megrim, anglerfish as well as other gadoids.
  • The majority of Irish otter trawl discards are between 20-30cm (the MCRS is 27cm). The majority of discards for this stock are from beam trawlers targeting sole with 80mm cod-ends. It is likely that a significant proportion of the discards survive.
  • Discards have increased in recent years and now 73% of the catch is discarded, posing challenges for implementation of the landings obligation.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions 7.f-g. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
  • There are no explicit management objectives or plans for this stock.
Additional:
• Irish landings of Celtic Sea plaice are taken as a minor by-catch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with whiting, megrim, anglerfish as well as other gadoids.
  • Discards have increased in recent years and now ~70% of the catch is discarded, posing challenges for implementation of the landing obligation.
  • The majority of Irish otter trawl discards are between 20-30cm (the MCRS is 27cm). The majority of discards for this stock are from beam trawlers targeting sole with 80mm cod-ends. It is likely that a proportion of the discards survive, however studies should be done to confirm this.

Management: • The TAC area covers Divisions 7.f-g. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
Additional:
• The stock status for Celtic Sea plaice is that F is well below the FMSY proxy and SSB well above the proxy for MSY Btrigger.
  • This stock will be benchmarked by ICES in 2020.
  • Irish landings of Celtic Sea plaice are taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with whiting and other gadoids, megrim, anglerfish.
  • Discards have increased in recent years and now ~70% of the catch is discarded. The majority of discards for this stock are from otter trawlers. Discards of plaice from Irish otter trawl operating in this area range in size between 20-30cm (MCRS 27cm).
  • Discards of plaice are considered to have a survivability of about 40%. Under the Landing Obligation Celtic Sea plaice have a high survivability exemption. This exemption would apply to beam trawls (≤ 221kW) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (≤ 221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel.

Management:
• The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
  • In 2018 Ireland took 12% of the landings. In 2019, there was an overall increase in European plaice quota, from 511 to 1,662 t. Ireland's quota was reduced from 40% to 15%, while France increased from 29% to 41%. However, this TAC is not restrictive.
Additional:
• Currently fishing pressure is well below the FMSY proxy and SSB well above the MSY Btrigger proxy
  • Irish landings of Celtic Sea plaice are taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with whiting and other gadoids, megrim and anglerfish.
  • Discards have increased in recent years and in 2018 55% of the catch was discarded. The majority of discards for this stock are from beam trawlers. Discards of plaice from Irish otter trawls operating in this area range in size between 20-30cm (MCRS 27cm).
  • Discards of plaice are considered to have a survivability of about 40%. Under the Landing Obligation Celtic Sea plaice have a high survivability exemption. This exemption applies to otter trawls; trammel nets; and beam trawls (≤ 221kW) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel (EC 2019/7048 & 2018/190).

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions VIIh-k. The assessment area also covers VIIh-k but there is insufficient data from VIIh to support an assessment and there are negligible landings from VIIk, therefore the assessment is carried out using data from VIIj only under the assumption that the trends are representative of VIIh-k.
  • The 2015 TAC was 135 t with an associated Irish quota of 59 t (44%). The Irish quota has become very restrictive in recent years.
  • There are no specific management objectives for this stock.
  • This stock is mainly caught within coastal mixed fisheries by otter trawlers in VIIj.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions 7.h-k. The assessment area also covers 7.h-k but there is insufficient data from 7.h to support an assessment and there are negligible landings from 7.k, therefore the assessment is carried out using data from 7.j only under the assumption that the trends are representative of 7.h-k.
  • The Irish quota has become very restrictive in recent years.
  • There are no specific management objectives for this stock.
  • This stock is mainly caught within coastal mixed fisheries by otter trawlers in 7.j.
Additional: • Irish landings of Southwest of Ireland plaice are taken as a minor by-catch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish, whiting and hake.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions 7.h-k. The assessment area also covers 7.h-k but there is insufficient data from 7.h to support an assessment and there are negligible landings from 7.k, therefore the assessment is carried out using data from 7.j only. This is under the assumption that the trends are representative of 7.h-k.
  • The Irish quota has become very restrictive in recent years and this may have led to increased discarding.
Additional:
• Irish landings of Southwest of Ireland plaice are taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish, whiting and hake.
  • Spawning stock biomass is below Blim therefore there is at a reduced reproductive capacity.
  • There is an indication of high survivability in discards of plaice, however studies should be conducted to verify this.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions 7.h-k. However, the assessment is conducted using data from 7.jk only, as there is insufficient landings-at-age data for 7.h. The assessment assumes that data trends in 7.jk are representative of those in 7.h.
  • The Irish quota has been not been restrictive since 2014.
Additional:
• Irish landings of this stock are caught as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery, and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish, haddock and hake.
  • Stock size has shown a continuing downward trend since the 1990s, with spawning-stock biomass (SSB) below Blim since 2002, therefore this stock is considered to have a reduced reproductive capacity.
  • As a result of the documented high survivability of discarded plaice, a proposed high survivability exemption may be implemented in 2019. This exemption would apply to beam trawls (≤ 221kW) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (≤ 221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel. This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.
  • This stock will be benchmarked by ICES in 2020 to incorporate increased biological sampling in 7h.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions 7.h-k. However, the assessment is conducted using data from 7.j and 7.k only, as there is insufficient landings-at-age data for 7.h. The assessment assumes that data trends in 7.j and 7.k are representative of those in 7.h.
  • The Irish quota has not been restrictive since 2014.
Additional:
• Fishing pressure is highly variable but has been above Flim for most of the entire time-series. Spawning-stock biomass has been below Blim since 2002.
  • Irish landings of this stock are caught as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery, and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish, haddock and whiting.
  • Stock size has shown a continuing downward trend since the 1990s, with spawning-stock biomass (SSB) below Blim since 2002, therefore this stock is considered to have a reduced reproductive capacity.
  • As a result of the documented high survivability of discarded plaice, a high survivability exemption is in place for 2020. This exemption applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kW) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel. This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The assessment area comprises two TAC areas; the first TAC area comprises Divisions IIa, IIIabcd, and Sub-area IV, the second TAC area covers Division Vb as well as Subareas VI, XII and XIV.
  • The total EC TAC for Division Vb and Sub-areas VI, XII and XIV in 2015 was 6,848 t, with an Irish quota of 389 t.
  • There is a long-term management plan for this stock based on the EU-Norway agreement that states that every effort should be made to maintain SSB above 199,270 t (Blim) and a TAC consistent with F = 0.3. Should SSB fall below Bpa this fishing mortality will be adapted in the light of the prevailing conditions (see ACOM advice for detailed description of the management plan).
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The assessment area comprises two TAC areas; the first TAC area covers Divisions 2a, 3abcd, and Sub-area 4, the second TAC area covers Division 5b as well as Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14. Ireland only has a quota for the latter.
  • Ireland has not taken its full quota in recent years.
  • There is a long-term management plan for this stock based on the EU-Norway agreement. However, changes to the stock assessment and reference points in 2016 imply a need to reevaluate the EU-Norway management strategy. Until such an evaluation is conducted, the ICES advice is based on the MSY approach.
  • The minimum conservation reference size is 35cm (unchanged from the minimum landing size).
Additional:
• One-third of Irish landings of saithe in 3a,4,6 come from trips where saithe was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with haddock, anglerfish and megrim.
  • The 2016 stock assessment of saithe is a benchmarked assessment based on the revised assessment protocol specified by the 2016 meeting of ICES WKNSEA to provide a solution to the uncertainty in the assessment and forecast due to the highly uncertain and fluctuating survey indices.

Management:
• The assessment area comprises two TAC areas; the first TAC area covers Divisions 2.a, 3.a, and Sub-area 4, the second TAC area covers Division 5.b as well as Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 (see Pie Plot of 2017 Quota Allocations).
  • Ireland only has a quota for the latter TAC area and has not taken its full quota in recent years. The EU quota excludes the 510 t allocation for Norway reflected in the overall TAC. The EU-Norway agreement adds a Top-up of 4.1% to this TAC making the total value 10,404t.
  • There is a long-term management plan for this stock based on the EU-Norway agreement. However, changes to the stock assessment and reference points in 2016 imply a need to re-evaluate the EU-Norway management strategy. Until such an evaluation is conducted, the ICES advice is based on the MSY approach.
  • Trawl fisheries with cod ends ≥ 100 mm in 6 and 5.b. are subject to the landing obligation for saithe in 2018 (see Appendix VI).
Additional: • One-third of Irish landings of saithe in 3.a, 4 and 6 come from trips where saithe was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with haddock, anglerfish and megrim.

Management:
• The assessment area includes two TAC areas; the first TAC area covers Divisions 2.a, 3.a, and Sub-area 4. The second TAC area covers Division 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 (Pie Plot of 2018 Quota Allocations for 5.b, 6, 12 and 14).
  • Ireland only has a quota for the latter TAC area (5.b, 6, 12 and 14). The EU quota excludes the 640 t allocation for Norway reflected in the overall TAC. The EU-Norway agreement adds a top-up of 4.76% to this TAC making the total value 10,701t for 2018.
  • There is a long-term management plan for this stock based on the EU-Norway agreement. However, changes to the stock assessment and reference points in 2016 imply a need to re-evaluate the EU-Norway management strategy. Until such an evaluation is conducted, the ICES advice is based on the MSY approach.
  • From July 2018; saithe in Division 3.a and Sub-areas 4 and 6 are subject to the EU regulation 2018/973 which introduced a multi-annual plan for several demersal stocks.
Additional:
• Ireland has not taken its full quota in recent years and the preliminary landings figures for 2018 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the quota.
  • Advice for 2018 was 118,460 t, for 2019 the advice is 135,035 t; an increase of 16,575 t (+14%).

Management:
• The assessment area includes two TAC areas; the first TAC area covers Divisions 2.a, 3.a, and Sub-area 4. The second TAC area covers Division 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14.
  • Ireland only has a quota for the latter TAC area (5.b, 6, 12 and 14). The EU quota excludes the 940 t allocation for Norway reflected in the overall TAC making the total value 9,713 t for 2019.
  • In February 2019 ICES reissued North Sea, Rockall and West of Scotland, Skagerrak and Kattegat catch advice for 2019, and following consultations with Norway the TAC was revised and decreased by 2,980 t.
Additional:
• Ireland has not taken its full quota in recent years and the preliminary landings figures for 2019 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the quota.
  • The 2019 catch advice of 135,035 t issued in November 2018, was updated in February 2019 to 103,327 t. The advice for 2020 is 88,093 t; a decrease of 15,234 t from the updated 2019 advice (-14.7%), owing to a downward revision in stock size and low incoming recruitment.

Management:
• The TAC covers Sub-areas VII, VIII, IX and X.
  • Ireland holds the greatest TAC share (45%), followed by France (41%).
  • The 2015 TAC was 3,176 t with an associated Irish quota of 1,491 t.
  • The TAC is not restrictive on catch but Irish landings have increased to levels close to the Irish quota.
  • Given the mixed nature of fisheries catching saithe, it is unrealistic to develop a management plan for this stock. Ireland, as the main participant in this fishery, has an opportunity to develop and implement a management strategy for mixed fisheries in this area.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The TAC covers Sub-areas 7, 8, 9 and 10.
  • Ireland holds the greatest TAC share (45%), followed by France (41%).
  • The TAC is not restrictive but Irish landings have increased to levels close to the Irish quota.
  • Some fleets fishing this stock are under the EU landing obligation since 2016.
  • The minimum conservation reference size is 35cm (which is the same as the historic minimum landing size).
Additional: • One-third of Irish landings of saithe in Sub-area 7 come from trips where saithe was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with hake and whiting.

Management:
• The Joint statement by the Fisheries Council and European Commission states it would be desirable if the TAC for this stock be maintained for 5 years (subject to scientific advice).
  • The TAC covers Sub-areas 7, 8, 9 and 10.
  • Landing obligation applies to trawls and seiners using > 100mm cod ends targeting saithe.
Additional: • One-third of Irish landings of saithe in Sub-area 7 come from trips where saithe was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with hake and whiting.

Management:
• The TACs for "Ad Specific Data Limited Stocks" included in the Joint statement by the Fisheries Council and European Commission in 2013 (Council document PECHE 13, 5232/14) will be maintained for a further 4 years (beyond 2018), subject to scientific advice unless the perception of the status of any of these stocks changes significantly during this period (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-6016_en.htm).
  • The TAC covers Sub-areas 7, 8, 9 and 10 (Pie Plot of 2018 Quota Allocations).
Additional:
• Irish landings of saithe in Sub-area 7 are mainly taken by gillnets, however, in some years considerable by-catches of saithe are landed with hake, whiting and pollack by OTB fleets.
  • Preliminary ICES landings figures for 2017, show the lowest Irish landings over the last five years. There is little discarding of Saithe in Irish fisheries.
  • Preliminary landings figures for 2018 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the quota.

Management:
• The TACs for "Ad Specific Data Limited Stocks" included in the Joint statement by the Fisheries Council and European Commission in 2013 (Council document PECHE 13, 5232/14) will be maintained for a further 4 years (beyond 2018), subject to scientific advice unless the perception of the status of any of these stocks changes significantly during this period (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-6016_en.htm).
  • The TAC covers Sub-areas 7, 8, 9 and 10 (Pie Plot of 2019 Quota Allocations).
Additional:
• Irish landings of saithe in Sub-area 7 are mainly taken by gillnets, however, in some years considerable by-catches of saithe are landed with hake, whiting and pollack by bottom trawler fleets.
  • ICES landings figures for 2018 show the lowest Irish landings over the last five years. There is little discarding of saithe in Irish fisheries.
  • Preliminary landings figures for 2019 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the quota.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas for which Ireland has quota.
  • The ''Joint statement by the Council and the Commission'' states it would be desirable if the TAC for Pollack in VI; EU and international waters of Vb; international waters of XII and XIV of 397 t with an Irish quota of 56 t was maintained for 5 years (subject to scientific advice).
  • The ''joint statement'' does not appear to extend to VII Pollack. The 2015 TAC for VII was 13,495 t with an associated Irish quota of 1,030 t. Quota uptake by Ireland has been high in recent years and is being actively managed to remain below the quota.
  • There are no explicit management plans for this stock.
  • FEAS advises that management objectives be established and that a management plan be developed and implemented for fisheries catching pollack.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The advice is biennial.
  • There are two TAC areas that cover this stock. Ireland has quota for both.
  • Quota uptake in the TAC area 5b, 6, 12 and 14 is low.
  • The 2015 TAC for area 7 was 13,495 t with an associated Irish quota of 1,030 t. Quota uptake by Ireland has been high in recent years and is being actively managed to remain below the quota.
  • The minimum conservation reference size is 30cm.
Additional:
• The current TACs are well above the recent average reported landings due to substantial low uptake of some countries.
  • Commercial landings may not reflect true pollack catches since recreational fisheries may well be significant.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas that cover this stock. Ireland has quota for both.
  • The current TACs are well above the recent average reported landings due to low uptake by some countries.
  • Quota uptake in the TAC area 5.b, 6, 12 and 14 is low. The quota uptake in TAC area 7 is higher, of which 2% may be fished in Divisions 8.a,b,d,e.
  • Quota uptake by Ireland in 7 has been high in recent years and is being actively managed to remain below the quota.
  • Fisheries in 7.d and 7.e are subject to the landing obligation for pollack in 2018 (see Appendix VI).
Additional:
• The Marine Institute is currently engaged in a project aimed at improving the assessment of pollack and gaining more insight into biological aspects of the species.
  • Commercial landings may not reflect true pollack catches since recreational fisheries are thought to be significant.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas that cover this stock. Ireland has quota for both. The first TAC area covers Divisions 5.b and Sub-area 6, 12 and 14. The second TAC area covers Sub-areas 7. 2% of this TAC may be fished in Divisions 8.a, b, d, e.
  • The current TACs are well above the recent average reported landings due to low uptake by some countries.
  • Quota uptake in the TAC area 5.b, 6, 12 and 14 is low. The quota uptake in TAC area 7 is substantially higher and uptake by Ireland has been high in recent years and is being actively managed to remain below the quota.
  • In 2018 pollack in Sub-area 7 was subject to an EU request to provide FMSY ranges, however, methods for calculating proxy FMSY ranges for data limited stocks have not been developed by ICES.
Additional:
• Preliminary landings figures for 2018 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the quota.
  • Irish landings of pollack are mainly taken by gillnets, however, in some years considerable by-catches of pollack are landed with hake, whiting and saithe by OTB fleets.
  • A precautionary buffer of -20% was applied to the advice for 2019 because of decreasing catches by France and UK in area 7. This has reduced the advice from 4,200 t in 2018 to 3,360 t in 2019 - a decrease of 840 t (-20%).
  • The Marine Institute is currently engaged in a project aimed at improving the assessment of pollack and gaining more insight into biological aspects of the species.
  • Commercial landings may not reflect true pollack catches since recreational fisheries are thought to be significant. Ireland propose to carry out a project in 2019 under the EMFF (DCMAP) to evaluate the catches from recreational fisheries.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas that cover this stock. Ireland has quota for both. The first TAC area covers Divisions 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14. The second TAC area covers Sub-area 7. Up to 2% of the latter TAC may be fished in Divisions 8.a, b, d and e.
  • Low quota uptake by some countries mean that the current TACs are well above the reported landings.
  • Quota uptake by Ireland in Sub-areas 5.b, 6, 12 and 14 is about 60%. The quota uptake by Ireland in Sub-area 7 is higher, with 80% of the quota utilised in 2018.
Additional:
• Preliminary landings figures for 2019 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the Irish quota.
  • Irish landings of pollack are mainly taken by gillnets, however, in some years considerable by-catches of pollack are landed with hake, whiting and saithe by OTB fleets.
  • The Marine Institute is currently engaged in a project aimed at improving the assessment of pollack and gaining more insight into biological aspects of the species. This stock is scheduled to be benchmarked by ICES in 2021.
  • Commercial landings may not reflect true pollack catches since recreational fisheries are thought to comprise a significant component of total catch. A recent study (Radford et al., 2018) estimated that recreational catches are approximately 3,500 t per year.
  • Ireland are due to commence an EMFF (DCMAP) funded project aiming to evaluate recreational catches.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Sub-areas VI, XII, XIV and Division Vb0.
  • The TAC in 2015 was 57 t with an associated Irish quota of 46 t.
  • There are no explicit management objectives or plans for this stock.
  • The Emergency Measures (EC 43/2009) limits the mesh size of bottom trawls (TR1) in this area to >120 mm.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management: • The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6, 12, 14 and Division 5.b.
Additional: • The Emergency Measures (EC 43/2009) limits the mesh size of bottom trawls (TR1) in this area to >120 mm.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6, 12, 14 and Division 5.b.
  • Vessel targeting gadoids and Nephrops with trawls and seines will be subject to the EU landing obligation for sole from 2018 (see Appendix VI).
Additional: • The Emergency Measures (EC 43/2009) limits the mesh size of bottom trawls (TR1) and seines targeting demersal fish in this area to >120 mm .

Management:
• The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6, 12, 14 and EU and international waters of Division 5.b. This TAC has been unchanged at 57 t since 2013.
  • The TACs for data limited stocks included in the Joint statement by the Fisheries Council and European Commission (Council document PECHE 13, 5232/14) will be maintained for a further 4 years (beyond 2018), subject to scientific advice unless the perception of the status of any of these stocks changes significantly during this period (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-6016_en.htm).
Additional: • The Emergency Measures (EC 43/2009) limits the mesh size of bottom trawls (TR1) and seines targeting demersal fish in the part of this area where sole are most likely to be caught, to >120 mm. This mesh size is too large to target sole.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6, 12, 14 and EU and international waters of Division 5.b. This TAC has been unchanged at 57 t since 2013.
  • The TACs for data limited stocks included in the Joint statement by the Fisheries Council and European Commission (Council document PECHE 13, 5232/14) will be maintained for a further 4 years (beyond 2018), subject to scientific advice unless the perception of the status of any of these stocks changes significantly during this period (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-6016_en.htm).
Additional: • The Emergency Measures (EC 43/2009) limits the mesh size of bottom trawls (TR1) and seines targeting demersal fish in the part of this area where sole are most likely to be caught, to >120 mm. This mesh size is too large to target sole.

Management:
• The TAC area (Division VIIa) corresponds to the assessment area.
  • The TAC in 2015 was 90t with an Irish quota of 38t.
  • FEAS recommends that management objectives be established and that a management plan be developed and implemented for fisheries catching sole.
  • Effort reductions as part of the Cod Long Term Management Plan (EC Reg.1342/2008) will also reduce catch and discarding of sole in this area.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management: • The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.a.
Additional: • Irish landings of Irish Sea sole are mainly taken in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with rays and to a lesser extent also anglerfish and Nephrops.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.a.
  • The Irish allocation of 17 t is exclusively for by-catch and no directed fisheries are permitted.
  • In addition to the TAC, member states are allowed to allocate an extra 7 t for vessels carrying out a directed scientific fishery.
Additional: • Irish landings of Irish Sea sole are mainly taken in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with rays and to a lesser extent also anglerfish and Nephrops.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.a.
  • The Irish allocation of 17 t was exclusively for by-catch and no directed fisheries were permitted in 2018.
Additional:
• Previous catch advice for this stock has been 0 t as Blim could not be achieved in 2018, even with no fishing occurring.
  • Because of higher recruitment in 2015 and 2016, SSB is increasing and is predicted to be above Blim and below MSY Btrigger in 2019 and consequently a non-zero catch advice is given for 2019.
  • This fishery was worth € 180,000 in 2017.
  • Discarding is low for this stock (2 t in 2017, about 6%).
  • Irish landings of Irish Sea sole are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting rays and plaice in the St. George's Channel and to a lesser extent also in the Nephrops fishery. Most landings are from beam trawlers but an increasing proportion of landings are from the otter trawl fleets.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.a.
  • The TAC was set exclusively for bycatch and no directed fisheries were permitted in 2019. The Irish bycatch quota allocation was 74 t.
  • The TAC for this stock has increased from 40 t in 2018 to 414 t in 2019.
Additional:
• The catch advice for 2020 has increased compared to previous years due to an increase in stock size and high recruitment.
  • This catch was worth € 212,000 in 2018.
  • Discarding is low for this stock (2 t in 2018, about 5%).
  • Irish landings of Irish Sea sole are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting rays and plaice in the St. George's Channel and to a lesser extent also in the Nephrops fishery. Most landings are from beam trawlers but an increasing proportion of landings are from the otter trawl fleets.

Management:
• The TAC covers Divisions VIIb and VIIc. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
  • The 2015 TAC was 42 t with an associated Irish quota of 36 t.
  • There are no explicit management objectives or plan for this stock.
  • This stock is mainly caught within coastal mixed fisheries by Irish otter trawlers.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and although recent landings have generally been below the TAC. If it is further reduced, the TAC is likely to become restrictive.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.b and 7.c.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and although recent landings have generally been below the TAC. If it is further reduced, the TAC is likely to become restrictive.
Additional: • Irish landings of West of Ireland sole are mainly taken in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, megrim and Nephrops.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.b and 7.c.
  • The stock is managed by TAC although recent landings have been close to the TAC.
  • Fisheries in 7.b,c are subject to the landing obligation for sole in 2018 (see Appendix VI). These fisheries are only applicable to beam trawls, trammel and gill nets and Irish landings are largely from the otter board trawl fleet.
Additional: • Irish landings of West of Ireland sole are mainly taken in mixed fisheries tending to be landed with anglerfish, megrim and Nephrops.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.b and 7.c.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent landings have been close to the TAC.
  • Fisheries in 7.b,c were subject to the landing obligation for sole in 2018.
Additional: • Irish landings of West of Ireland sole are mainly taken as a bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting Nephrops and the other bottom trawl fisheries that occur in relatively shallow water (less than 200m) of area 7b.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Divisions 7.b and 7.c.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent landings have been close to the TAC.
Additional: • Irish landings of West of Ireland sole are mainly taken as a bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting Nephrops and the other bottom trawl fisheries that occur in relatively shallow water (less than 200m) of area 7.b.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions VIIfg. The assessment area is the same as the TAC area.
  • The 2015 TAC was 851 t with an associated Irish quota of 27 t.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management: • The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.f and 7.g
Additional: • Irish landings of Celtic Sea sole are mainly taken in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish, Nephrops and gadoids.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.f and 7.g
  • The Irish quota is very restrictive with a 1% bycatch quota in sole for most months.
  • Fisheries in 7.f and 7.g using beam trawls and gill nets are subject to the landing obligation for sole in 2018 (see Appendix VI).
Additional: • Irish landings of Celtic Sea sole are mainly taken in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish, Nephrops and gadoids.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.f and 7.g
  • The Irish quota is very restrictive, Ireland applies a 1% bycatch quota in sole for most months (DAFM, Fisheries management Notices).
Additional:
• In 2018, SSB is estimated to be just above MSY Btrigger and Fishing mortality is above FMSY. The 2015 and 2017 recruitment are estimated to be have been well above average with the latter being the second highest in the time-series.
  • This fishery was worth € 260,000 in 2017.
  • Discarding is low for this stock (42 t in 2017, about 5%).
  • Irish landings of Celtic Sea sole are mainly taken as a minor by-catch in mixed fisheries targeting Nephrops and are in mixed beam trawl fisheries off the south coast.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.f and 7.g.
  • The Irish quota is very restrictive, Ireland applies a 1% bycatch quota in sole for most months (DAFM, Fisheries management Notices).
Additional:
• There was an inter-benchmark in 2019 (ICES 2019b) for this stock which lead to a substantial change in perception of the stock with an upward revision of the stock size and recruitment, and a downward revision of the F to below FMSY. As a result, a special request was made to ICES for a revision of catch advice for 2019.
  • The ICES response to the special request states that if the 2019 TAC is revised, then the advice released in June 2019 would no longer be valid.
  • If the 2019 TAC is not revised, the June 2019 advice would still be valid, with catches in 2020 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 1020 and 2665 tonnes. According to the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding to FMSY (1731 tonnes).
  • If the 2019 TAC were to be revised to fishing at FMSY (1488 tonnes), ICES advises that when WWMAP is applied catches in 2020, corresponding to F ranges, are between 918 and 2,402 tonnes, with an FMSY point value of 1,559 tonnes.
  • If the 2019 TAC were to be revised to the 2019 TAC +20% (1009 tonnes), ICES advises that when WWMAP is applied catches in 2020, corresponding to F ranges are between 993 and 2,597 tonnes, with an FMSY point value of 1,686 tonnes.
  • This fishery was worth € 280,000 in 2018.
  • Discarding has increased from 5% (42 t) in 2017 to 14% (147 t) in 2018 for this stock.
  • Irish landings of Celtic Sea sole are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting Nephrops and are in mixed beam trawl fisheries off the south coast.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions VIIh-k. The assessment area also covers VIIh-k but there is insufficient data from VIIh to support an assessment and there are negligible landings from VIIk, therefore the assessment is carried out using data from VIIj only under the assumption that the trends are representative of VIIh-k. The 2015 TAC was 382 t with an associated Irish quota of 171 t (45%). Ireland was allocated the largest share of the TAC.
  • This stock is mainly caught within coastal mixed fisheries by otter trawlers in VIIj.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent landings have been below the TAC.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The TAC area covers Division 7.h-k. The assessment area also covers 7.h-k but there is insufficient data from 7.h to support an assessment and there are negligible landings from 7.k, therefore the assessment is carried out using data from 7.j only under the assumption that the trends are representative of 7.h-k.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent landings have been below the TAC.
Additional: • Irish landings of West of Ireland sole are mainly taken in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, megrim and gadoid species.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Division 7.h-k. The assessment area also covers 7.h-k but there is insufficient data from 7.h to support an assessment and there are negligible landings from 7.k. The assessment is carried out using data from 7.j and the advice is scaled up to take account of landings in 7.h.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent Irish landings have been below the quota.
  • Beam trawl and gill net fisheries in 7.f-7.k are subject to the landing obligation for sole in 2018 (see Appendix VI). The majority of the Irish catches are from otter trawls which are not yet subject to the landing obligation.
Additional: • Irish landings of Southwest of Ireland sole are mainly taken in mixed otter trawl fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, megrim and gadoid species.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Division 7.h-k. The assessment area also covers 7.h-k but there is insufficient data from 7.h to support an assessment and there are negligible landings from 7.k. The assessment is carried out using data from 7.j and the advice is scaled up to take account of landings in 7.h.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent Irish landings have been below the quota.
Additional:
• Irish landings of Southwest of Ireland sole are mainly taken in mixed otter trawl fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, megrim and gadoid species.
  • This fishery was worth € 45,000 in 2017.
  • Since 2002, Irish landings have been well below the Irish quota.
  • Discarding is considered to be negligible (5 t in 2017, less than 2%).

Management:
• The TAC area covers Division 7.h-k. The assessment area also covers 7.h-k but there is insufficient data from 7.h to support an assessment and there are negligible landings from 7.k. The assessment is carried out using data from 7.j and the advice is scaled up to take account of landings in 7.h.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent Irish landings have been below the quota.
Additional:
• Irish landings of Southwest of Ireland sole are mainly taken in mixed otter trawl fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, megrim and gadoid species.
  • Discarding is considered to be negligible (1 t in 2018, less than 0.5%).

Management:
• There are no TACs for sprat in Irish waters. TACs are in place in the English Channel and in the North Sea.
  • EC vessels are restricted in the gear they can use to target sprat. Mesh sizes of 16 mm and above are permitted when sprat is the target species. There are also restrictions on the by-catch of most pelagic and demersal species covered by the TAC and quota system. Further restrictions on mesh size of above 32 mm apply, if demersal TAC species are a by-catch in sprat fisheries.
  • Though Irish vessels are not subject to any quota for sprat, certain license provisions regulate access to coastal waters for certain sizes of vessel.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• There are no TACs for sprat in Irish waters. TACs are in place in the English Channel and in the North Sea.
  • EC vessels are restricted in the gear they can use to target sprat. Mesh sizes of 16 mm and above are permitted when sprat is the target species. There are also restrictions on the by-catch of most pelagic and demersal species covered by the TAC and quota system. Further restrictions on mesh size of above 32 mm apply, if demersal TAC species are a by-catch in sprat fisheries.
  • Though Irish vessels are not subject to any quota for sprat, certain license provisions regulate access to coastal waters for certain sizes of vessel.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

  • EC vessels are restricted in the gear they can use to target sprat. Mesh sizes of 16 mm and above are permitted when sprat is the target species. There are also restrictions on the by-catch of most pelagic and demersal species covered by the TAC and quota system. Further restrictions on mesh size of above 32 mm apply, if demersal TAC species are a by-catch in sprat fisheries.
  • Though Irish vessels are not subject to any quota for sprat, certain license provisions regulate access to coastal waters for certain sizes of vessel.

Management:
• There are no TACs for sprat in Irish waters. TACs are in place in the English Channel and in the North Sea.
  • EC vessels are restricted in the gear they can use to target sprat. Mesh sizes of 16 mm and above are permitted when sprat is the target species. There are also restrictions on the by-catch of most pelagic and demersal species covered by the TAC and quota system. Further restrictions on mesh size of above 32 mm apply, if demersal TAC species are a by-catch in sprat fisheries.
  • Though Irish vessels are not subject to any quota for sprat, certain license provisions regulate access to coastal waters for certain sizes of vessel.
  • Irish landings of sprat in this area were 4,250 t in 2017, down from 4,705 t in 2016 and 9,328 t in 2015.
Additional:
• There is no assessment or TAC for this stock.
  • ICES advice is given for two years.
  • The ICES framework for category 5 stocks was applied to sprat in sub-area 7.a-c and 7.f-k. The advice is based on the most recent catches (3,500 t). A precautionary buffer (0.8) is applied to give the catch advice (2,800 t).
  • Research has been conducted by the Marine Institute and Galway-Mayo Institute of Technology on the identification and description of sprat stocks within Irish waters, as well as development of tools which can be incorporated into an assessment of this fishery.
  • Sprat within Irish waters exhibit a truncated age structure (0-2 year olds as opposed to 0-5 in other European management units).
  • A validated ageing methodology for the sprat in Irish waters is now available, an essential tool to move forward to an analytical assessment of this fishery.
  • Sprat within division 6.a exhibited a faster growth rate than sprat within division 7.j and 7.g.
  • An otolith shape analysis was conducted to identify stocks in Irish waters but did not find any conclusive evidence of stock separation. However, it did identify a number of drivers in shape variation, including catch location, proximity to the shore, and sex.
  • Current research is focusing on identifying the drivers in the characteristic fluctuations in biomass of this fishery.
  • The Marine Institute have undertaken observer trips on the Irish sprat fishery since 2011, averaging 2 trips per year (2011-2016). The number of trips in 2017 increased significantly to 15, representing around 20% of vessels targeting sprat.

Management:
• There is no TAC for sprat in Irish waters. TACs are in place in the English Channel and in the North Sea.
  • EU vessels are restricted in the gear they can use to target sprat. Mesh sizes of 16 mm and above are permitted when sprat is the target species.
  • Though Irish vessels are not subject to any quota for sprat, vessels >36.58 m are excluded from the 12 nautical mile zone. Vessels >27.43 m and <36.58 m are excluded from the 3 nm zone.
  • From 1 January 2020, trawlers >18 m LOA will be excluded from the 6 nm zone. An exemption from this regulation will allow pelagic vessels >18 m to target sprat inside the 6 nm zone until 31 December 2021. For these vessels, catches will be limited to 2,000 t and 1,000 t in 2020 and 2021 respectively.
  • Irish landings of sprat in this area were 3,580 t in 2018, 4,250 t in 2017, 4,705 t in 2016 and 9,328 t in 2015.
Additional:
• No TAC is set for this stock. Although ICES provides a catch advice, there is no information on the fishing pressure or state of the stock.
  • The number vessels involved in sprat fishing ranged from 39 to 46 including 22 vessels <10 m over the years 2015-2017. About half of the total catch of sprat is taken in 6.a (Donegal Bay), a third in the Celtic Sea (Kerry bays) and 15% in the Irish Sea (off Dunmore East). The fishery is primarily in Q4 and to a lesser extent in Q1.
  • ICES advice was given in 2017 for two years (2,800 t). The advice was based on the advice given in 2015 (3,500 t) that was reduced by 20% (PA buffer). In 2019, the previous advice was rolled over for another two years without applying the buffer.
  • Recent research has focused on identifying and describing the stock(s) structure around Ireland.
  • The application of a validated aging methodology has revealed a fishery with a truncated age structure (0-2 year olds as opposed to 0-5 in other European management units).
  • Analysis of growth and otolith shape indicate a wide variation life history strategies within this fishery, i.e. Sprat within division 6.a exhibited a faster growth rate than sprat within division 7.j and 7.g.
  • The Marine Institute have undertaken observer trips on the Irish sprat fishery since 2011, averaging 2 trips per year (2011-2016). The number of trips in 2017 and 2018 increased to 15 and 13 respectively, representing on average 10% of vessel trips targeting sprat.
  • Over the years 2007-2018, 42 MI observer trips were carried out, there is no record of either marine mammal, seabird or sea turtle being killed by fishing activity targeting sprat.

Management:
• The TAC for 2015 is 13,700 t. The EC has a large share of this TAC (8,347 t), but this is mainly split between Spain and Portugal. An EC by-catch quota of 144.8 t that is otherwise unallocated is available to Ireland. By-catches by Ireland and other countries not having a quota must not exceed this level.
  • The TAC covers the entire North Atlantic Ocean.
  • There are two minimum size options that are applied to the entire Atlantic: 125 cm Lower Jaw-Fork Length (LJFL) or 25 kg weight, with a 15% tolerance, or 119 cm LJFL or 15 kg weight with zero tolerance and record keeping of discarding.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• Rec. 11-13, adopted by the Commission that indicates that For stocks that are not overfished and not subject to overfishing (i.e. stocks in the green quadrant of the Kobe plot), management measures shall be designed to result in a high probability of maintaining the stock within this quadrant.
  • There are two minimum size options that are applied to the entire Atlantic: 125 LJFL (lower jaw fork length) with a 15% tolerance, or 119 cm LJFL with zero tolerance and evaluation of the discards.
  • The status of the North Atlantic swordfish stock was assessed in September 2013, by means of applying statistical modelling to the available data up to 2011.
  • No quota uplift is applicable as bycatch is considered negligible.
Additional:
• Atlantic South and North delimited by 5° N.
  • Rec. 13-02 stipulates that a total allowable shall be 13,700 t for 2014, 2015 and 2016. For some CPCs, part of Swordfish taken in the South Atlantic can be count up against uncaught catch in the North. CPCs who have overall exceeded their individual adjusted catch limits shall pay back their overharvest.

Management:
• ICCAT recommendation 16-03
    • The Contracting Parties, and non-Contracting Parties, Entities or Fishing Entities (CPCs) shall ensure the conservation of North Atlantic swordfish with the goal of maintaining BMSY, with a greater than 50% probability.
    • Any unused portion or excess of the annual adjusted quota may be added to/shall be deducted from, according to the case, the quota 2 years later (i.e. in 2018 for catch in 2016). The maximum underage (deficiency in amount) that a Party may carryover in any given year shall not exceed 15% of its initial catch limit (excluding quota transfers) for those CPCs holding catch limits more than 500 t, and 50% for other CPCs.
    • The SCRS and the Commission shall begin a dialogue to allow for the development of harvest control rules (HCRs).
  • ICCAT recommendation 16-04
    • The European Union shall be allowed to count up to 200 t of its swordfish catch taken from the North Atlantic management area against its uncaught South Atlantic swordfish quota.
    • CPC may choose, as an alternative to the minimum size of 25 kg/125 cm lower jaw fork length (LJFL), to take the necessary measures to prohibit the taking by its vessels in the Atlantic Ocean, as well as the landing and sale in its jurisdiction, of swordfish (and swordfish parts), less than 119 cm LJFL, or in the alternative 15 kg, provided that, if this alternative is chosen, no tolerance of swordfish smaller than 119 LJFL, or in the alternative 15 kg, shall be allowed.
  • No quota uplift is applicable as bycatch is considered negligible.
Additional:
• The stock was assessed in 2017 by means of applying statistical modelling to the available data up to 2015.
  • Ireland has no target fisheries. Bycatches in any fishery are subject to an unallocated bycatch quota for EU vessels (130.74 t in 2017).
  • Atlantic South and North are delimited by the 5 ° N line.

Management:
• In 2005, the coastal states (EU, Norway, Iceland and Faroe Islands) agreed a sharing arrangement for the blue whiting stock with catches allocated as follows: EU 30.5%, Faroe Islands 26.125%, Norway 25.745% and Iceland 17.63%. Russia is accommodated by transfers from the Faroe Islands and additional catches in the NEAFC regulatory area.
  • The above sharing arrangements have not been followed by all parties.
  • Ireland has a share of the EU quota, in Sub-areas I-VII, VIIIa, VIIIb, VIIId, VIIIe, XII and XIV. In 2015 this EU share was 197,195 t and the Irish quota was 23,313 t.
  • Separate EU quotas exist for VIIIc, IX and X, and for Norwegian and Faroese waters. There are no Irish quotas in these areas.
  • The EU TAC may be adjusted subject to transfers in the EU Norway agreement.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• In 2005, the coastal states (EU, Norway, Iceland and Faroe Islands) agreed a sharing arrangement for the blue whiting stock with catches allocated as follows: EU 30.5%, Faroe Islands 26.125%, Norway 25.745% and Iceland 17.63%. Russia is accommodated by transfers from the Faroe Islands and additional catches in the NEAFC regulatory area.
  • The above sharing arrangements have not been followed by all parties.
  • Ireland has a share of the EU quota, in sub-areas 1-7, Divisions 8.a, 8.b, 8.d, 8.e and subareas12 and 14.
  • Separate EU quotas exist for 8.c, 9 and 10, and for Norwegian and Faroese waters. There are no Irish quotas in these areas.
  • The EU TAC may be adjusted subject to transfers in the EU Norway agreement.
  • In 2016 the EU TAC was 207,657 t.
  • Currently there is no agreement between the Coastal States EU, Norway, Iceland and the Faroe Islands on the share of the blue whiting stock. Consequently, the previous management plan is no longer in force.
  • NEAFC has asked ICES on behalf of the Coastal States to evaluate a long-term management strategy (LTMS) for blue whiting. In 2016 ICES evaluated this strategy and advise that the harvest control rule (HCR) proposed for blue whiting, is precautionary given the ICES estimates of BLIM (1.5 million tonnes), Bpa (2.25 million tonnes), and FMSY (0.32).
Additional: • An inter-benchmark assessment was conducted in 2016. This was to deal with how to incorporate the latest acoustic survey into the assessment.

Management:
• A long-term management strategy was agreed by the European Union, the Faroe Islands, Iceland and Norway in 2016. ICES has evaluated the strategy and found it to be precautionary.
  • The new HCR leads to slightly lower SSB on average in the long term, however the probability of the stock falling below Blim remains less than 5%.
  • In recent years, there have been difficulties in reaching a sharing agreement for the blue whiting stock.
  • In 2017, the catch is estimated at 1,559,400t (based on declared quotas and expected uptake).
  • Ireland has a share of the EU quota, in Sub-areas 1-7, Divisions 8.a, 8.b, 8.d, 8.e and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • Separate EU quotas exist for 8.c, 9 and 10. There are no Irish quotas in these areas.
  • The EU TAC may be adjusted subject to transfers in the EU Norway agreement.
  • Within a total access quantity of 21,500t for the EU, up to 9.2% of Ireland's quotas may be fished in Faroese waters.
  • Currently the landing obligation only applies to pelagic gears (pelagic otter trawls, pair trawls).
Additional: • The assessment estimates a low 2016 year class, which is confirmed by a series of surveys not used in the assessment model. This is likely to result in a decrease in stock size, and a reduction in fishing opportunities when the 2016 year class is fully selected in the fishery from 2019.

Management:
• A long-term management strategy was agreed by the European Union, the Faroe Islands, Iceland and Norway in 2016. ICES has evaluated the strategy and found it to be precautionary.
  • In recent years, there have been difficulties in reaching a sharing agreement for the blue whiting stock and total catches have exceeded advice.
  • In 2018, the catch is estimated at 1,712,874 t (based on declared quotas and expected uptake), substantially in excess of the catch advice of 1,387,872 t.
  • Ireland has a share of the EU quota, in Sub-areas 1-7, Divisions 8.a, 8.b, 8.d, 8.e and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • Separate EU quotas exist for 8.c, 9 and 10. There are no Irish quotas in these areas.
  • The EU TAC may be adjusted subject to transfers in the EU Norway agreement.
  • Within a total access quantity of 21,500 t for the EU, up to 9.2% of Ireland's quotas may be fished in Faroese waters.
Additional:
• The strong 2015 year class is now fully recruited to the fishery.
  • While the stock remains well above MSY Btrigger, recent catches have exceeded advice and recruitment in 2017 and 2018 are estimated to be low. This will likely lead to reduced fishing opportunities in 2020.
  • The SSB trajectory has been revised downward in the past 3 assessments. This indicates a bias in the current year's estimate.

Management:
• A long-term management strategy was agreed by the European Union, the Faroe Islands, Iceland and Norway in 2016. ICES has evaluated the strategy and found it to be precautionary.
  • Since 2014, there have been difficulties in reaching a sharing agreement for the blue whiting stock and total catches have exceeded advice.
  • In 2019, the catch is estimated at 1,444,301 t (based on declared quotas and expected uptake), substantially in excess of the catch advice of 1,143,629 t.
  • Ireland has a share of the EU quota, in Sub-areas 1-7, Divisions 8.a, 8.b, 8.d, 8.e and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • A separate EU quota exists for 8.c, 9 and 10. There is no Irish quota in these areas.
  • The EU TAC may be adjusted subject to transfers in the EU- Norway agreement.
  • The EU are allowed to catch up to 22,500 t in Faroese waters and up to 7% of Ireland's quota may be fished in that area.
Additional:
• The strong 2014 year-class is now fully recruited to the fishery.
  • While the stock remains well above MSY Btrigger, recent catches have exceeded advice and recruitment since 2016 is estimated to be low. This will likely lead to reduced fishing opportunities in 2021.
  • Despite recent poor recruitment, the latest assessment has revised up SSB in recent years. This is mainly due to the high survey index for the large 2014 year-class. This revision leads to similar catch advice for 2020 as 2019.

Management:
• The TAC area covers EC waters in Division Vb and Sub-areas VI, XII and XIV.
  • The assessment area covers Division VIa only but landings from other areas have been negligible in recent years.
  • The TAC in 2015 was 263 t with an associated Irish quota of 79 t.
  • There are no explicit management objectives or management plans for this stock.
  • Whiting is taken with cod and haddock in mixed demersal fisheries and management advice should be considered in that context.
  • There are strong indications that management control is not effective in limiting the catch. The whiting catches in 2014 were nearly four times the TAC and over 80% of the catch is discarded.
  • Effort reductions as part of the Cod Long Term Management Plan (EC Reg.1342/2008) have reduced catch and discarding of whiting in this area.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The assessment area is 6.a while the TAC management area includes ICES subareas 6, 12 and 14; and International waters of 5.b.
  • The 2016 TAC was 213 t with an associated Irish quota of 64 t.
  • Despite effort reductions as part of the Cod Long Term Management Plan (EC Reg.1342/2008) discarding of whiting in this area remains high.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock, cod and megrim.
  • The increase in mesh size from 100 mm to 120 mm, under the emergency measures since 2010 and the introduction of large square mesh panels in the Nephrops fishery, are likely to have contributed to the observed reductions in fishing mortality.
  • Given the continued high discards and low TAC this stock could become a major 'choke species' for the 6.a Nephrops fishery in the context of the landing obligation.

Management:
• The assessment area is 6.a while the TAC management area includes ICES subarea 6 and union and international waters of 5.b, 12 and 14.
  • The 2017 TAC is 213t with an associated Irish quota of 64t exclusively for bycatches.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock, cod and megrim.
  • The increase in mesh size from 100 mm to 120 mm, under the emergency measures since 2010 and the introduction of large square mesh panels in the Nephrops fishery, are likely to have contributed to the observed reductions in fishing mortality.
  • Given the continued high discards and low TAC this stock could become a major 'choke species' for the 6.a Nephrops fishery in the context of the landing obligation.

Management:
• The assessment area is 6.a while the TAC management area covers ICES subarea 6 and union and international waters of 5.b, 12 and 14.
  • The 2018 TAC is 213 t with an associated Irish quota of 64 t, exclusively for bycatches.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock and megrim.
  • The increase in mesh size from 100 mm to 120 mm, under the emergency measures since 2010 and the introduction of large square mesh panels in the Nephrops fishery, are likely to have contributed to the observed reductions in fishing mortality. There has been a gradual increase in SSB in recent years but the stock is still below Blim.
  • Discard rates are very high (1,209 t, about 87% in 2017). Given the continued high discards and low TAC this stock could become a major 'choke species' for bottom trawl fisheries on the shelf in 6.a given the obligation to land all catches of whiting in 2019.

Management:
• The assessment area is 6.a while the TAC management area covers ICES sub-area 6 and union and international waters of 5.b, 12 and 14.
  • The 2019 TAC was set at 1,112 t with an associated Irish quota of 324 t, exclusively for bycatches.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock and megrim.
  • The increase in mesh size from 100 mm to 120 mm, under the emergency measures since 2010 and the introduction of large square mesh panels in the Nephrops fishery, are likely to have contributed to the observed reductions in fishing mortality. There has been a gradual increase in SSB in recent years but the stock is still below Blim.
  • Discards in 2018 (ages 1+) were 41% lower than those in 2017 and also below the average for the last decade. In terms of discard rate (discards as a proportion of catch), they were the tenth highest in the time-series.

Management:
• The TAC is for the combined Divisions VIa and VIb; therefore, the TAC cannot be effective in limiting catches in Division VIb (Rockall).
  • The Division VI TAC in 2015 is 263 t, with an associated Irish quota of 79 t.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• ICES provides biennial advice for this stock.
  • A TAC allocation for Division 6.b (Rockall) whiting comes under the TAC set for ICES Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 and EU and international waters of 5.b. Therefore the TAC cannot effectively manage catches in 6.b (Rockall) specifically.
  • The sub-area 6 TAC in 2016 is 213 t, with an associated Irish quota of 64 t.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock, cod and megrim.
  • Rockall whiting is managed under a TAC for the combined area 6.a and 6.b which therefore cannot be effective in limiting catches in 6.b (Rockall).

Management:
• ICES provides biennial advice for this stock.
  • A TAC allocation for Division 6.b (Rockall) whiting comes under the TAC set for ICES Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 and EU and international waters of 5.b. Therefore the TAC cannot effectively manage catches in 6.b (Rockall) specifically.
  • The Sub-area 6 TAC in 2017 is 213t, with an associated Irish quota of 64t exclusively for bycatches.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock, cod and megrim.
  • Rockall whiting is managed under a TAC for the combined area 6.a and 6.b which therefore cannot be effective in limiting catches in 6.b (Rockall).
  • The stock structure of whiting at Rockall is not known, but it is probable that fish caught at Rockall are not a separate stock.

Management:
• ICES provides triannual advice for this stock.
  • The TAC covers ICES Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 and EU and international waters of 5.b. Therefore the TAC cannot effectively manage catches in 6.b (Rockall) specifically.
  • TAC is exclusively for bycatches No targeted fisheries are permitted.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock.
  • The stock structure of whiting at Rockall is not known, but it is possible that this is not a separate stock.

Management:
• ICES provides triannual advice for this stock.
  • The TAC covers ICES Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 and EU and international waters of Division 5.b. Therefore the TAC cannot effectively manage catches in Division 6.b (Rockall) specifically.
  • TAC is exclusively for bycatches, no targeted fisheries are permitted.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock.
  • The stock structure of whiting at Rockall is not known, but it is possible that this is not a separate stock.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Division VIIa and this corresponds with the assessment area.
  • The TAC for Division VIIa in 2015 was 80 t with an associated Irish quota of 46 t.
  • The spring closure of the western Irish Sea to whitefish fishing, designed to protect cod, has been continued, but is unlikely to have affected whiting catches, which are mainly by-catch in the derogated Nephrops fishery.
  • The operation of days-at-sea effort limitations in the Irish Sea since 2004 is not expected to have resulted in a significant reduction in fishing mortality for whiting.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.a.
  • The 2016 TAC was 80 t with an associated Irish quota of 46 t.
  • FMSY proxy 22 cm (expected mean length of catch above Lc when F = M).
  • Effort reductions as part of the Cod Long Term Management Plan (EC Reg.1342/2008) are in place, but not predicted to be beneficial to 7.a whiting.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting in the Irish Sea are mainly taken in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock. However, 20% of the landings come from trips where whiting was the dominant species mainly in the south of 7.a.
  • This stock is due to be benchmarked in 2017.
  • Given the continued high discards and low total allowable catch (TAC) this stock could become a major 'choke species' for the 7.a Nephrops fishery in the context of the landing obligation.
  • WKPROXY 2015 concluded that the overall perception was Irish Sea whiting is exploited above the length based indicator reference point proxies (see FMSY proxy above).
  • Recruitment in 2014 is one of the highest in the time series, but SSB has been at a low level since 2003.
  • Landings have been adjusted since 2003 to exclude landings taken from the southern rectangles (33E2 and 33E3) in the Irish Sea as they are not believed to be part of this stock. This needs to be considered when setting catch options for Divisions 7.a and 7.b-k whiting.

Management:
• The stock area does not include Irish landings taken or reported in 33E2 and 33E3, these accounted for 82% of the 7.a Irish landings in 2016. The TAC management area covers all of ICES Division 7.a.
  • The 2017 TAC was 80 t with an associated Irish quota of 46 t.
Additional:
• The majority of whiting caught are discards in the Nephrops fishery and are below the minimum landings size. Despite the introduction of several technical measures to reduce fin fish catch and discards in the Nephrops fishery, the total discards estimates remain high. Given the continued high discards and low TAC this stock could become a major 'choke species' for the Division 7.a Nephrops fishery in the context of the landing obligation.
  • This stock was benchmarked in 2017 and the assessment was upgraded to category 1. The stock status is confirmed by the new assessment and management advice from this assessment remains the same.
  • Landings have been adjusted to exclude landings taken from the southern rectangles (33E2 and 33E3) in the Irish Sea as they are not believed to be part of this stock. This needs to be considered when setting catch options for Divisions 7.a and 7.b-k whiting.

Management:
• The stock area does not include landings taken or reported in 33E2 and 33E3, these accounted for 40% of the 7.a landings in 2017. The TAC management area covers all of ICES Division 7.a.
  • The 2018 TAC was 80 t with an associated Irish quota of 46 t.
Additional:
• This stock was benchmarked in 2017 and the assessment was upgraded to category 1 (Quantitative Assessment). The stock is still well below Blim and shows no signs of recovery.
  • The majority of whiting caught are discards in the Nephrops fishery and are below MCRS. Despite the introduction of several technical measures to reduce finfish catch and discards in the Nephrops fishery, the total discards estimates remain high. In 2017 95% of the total catch of 703 t was discarded (667 t). Given the continued high discards and low TAC this stock could become a major 'choke species' for the 7.a Nephrops fishery given the obligation to land whiting catches in 2019.

Management:
• The stock area does not include landings taken or reported in 33E2 and 33E3, these ICES rectangles accounted for an average of 54% of the ICES Division 7.a landings over the last five years. The TAC management area covers all of Division 7.a.
  • The 2019 TAC was changed from 727 t to 1,246 t following an updated scientific assessment and revised figures from ICES on the bycatch of whiting
Additional:
• This stock was benchmarked in 2017 and the assessment was upgraded to category 1 (Quantitative Assessment). The stock is still well below Blim and shows no signs of recovery.
  • The majority of whiting caught are discards in the Nephrops fishery and are below MCRS. Despite the introduction of several technical measures to reduce finfish catch and discards in the Nephrops fishery, the total discards estimates remain high. In 2018, 95% of the total catch of 899 t was discarded (853 t).
  • Whiting is a key management consideration and potential choke species for Nephrops fisheries in the Irish Sea.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Divisions VIIb-k, and the assessment area covers Divisions VIIb,c,e-k. VIId is assessed as part of the North Sea stock.
  • The 2015 TAC was set at 17,742 t with an associated Irish quota of 5,029 t.
  • There is a management plan in development by the NWWRAC for mixed demersal fisheries catching whiting in VIIfg. FEAS supports the development of this plan.
  • Technical measures have been implemented by vessels in the Celtic Sea to reduce discards of whiting. These are expected to improve fishery selection and reduce discarding.
Additional: • There is no additional information for this stock

Management:
• ICES division 7.d is not included in the assessment area for the whiting 7.b-k stock. The ICES advice for 7.d is for total catches of less the 5,446 t.
  • Vessels actively targeting whiting have been subject to the landings obligation since 2016. Other fleets, in which whiting is a bycatch species, are not currently under the landings obligation (EC, 2015/812).
  • An uplift will need to be applied to the ICES landings advice in 2017 to cover vessels subject to the Landings Obligation.
Additional:
• Irish landings of Celtic Sea whiting are largely taken in a targeted fishery; two-thirds of the landings are from trips where whiting was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are landed with haddock, megrim, anglerfish as well as other gadoid species.
  • Whiting is fished at or below FMSY in 2017 under all mixed-fisheries scenarios except the maximum scenario, reflecting that it is the least limiting stock for most fleets.
  • Catches reported or taken in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3 are reallocated from Division 7.a to this stock. The implications for this stock are minor due to the relative low catches which are in the order of 30-50 t annually.
  • Recruitment in 2013 was one of the highest in the time series and resulted in increased in SSB with this year class making up the bulk of the catches in 2015.

Management:
• ICES division 7.d is not included in the assessment area for the whiting 7.b-k stock. The ICES advice for 7.d is for wanted catch catches (landings) of less than 2,688t.
  • Gadoid fisheries in 7.b,c,e-k and 7.d are subject to the landing obligation for haddock in 2018 (see Appendix VI).
  • There were significant reported landings of whiting from midwater gear targeting herring during 2016 as a consequence of the landing obligation.
Additional:
• Irish landings of Celtic Sea whiting are largely taken in a targeted fishery; two-thirds of the landings are from trips where whiting was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are landed with haddock, megrim, anglerfish as well as other gadoid species.
