  • Whiting is fished at or below FMSY in 2017 under all mixed-fisheries scenarios except the maximum scenario, reflecting that it is the least limiting stock for most fleets.
  • Catches from ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3 are reallocated from Division 7.a to this stock. The implications for this stock are minor due to the relative low catches which are in the order of 30-50 t annually.

Management:
• ICES division 7.d is not included in the assessment area for the whiting 7.b-k stock.
  • Whiting in 7.d are subject to EU regulation 2018/973 which introduced a multi-annual plan for several demersal stocks.
Additional:
• Ireland is the only country with a directed whiting fishery in the Celtic sea. The majority of the landings are from trips where whiting was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are landed with haddock, hake, megrim, anglerfish and Nephrops.
  • Whiting is the least limiting stock for most fleets in the ICES mixed fishery assessment. Celtic Sea cod is likely to become the most limiting (i.e. choke) stock for all demersal fleets in 2019.
  • The stock increased substantially after strong recruitment in 2009 and 2013 and has been declining in recent years, resulting in a decrease in the advised catches.
  • Discards continue to be high: 28% of the catch in 2017 (4,505 t). The majority of discards occur above the minimum landing size. Irish discard rates are usually quite high, but in 2017 the discard rate was estimated to be less than 10%.
  • The proposed 6% de minimis exemption would apply to bottom trawls and seines using a mesh size of ≥ 80 mm, and pelagic and beam trawls using mesh = 80-119 mm fishing in ICES divisions 7b-c and 7e-k.
  • The stock will be benchmarked by ICES in 2020.

Management:
• The stock area consists of Divisions 7.b,c,e-k and two ICES rectangles in the south of Division 7.a (33E2 and 33E3) which are reallocated to Division 7.g. This differs to the TAC area, 7.b-k, 8, 9 and 10.
  • ICES division 7.d is not included in the assessment area for the whiting 7.b-k stock.
  • Whiting in 7.d are subject to NSMAP (EU regulation 2018/973)
Additional:
• Ireland is the only country with a directed whiting fishery in the Celtic sea. The majority of the landings are from trips where whiting was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are landed with haddock, hake, megrim, anglerfish and Nephrops.
  • The perception of the stock has changed considerably since last year (recruitment since 2015 is now considerably lower than previously estimated and SSB in 2018 and 2017 is consequentially also lower). This change in perception was caused by the low abundance of age 1-3 year old fish in the 2018 Irish and French surveys as well as the French otter trawl fleet. Last year's assessment estimated these cohorts to be of average abundance but the 2018 data suggests they were actually well below average.
  • Given the increase in the haddock advice, the whiting catch advice will likely impact mixed fisheries management significantly in the Celtic sea.
  • Discards have declined in recent years from 28% of the catch in 2017 (4,505 t) to 15% (1,495 t) in 2018. The majority of discards occur above the minimum landing size.
  • The stock is scheduled to be benchmarked by ICES in 2020.

Management:
• Two species of Lophius occur in this area. Black anglerfish (Lophius budegassa) usually make up around 10% of the international landings but in some years this may be as much as 30%. The two species are assessed and managed as a single stock.
  • There are three TAC areas that cover the stock:
    • Union waters of areas 2.a and 4
    • Norwegian waters of area 4
    • Union and international waters of areas 6, 5.b, 12, 14.
  • Ireland only has a quota for 6, 5.b, 12, 14 and generally takes its full quota. France has the largest quota but take less than a third of this. The UK (Scotland) have full quota uptake and they are responsible for the vast majority of the international landings.
  • There is a special condition on the Sub-area 4 TAC which states that up to 10 % may be fished in Sub-area 6. There is currently no other flexibility between TAC areas.
Additional:
• The advice is based on a survey index but the survey did not take place this year due to COVID 19 concerns.
  • The advice is normally based on the ratio of the index in the last 2 years (2019-20) over that in the 3 previous years (2016-18). This year the index ratio is calculated as the 2019 value divided by the mean index value of 2016-18, resulting in a reduction in the advice compared to last year. The precautionary buffer was applied last year and is not applied again this year. Other demersal surveys in the area that did go ahead, all show a decrease in biomass.
  • Irish vessels mainly catch anglerfish in mixed fisheries with various gadoids and megrim near the Stanton Bank; with hake and other gadoids along the continental slope; and with megrim to the south of Rockall. The landings from Rockall (6.b) have increased faster than the landings from 6.a now account for around 30% of the Irish landings of this stock.
  • Discard levels in this stock are estimated to be low (2% in 2019).

Management:
• The TAC applies to both species of anglerfish because they are often not separated in the landings. This could lead to over-exploitation of one species and under-exploitation of the other. However, the relative abundance of the two species does not appear to have changed much over time, suggesting that the two species are subject to similar stock dynamics and fishing mortality.
  • There are two TAC areas that cover this stock: area 7 and area 8abde. Up to 10% of the Sub-area 7 TAC may be fished in Divisions 8.a-b,d-e, but there currently is no flexibility from 8abde to 7
Additional:
• The advice for the combined species in the total stock area is 50,130 t. This implies an Irish quota of 3,027 t in Sub-area 7 in 2021, assuming the same allocation between the TAC areas as last year.
  • The advice for black anglerfish is based on an IBTS survey index. This survey indicates that the stock is increasing and catch data indicate that the fishing pressure is below FMSY. Therefore, the advice is for an increase in catches compared to the advice for the previous year.
  • The assessment for white anglerfish indicates that the stock is increasing and fished below FMSY. The advice is for an increase in catches compared to the advice for the previous year.
  • In recent years the TAC has been set slightly below the advised catches for the two species combined.
  • France, which has most of the TAC, only lands around 75% of its allocated quota; most other countries depend on quota swaps to land their catches.
  • Much of the Irish anglerfish landings come from highly mixed fisheries. They are caught together with megrim, Nephrops, haddock, hake and other species. In some areas anglerfish are specifically targeted, mainly along the edge of the continental shelf.

Management:
• The TAC applies to both species of anglerfish because they are often not separated in the landings. This could lead to over-exploitation of one species and under-exploitation of the other. However, the relative abundance of the two species does not appear to have changed much over time, suggesting that the two species are subject to similar stock dynamics and fishing mortality.
  • There are two TAC areas that cover this stock: area 7 and area 8abde. Up to 10% of the Sub-area 7 TAC may be fished in Divisions 8.a-b,d-e, but there currently is no flexibility from 8abde to 7
Additional:
• The advice for the combined species in the total stock area is 50,130 t. This implies an Irish quota of 3,027 t in Sub-area 7 in 2021, assuming the same allocation between the TAC areas as last year.
  • The advice for black anglerfish is based on an IBTS survey index. This survey indicates that the stock is increasing and catch data indicate that the fishing pressure is below FMSY. Therefore, the advice is for an increase in catches compared to the advice for the previous year.
  • The assessment for white anglerfish indicates that the stock is increasing and fished below FMSY. The advice is for an increase in catches compared to the advice for the previous year.
  • In recent years the TAC has been set slightly below the advised catches for the two species combined.
  • France, which has most of the TAC, only lands around 75% of its allocated quota; most other countries depend on quota swaps to land their catches.
  • Much of the Irish anglerfish landings come from highly mixed fisheries. They are caught together with megrim, Nephrops, haddock, hake and other species. In some areas anglerfish are specifically targeted, mainly along the edge of the continental shelf.

Management:
• The stock assessment and management units are ICES Sub-areas 6, 7 and 8.
  • A long term management plan was proposed by the Pelagic Advisory Council in 2015 and evaluated by ICES as precautionary. The plan follows the rationale for the TAC setting within the ICES advice framework, but with some additional caution at low stock size.
  • The plan includes a closed season inside the Irish 12-mile limit, south of 52° 30 from 12th February - 31st October to prevent catches of Celtic Sea herring.
Additional:
• The full TAC has not been taken since 2012. In 2019 Ireland caught 9,910 t, below its quota of 13,235 t.
  • Approximately 10% of the international catch is discarded, most of this is from demersal gears.
  • Since 2015, Denmark and UK have only caught a minor proportion of their quota.

Management:
• The assessment area covers 7.e-k, with inclusion of catch from the south Irish Sea (7.a; ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3). This does not correspond to the TAC management area of 7.b-c, 7.e-k, 8, 9 and 10; Union waters of CECAF 34.1.1.
  • Irish landings in 33E2 and 33E3 account for notable proportions of Irish landings from the Irish Sea quota (37 t, 7% in 2019).
  • Since 2005, ICES rectangles 30E4, 31E4, and 32E3 have been closed during the first quarter as part of the Celtic Sea Conservation area (Appendix VI).
  • The proportional quota split in 2020 changed in favour of Ireland, relative to 2019 increasing from 40% to 57% of total TAC. This was due to the application of the Hague preferences.
Additional:
• The forecast for Celtic Sea cod is highly sensitive to assumptions around recruitment in 2020 and 2021 and catches in the interim year (2020). ICES have given zero catch advice based on precautionary considerations since there is a greater than 5% probability the SSB in 2022 will be below Blim with catches corresponding to the usual advice rule (i.e. catches of 544 t in 2021).
  • The stock was benchmarked in 2020 (ICES, 2020a). The model was changed to a stochastic state-space assessment model (SAM). Input data were revised. The new assessment model reduced the bias issues observed in the previous assessment model.
  • Most Irish catch is taken as a minor bycatch throughout the Celtic Sea. This makes it difficult to control the fishing mortality on the stock.
  • There is a small targeted gillnet fishery for cod off the south-east coast, this has been in decline over recent years.
  • As cod is widely caught as part of mixed fisheries, it is likely to be the primary 'choke' species and be the limiting stock for all Celtic Sea fleets in 2021 under the Landings Obligation.

Management:
• A revised management plan has been in place since 2016, for which ICES evaluated the harvest control rule in 2016 and concluded that it is precautionary.
  • Ireland has a share of the EU quota but does not actively take part in the fishery. Occasional minor catches are a result of bycatch from pelagic fisheries.
  • Bycatch of coastal cod and golden redfish, both of which are unsustainably fished, is a concern in fisheries targeting Arctic cod.
Additional:
• Stock size is considered to be well above the long term average, although continues to decrease from a peak in 2013.
  • Fishing pressure had been increasing since the mid-2000s, however it declined slightly in 2019 and is now just below FMSY. There has been no strong recruitment since the 2007 and 2008 year classes.
  • Under the management plan, the TAC is calculated as the average catch predicted for the coming 3 years using a defined target level of exploitation, set according to rules around the spawning-stock biomass (SSB) in the first year of the forecast.

Management:
• Quota is exclusively for bycatch in fisheries for other species.
  • Division 6.a cod falls under a quota exchange mechanism related to the Landing Obligation, through which up to 6% of national quota is made available to other Member States who lack quota.
  • The TAC Area covers Division 6.a, EU and international waters of 5.b east of 12° W. The assessment covers Division 6.a only and landings in the past have been adjusted to include substantial area misreporting estimates for landings reported in 4 but thought to be taken in 6.a.
Additional:
• The 2020 ICES advice for this stock is biennial and is relevant for 2021 and 2022.
  • The stock collapsed in the early 1980s, with SSB dropping from 40,000 t to below 3,100 t in 2006, with no indications of recovery despite significant management measures.
  • There is no targeted fishery for cod in Division 6a. Landings are from bycatch in the mixed bottom trawl fishery targeting haddock, hake, anglerfish and megrim. ICES has provided a technical service for cod in Division 6.a which states that catches in 2021 are estimated to be between 1,625 tonnes and1,914 tonnes, based on the fishing mortality reductions advised for saithe and based on the current fishing mortality. Under these scenarios, spawning-stock biomass (SSB) in 2022 is expected to increase by 17-30%.
  • The stock assessment was benchmarked in 2020. This resulted in a change of the assessment method, the inclusion of revised catch (mostly discards) data from 2003 onwards, and updated biological parameters. The impact of this was to upscale SSB, F and recruitment but the overall stock status and perception of the stock has not changed. Although a significant proportion (> 40%) of total landings of 6.a cod are misreported to 4, there is uncertainty around the true proportion. There is increasing evidence that cod in the north of 6.a are in fact part of the North Sea population.

Management: • The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6.b, EU and international waters of 5.b west of 12°00' W and to 12 and 14. The TAC applies to EU vessels only and not the international fishery at Rockall.
Additional:
• The ICES advice issued in 2020 is relevant for 2021, 2022 and 2023.
  • Total landings for 2019 (the most recent available data point) were estimated to be 66 t the majority is taken by Scottish vessels
  • Irish landings of Rockall cod are taken as a minor bycatch in the fishery targeting haddock; they are also landed with megrim, saithe and anglerfish.
  • Irish LPUE showed large reductions from the 1990s to historic lows in recent years (Figure 1). Scottish LPUE and survey data shows some increase in abundance in the last 3-4 years but the stock is likely to be significantly lower than was observed in the 1990s.

Management:
• The TAC Area covers Division 7.a, which corresponds to the assessment area, however Irish landings taken or reported from 33E2 and 33E3 (off Waterford & Wexford), are transferred into the Celtic Sea assessment (Division 7.e-k). These accounted for 37 t, 11% of Irish landings reported in this TAC area in 2019. The TAC is exclusively for by-catches. No directed fisheries are permitted under this quota.
  • This stock is considered to be a target stock in the Western Waters MAP regulation ((EU) 2019/472) but given the state of the stock no directed fisheries are permitted.
  • All Irish TR2 vessels targeting Nephrops in 7.a must use highly selective gears i.e. SELTRA trawl, large mesh (300mm) square mesh panels or sorting grid as a condition of national license obligations.
Additional:
• Previous assessments showed signs of stock recovery around 2016, and the TAC was increased in 2018. However, this perceived recovery did not persist as the expected proportions of older fish were not observed in the survey or catches over time.
  • The update assessment this year show that SSB in 2020 remains at a low level.
  • In the past cod were mainly taken as a bycatch in the Nephrops fisheries. In recent years, the majority of landings are from vessels targeting demersal fish.
  • An EU funded tagging study which concluded in 2019, has indicated outward migration of cod into the Celtic Sea. This needs to be further investigated to determine stock assessment implications.
  • Preliminary landings figures for 2020 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the quota.

Management:
• A long-term management strategy was agreed by the European Union, the Faroe Islands, Iceland and Norway in 2016. ICES has evaluated the strategy and found it to be precautionary.
  • Since 2014, there have been difficulties in reaching a sharing agreement for the blue whiting stock and total catches have exceeded advice.
  • In 2020, the catch is estimated at 1,478,358 t (based on declared quotas and expected uptake), substantially in excess of the catch advice of 1,161,615 t.
  • Ireland has a share of the EU quota, in Sub-areas 1-7, Divisions 8.a, 8.b, 8.d, 8.e and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • A separate EU quota exists for 8.c, 9 and 10. There is no Irish quota in these areas.
  • The EU TAC may be adjusted subject to transfers in the EU- Norway agreement.
  • The EU are allowed to catch up to 37,500 t in Faroese waters and up to 7% of Ireland's quota may be fished in that area.
Additional:
• While the stock remains above MSY Btrigger, recent catches have exceeded advice and recruitment since 2016 is estimated to be low. This will likely lead to further reductions in fishing opportunities in 2022.
  • The assessment terminal year estimates are more uncertain this year, due to the cancellation of the acoustic survey as a result of the COVID disruption.
  • The 2021 advice is based on the agreed long-term management strategy which contains a provision to cap reductions in TAC at 20%.
  • The long-term management strategy was evaluated in 2016 and did not take into account consistent deviations from the plan catch advice. Therefore, the current implementation of the long-term management strategy may no longer be precautionary.

Management:
• The stock area consists of Divisions 7.b,c,e-k and two ICES rectangles in the south of Division 7.a (33E2 and 33E3) which are reallocated to Division 7.g. This differs to the TAC area, 7.b-k, 8, 9 and 10.
  • ICES division 7.d is not included in the assessment area for the whiting 7.b-k stock.
  • Whiting in 7.d are subject to NSMAP (EU regulation 2018/973)
Additional:
• The stock assessment was benchmarked in 2020 (ICES, 2020a). The model has been changed to a stochastic state-space assessment model (SAM). Maturity and natural mortality information were updated, catch (landings and discards) time series were reviewed and updated from 2003 to 2018, and survey indices updated to a single-modelled time-series, using the vector-autoregressive spatio-temporal model (VAST).
  • Ireland is the only country with a directed whiting fishery in the Celtic sea. The majority of the landings are from trips where whiting was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are landed with haddock, hake, megrim, anglerfish and Nephrops.
  • Mixed-fisheries advice will be provided in the Celtic Seas fisheries overview later in the year.
  • Discards have declined in recent years from 28% of the catch in 2017 (4,505 t) to 15% (1,495 t) in 2018 and 12% (752 t) in 2019. The majority of discards occur above the minimum landing size.

Management:
• The assessment area is 6.a while the TAC management area covers ICES sub-area 6 and union and international waters of 5.b, 12 and 14.
  • The 2020 TAC was set at 937 t with an associated Irish quota of 273 t, exclusively for bycatches.
Additional:
• The assessment was benchmarked in 2020, resulting in the rejection of the previous assessment. There is no new assessment but information on the relative size of the stock suggests that stock biomass is very low.
  • Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock and megrim.
  • Lack of assessment means it was not possible to forecast catches for 2021 or stock development. Catches in 2019 were estimated at 1,444 tonnes.
  • Catches of whiting are mainly discarded with recent discard rates of 78% by weight

Management:
• ICES provides triannual advice for this stock (2019-21).
  • TAC covers ICES Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 and EU and international waters of Division 5.b. Therefore the TAC cannot effectively manage catches in Division 6.b (Rockall) specifically.
  • TAC is exclusively for bycatches, no targeted fisheries are permitted.
Additional:
• Irish landings of whiting to the west of Scotland are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with haddock.
  • The stock structure of whiting at Rockall is not known, but it is possible that this is not a separate stock.

Management: • The stock area does not include landings taken or reported in 33E2 and 33E3, these ICES rectangles accounted for an average of 54% of the ICES Division 7.a landings over the last five years. The TAC management area covers all of Division 7.a.
Additional:
• This stock was benchmarked in 2017 and the assessment was upgraded to category 1 (Quantitative Assessment). The stock is still well below Blim and shows no signs of recovery.
  • The majority of whiting caught are discards in the Nephrops fishery and are below MCRS. Despite the introduction of several technical measures to reduce finfish catch and discards in the Nephrops fishery, the total discards estimates remain high. In 2018, 95% of the total catch of 899 t was discarded (853 t).
  • Forecasted bycatch levels for 2021 are 930 tonnes, using a model of whiting bycatch in the Nephrops fishery and assuming 7,300 tonnes of Nephrops catches in 2021. This is expected to result in a 7% increase in whiting SSB in 2022.
  • Whiting is a key management consideration and potential choke species for Nephrops fisheries in the Irish Sea.

Management:
• The stock area consists of 7.b,c,e-k and two rectangles in the south of the Irish Sea, (ICES Division 7.a, rectangles 33E2 and 33E3). This differs to the TAC area, 7.b-k, 8, 9 and 10.
  • The reallocation of landings from 33E2 and 33E3 has increased since introduced in 2006. The 2019 reallocation, largest to date, of 760 t, accounted for 9.9% of Division 7.b-k landings and 43% of Irish Sea landings (Division 7.a).
  • The TAC has been very restrictive since 2010, resulting in high discarding of fish over the minimum conservation reference size (MCRS). International discarding of catch has averaged 46% over the last 5 years (2015 to 2019).
Additional:
• The assessment was benchmarked in 2020, the model changed to a stochastic State-Space Assessment Model, maturity, natural mortality, survey indices and catch (landings and discards) time series were reviewed and updated. This has reduced perception of fishing mortality and increased biomass estimates since 2015 relative to previous assessments.
  • A 10% increase in catch advice is given for 2021 over 2020 owing to large 2018 and 2019 year classes and the revised assessment.
  • Celtic Sea haddock are caught in mixed fisheries, primarily with whiting, megrim, anglerfish, Nephrops and other species. They are rarely specifically targeted but are widely distributed, making it difficult to control fishing mortality on the stock.
  • Discarding of the stock has been high and continued so in 2019 (32% of catch).
  • The large reduction in fishing mortality advised for Celtic sea cod since 2019 will result in cod continuing to be a choke species for all demersal fleets.

Management:
• The EU multiannual plan for demersal stocks in the North Sea applies to this stock, however with failure to reach agreement with Norway, MSY advice was provided for 2021.
  • ICES advice was split across three TAC areas, with Irish interest in Union and international waters of 5.b and 6.a, and a TAC of 3,973t.
  • Over the past four years the Irish fleet has caught the full quota.
Additional:
• Most of the Irish landings of haddock in Division 6.a come from trips that target haddock. The remainder are taken from a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish and other gadoid species. A targeted seine fishery west of Donegal Bay normally accounts for 10-20% of the landings.
  • The TAC for this stock is linked to the North Sea and is negotiated as part of the EU Norway agreement. There is a fixed ratio that splits the TAC.
  • Advice has increased notably for the last two years (+23% for 2020 and +66% for 2021) both owing to strong incoming recruitment observed in 2019 surveys. Irregular strong recruitments have been a feature of the stock dynamics in the past, resulting in a saw tooth SSB time profile.

Management:
• There is no internationally agreed TAC for haddock in Division 6.b. Since 2004 an autonomous TAC has been set for EU fleets operating in Division 6.b and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • Part of Division 6.b falls (since 1999) within international waters fished by non EU vessels (mainly Russian).
  • Following the NEAFC agreement in March 2001, NEAFC has maintained an area closure to all fishing except long-lining in the SW corner of the Rockall Bank, this continued in 2020. Data are inadequate to fully evaluate the impact of this measure on the stock status.
  • Over the past four years the Irish fleet has caught the full quota.
Additional:
• Most of the Irish landings of Rockall haddock come from trips where haddock was the dominant species. They are mainly landed with megrim, saithe and anglerfish.
  • Since 2014 seiners have reported landings of haddock in Division 6.b.
  • Stock size markedly increased from an all-time low in 2014 owing to a strong 2016 year class and low fishing pressure. Advice for 2021 is down by 40% on 2020 advice following a decline in the stock size as the contribution of the 2016 year class reduces in the stock, and due to changes in the selectivity assumption for older fish in the fishery.

Management:
• The stock area of Division 7.a does not include Irish landings taken or reported in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3, which are reallocated from Division 7.a to Division 7.g.
  • This reallocation (from 2 rectangles from the Irish Sea to the Celtic Sea) has increased since first introduced in 2006, peaking in 2017.
  • The 2019 reallocation of 760 t accounted for 43% of Irish Sea (Division 7.a) landings and 10% of Celtic Sea (Divisions 7.b-k) landings. The TAC management area covers all of ICES Division 7.a.
Additional:
• The assessment shows stock size to be at a high level since the mid-2010's and fishing mortality to be low over the same period.
  • Irish landings under the Irish Sea haddock quota are mostly taken in a targeted fishery; 70% of the landings come from trips where haddock was the dominant species landed. The majority of these trips are in the south of Division 7.a in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3 which are not included in this stock assessment.
  • The advice for 2021 is the same order as 2019 advice (+7%); however, preliminary landings figures for 2020 suggest that uptake by Irish vessels will be below the quota.

Management:
• Since 2016, ICES gives one advice for the combined area 6.aN, 6.aS, and 7.b-c. ICES still considers two separate stocks exist, but it is not currently possible to segregate them in commercial catches or surveys. The 56°N boundary between 6.aS/7.b-c and 6.aN is not biologically meaningful. Created in 1981, it corresponds roughly to the boundary of the Irish and UK fishery patrol zones, or "EEZs". The boundary cuts through both the summer feeding grounds and the winter spawning grounds, and thus the fishing grounds also.
  • Since 2015 all targeted herring fishing is prohibited in the part of the ICES zones subject to this TAC between 56°N and 57°30'N, with the exception of a six nautical mile limit measured from the baseline of the United Kingdom's territorial sea.
  • In 2016, a scientific monitoring fishery (4,840 t) was considered appropriate by ICES to allow the collection of samples for the two stocks and continue the time series.
  • In 2020, a TAC of 4,840 t was agreed and was split for 5.b, 6.b and 6.aN (3,480 t, 72%) and 6.aS and 7b-c (1,360 t, 28%).
  • Irish quota in 6.aS, 7.b-c is allocated to vessels in 4 different size categories.
  • The Irish herring fishery in 6.a opened on 2nd November 2020. This opening date coincides with the historical fishing period for the 6.aS, 7.b-c stock. There is an annual seasonal closure of the Butt of Lewis spawning area from the 15th August to the 15th September each year.
  • Irish and Dutch vessels are not allowed to fish herring inside the UK (Scottish) 6-12 nautical mile limits, including the outlying Hebridean Islands. German and French vessels have access to herring fishing between 6 and 12 nautical miles in Scottish waters in most areas, though not the mainland limits east of the Butt of Lewis.
Additional:
• In 2020, in a technical service, ICES has provided forecasts on the development of herring (Clupea harengus) in divisions 6.a and 7.b-c (West of Scotland, West of Ireland), with zero-catch TAC and with the current monitoring TAC of 4,840 tonnes under two different uptake scenarios for the monitoring TAC in 2020. Both scenarios showed an increase in spawning-stock biomass (SSB) in 2021, and a stable or small (up to +6%) increase in SSB in 2022.
  • An interbenchmark was held at the start of 2019 to address the retrospective bias that was observed in the assessment. The interbenchmark could not conclude a Category 1 assessment for the stock and the assessment is now Category 3, which is indicative of trends.
  • The trends based assessment agreed at the interbenchmark gave a new perception of the stock with SSB revised downwards and F revised upwards since the early 1990s. A decrease in F can be seen since the reduction of the TACs in 6.aS, 7.b, 7.c and 6.aN, 5.b, 6.b in 2016.
  • SSB is now at one of its lowest levels in the time series. Recruitment has been very low since 2013.
  • A rebuilding plan was developed by the Pelagic AC, evaluated by ICES in 2017 and found not to be precautionary. A revised rebuilding plan was proposed by the Pelagic AC in 2018 but has not been evaluated because the quality of the assessment and stock mixing need to be resolved before the evaluation can be conducted.
  • In 2016, a stock identification project was initiated which aims to develop genetic and morphometric methods to distinguish the 6.aS and 6.aN stocks. This work will be completed and a report produced at the end of 2020.

Management:
• The Celtic Sea Herring Management Advisory Committee was established in 2005 to provide Industry input to the management of the Irish Celtic Sea herring fishery.
  • The ICES advice for 2020 was zero catch, based on the MSY approach. There was a special request to establish the amount of catch required for a scientific monitoring fishery. Council set a TAC of 869 t based on the catch level considered appropriate by ICES to allow the continued collection of samples. The Irish quota for 2020 is 750 t.
  • Spawning Box C (see Appendix IV) will be closed as part of the triennial spawning box closures that are enshrined in EC legislation.
  • The fishery in Division 7.aS is confined to vessels of <17 m LOA.
  • The UK, Netherlands, France and Germany can fish for herring in the Irish territorial limits from 6-12 nm, however, in recent years they have not fished in this area.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to individual vessels on a weekly basis in two pools, one for the main fishery and one for the sentinel fishery in Division 7.aS.
  • The TAC is set by calendar year but the assessment is carried out for the period 1st April - 31st March.
  • When less than 10 % of the total catches by live weight are below the minimum conservation reference size of 20 cm, the MCRS shall not apply.
Additional:
• Recruitment has been below average since 2013. Due to the current low SSB the incoming recruitments for 2020 and 2021 are expected to be low.
  • The SSB has been below Blim since 2016.
  • Since 2014, herring have been observed close to the seabed and are less reliably estimated by the acoustic survey.
  • The 2019 acoustic survey estimate is the lowest in the time series.
  • The addition of the 2019 data to the assessment revised the SSB downwards and the mean F upwards.
  • Genetic work on stock identification of the Irish Sea and Celtic Sea herring commenced in 2018. Tools to identify fish from each stock have been developed.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.aN.
  • There are two closed areas in operation to protect the spawning stock during part of the spawning season and to prevent exploitation of juveniles. These measures were introduced during the period of the industrial fishery in the Irish Sea (1969 - 1979). The area off County Louth and County Down is closed from the 21st September - 31st December and the Douglas Bank area, east of the Isle of Man is closed from 21st September until 15th November.
  • Vessels of less than 40 feet in length may fish within the Down-Louth seasonal closed box, but only using driftnets of mesh size ≥ 54 mm.
  • Republic of Ireland vessels are not permitted to fish herring in any part of the 0-12 nautical mile limits off England, Wales, Scotland or east of the Isle of Man. Republic of Ireland vessels are permitted to fish in waters between 6-12 nautical miles, west of the Isle of Man.
Additional:
• SSB has been above the reference points since 2006 and F has been below the reference points since 2007.
  • Catches were stable from 2005-2017. In 2018-2019, the catch increased due to an increase in TAC. Ireland caught the close to their full quota in 2018 and 2019.
  • The assessment is carried out on a mixed stock and may overestimate the Irish Sea stock due to the presence of herring from other stocks.
  • Genetic work on stock identification of the Irish Sea and Celtic Sea herring commenced in 2018. Tools to identify fish from each stock have been developed.

Management:
• A long term management strategy (LTMS) was agreed by the EU, the Faroe Islands, Iceland, Norway, and Russia in 2018.
  • ICES considers that the HCR proposed for the LTMS is consistent with the precautionary approach.
  • Since 2013, there has been no agreement by the Coastal States on TAC sharing and the management plan has not been followed. This has led to unilaterally set quotas which together are higher than the TAC indicated by the management plan.
  • In 2020, the sum of the declared national quotas is 693,915 t.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to a small number of vessels on a lottery basis.
  • EU access to the Norwegian sector where the most fishable aggregations occur is negotiated on a yearly basis. The Irish quota is not useable without EU access to the Norwegian EEZ.
  • Quantities fished by EU vessels in the NEAFC Regulatory Area and Union waters must be reported to the Commission.
  • Up to 621 t of the Irish quota may be caught in Norwegian waters north of 62°N and the fishery zone around Jan Mayen.
Additional:
• The stock is declining but is estimated to be above MSY Btrigger in 2020.
  • Fishing mortality has increased since 2015 and is estimated to be above FMSY in 2019.
  • The advice for 2021 is 24% higher than that for 2020 due to an upward revision in the 2016 year class, which contributes more to the catches in 2021.

Management:
• The assessment area overlaps with four TAC areas but Ireland only has quota for the 6, 7, 5.b, 12 and 14 TAC area (shown in the pie chart). Several inter-area flexibilities are allowed within the TAC areas.
  • About two-thirds of the landings in the TAC area are taken in Irish waters; however, Ireland only has a 6% TAC share.
  • ICES notes the existence of a precautionary management plan developed and adopted by one of the relevant management authorities for this stock.
Additional:
• The spawning-stock biomass (SSB) increased from 2006 to 2016 and has declined slightly since then. Fishing mortality (F) decreased markedly between 2005 and 2012, and has been stable around FMSY since then.
  • The advice for 2021 is about 5% lower than the advice for 2020 because the perception of the stock has been revised downwards.
  • Most Irish trawlers in Sub-area 7 do not seem to target hake but take them as a bycatch in mixed fisheries with anglerfish, megrim, haddock and whiting. In Sub-area 6 trawlers target hake along the edge of the continental shelf. There are also targeted Irish gillnet and seine fisheries for hake in Sub-area 7.
  • International discard rates of hake in 2019 were 6% of the total catch. However, Irish fleets have higher discard rates than most other countries with an average of 18% in 2019.

Management:
• The TAC only applies to EU waters. There are occasional fisheries outside the TAC area that are not limited by the TAC.
  • Since 2005, ICES advice for the Western Stock has included Division 8.c, although the EU continues to set a separate TAC for Division 8.c.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may be fished in EU waters of Divisions 2.a and 4.a before 30th June and counted against the North Sea Horse Mackerel quota.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel provided that, in combination with provisions for other bycatch species, the total does not exceed 9% of the quota.
  • The Pelagic Advisory Council have proposed a harvest control rule for this stock. This is pending a scientific review by ICES
Additional:
• The 2020 assessment shows the same trend as the previous assessment, but rescales the absolute level of SSB and F, with a downward revision in spawning-stock biomass and an upward revision in F.
  • In the past, the stock and fishery have been dependent on occasional high recruitments. There are indications of above average recruitment in recent years although it is not yet possible to determine the effect on future stock development.
  • An interbenchmark in 2019 revised the PA and MSY reference points.
  • SSB has been declining since 2006 and has been below Blim (834 480 t) from 2015-2019. SSB is currently just above Blim.
  • F has been above FMSY (0.074) since 2008.

Management:
• The stock distribution area is Divisions 4.b-c, 7.d and also 3.a and 4.a in quarters 1 and 2.
  • The agreed TAC covers 4.b-c and 7.d. There is no TAC covering Norwegian waters or the fisheries in Divisions 3.a and 4.a (quarters 1 and 2).
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel provided that, in combination with provisions for other bycatch species, the total does not exceed 9% of the quota.
  • Quota uptake has increased in recent years as the TAC has been reduced. The largest proportion of catch is taken in Division 7.d where a large proportion of the catch consists of juvenile fish.
Additional:
• Advice for this stock is biennial.
  • The stock is considered to remain at a low level.
  • The stock was benchmarked in 2017 and an abundance index based on groundfish surveys in the North Sea was developed. Consequently, the stock is now in category 3 and the index is used to provide catch advice.
  • Since 2012, catches from Division 7.d have accounted for over 80% of the total catch.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas covering the assessment area. Ireland only has quota for the TAC in area 7. Up to 5 % of the area 7 TAC may be fished in 8abde, there is currently no flexibility from 8abde to 7.
  • The TACs cover two megrim species (megrim L. whiffiagonis and four-spot megrim L. boscii). There is no catch advice for four-spot megrim. This species normally constitutes less than 5% of total landings.
Additional:
• Most Irish landings are taken as a by-catch in mixed fisheries and are landed with anglerfish, Nephrops, haddock, whiting, hake and other species. A small number of trips appear to specifically target megrim.
  • The advice for 2021 is slightly higher than the previous year as the increase in stock size is expected to level off.
  • The advice implies an Irish quota for 2021 of approximately 3,160 t. (assuming the same approach to four-spot megrim catches and the same allocation between area 7 and 8.abde as recent years).
  • The landings are usually lower than the TAC, mainly due to low uptake by France and Spain. In some years, the quota for Ireland has been restrictive.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas, covering the Union waters of Division 2.a; Subarea 4 and Union and international waters of Division 5b; Subarea 6 and international waters of Subareas 12 and 14. Ireland has no quota in the TAC area 2.a and 4
  • For assessment purposes, megrim in 4.a and 6.a are considered a single stock; with megrim in 6.b a separate stock. The assessment areas are therefore incompatible with the TAC areas.
  • Official Landings in areas 6 are well below the TAC (29%); uptake by France is low at 7%, Irish uptake is approximately 40%.
  • The increase in mesh size from 100 to 120mm (vessels >15m) in 2009 has resulted in an increase in the length of first capture.
Additional:
• Megrim landings in 6.a are taken as a by-catch in mixed fisheries primarily landed with haddock, other gadoids and anglerfish.
  • Irish Discards are primarily from Bottom otter trawls targeting mixed demersal fish with a mesh size 100-119 mm.
  • The state of the stock has not changed substantially since last year; fishing mortality has remained below FMSY since 2002, and biomass has been above MSY Btrigger for the entire time series.
  • Irish Landings in 2019 were 271 tonnes; representing a slight decrease compared to recent years.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas, covering the Union waters of Division 2.a; Subarea 4 and Union and international waters of Division 5.b; Subarea 6 and international waters of Subareas12 and 14.
  • Ireland has no quota in the TAC area of 2.a and 4. The TAC and assessment area are incompatible.
  • A separate assessment is carried out for Megrim in 6.a and 4.a, with both stocks currently fished sustainably; however, management of two stocks under a single TAC could lead to over-exploitation of one stock.
  • Official Landings in areas 6 are well below the TAC (14%); uptake by France is low at 1%, Irish uptake is approximately 60%.
Additional:
• The stock size is unknown for 2020 due to the absence of the Scottish-Irish Anglerfish and Megrim Industry-Science Survey in Subarea 6 and Division 4.a (SIAMISS-Q2)
  • The advice is normally based on the ratio of the index in the last 2 years (2019-20) over that in the 3 previous years (2016-18). This year the index ratio is calculated as the 2019 value divided by the mean index value of 2016-18, resulting in an increase in the advice compared to last year.
  • Most Irish landings in Subarea 6 are taken south of Rockall at depths below 200m in a fishery targeting anglerfish. Some catches of megrim also occur in the fishery targeted at haddock closer to Rockall in shallower water.
  • Ireland had the highest catch in 2019 followed by Scotland and Spain, with the majority coming from demersal otter trawls.
  • Fishing mortality has been increasing in recent years but remains below FMSY. Stock biomass appears stable and above BMSY.
  • Roughly 50% of Irish landings in 2019 were from fishing trips where megrim accounted for at least 25% of the catch composition; making the stock a valuable by-catch.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.a.
  • The Irish quota allocation was 77 t.
  • The TAC for this stock has increased from 414 t in 2019 to 457 t in 2020.
Additional:
• The catch advice for 2021 has increased compared to previous years due to an increase in stock size and high recruitment.
  • This catch was worth € 670,000 in 2019.
  • The absence of discard data has a minor effect on the quality of the assessment as the average discarding by weight is low in recent years (3-8%). However, in 2019 a discard rate of 14% was recorded. If this increase in discarding continues, it might be recommended to include discards in the assessment.
  • Irish landings of Irish Sea sole are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting rays and plaice in the St. George's Channel and to a lesser extent also in the Nephrops fishery. Most landings are from beam trawlers but an increasing proportion of landings are from the otter trawl fleets.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Divisions 7.b and 7.c.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent landings have been close to the TAC.
Additional: • Irish landings of West of Ireland sole are mainly taken as a bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting Nephrops and the other bottom trawl fisheries that occur in relatively shallow water (less than 200m) of area 7.b.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.f and 7.g.
  • The Irish quota is very restrictive, Ireland applies a 1% bycatch quota for sole during most months (DAFM, Fisheries management Notices).
Additional:
• The benchmark in 2020 (ICES, 2020a) introduced a new assessment model (SAM), using revised abundance and biomass indices.
  • The advice for 2021 is 16% lower than the advice for 2020, because the large 2016-year class has been reduced in abundance through fishing and the biomass is expected to decrease in 2021. This reduction, combined with a revised lower FMSY reference point, results in lower advised catch.
  • This fishery was worth € 354,000 in 2019.
  • Discarding is estimated to be 145 t in 2019, which is similar to the 2018 level of 141 t. This accounts for 12% of overall catch.
  • Irish landings of Celtic Sea sole are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting Nephrops and are in mixed beam trawl fisheries off the south coast.

Management:
• The TAC and assessment area covers Division 7.h-k.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent Irish landings have been below the quota.
Additional:
• This stock was benchmarked in 2020 and the previous assessment which covered only 7j was no longer considered an appropriate basis for management advice. The assessment was downgraded from Category 3 (trends based) to Category 5 (Catch only) and a precautionary 20% reduction on average catches was applied.
  • Sole are mainly taken in mixed otter trawl fisheries by Irish vessels off the southwest and are landed with anglerfish, megrim and gadoid species.
  • Discarding is considered to be negligible (1 t in 2019, less than 1%).

Management:
• The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6, 12, 14 and EU and international waters of Division 5.b. This TAC has been unchanged at 57 t since 2013.
  • The TACs for data limited stocks included in the Joint statement by the Fisheries Council and European Commission (Council document PECHE 13, 5232/14) will be maintained for a further 4 years (beyond 2018), subject to scientific advice unless the perception of the status of any of these stocks changes significantly during this period (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-6016_en.htm).
Additional: • The Emergency Measures (EC 43/2009) limits the mesh size of bottom trawls (TR1) and seines targeting demersal fish in the part of this area where sole are most likely to be caught, to >120 mm. This mesh size is too large to target sole.

Management:
• There is currently no agreed long-term management strategy involving all fishing nations for this stock.
  • Historically, the TAC has been divided into a North Sea TAC (EU and Norway), a Western TAC (EU, Norway and Faroes), a Southern TAC (EU) and a NEAFC TAC (Coastal States and Russia). However, there has been no TAC agreement involving all fishing parties since 2008. For 2020, the sharing agreement of 2014 between the EU, Norway and Faroes was continued, allocating 84.4% of the Coastal States TAC to the contracting parties. The remaining parties declared unilateral quotas (Iceland 135 kt, Russia 130 kt and Greenland 30 kt) such that the total expected catch for 2020 is approximately 1 090 kt.
  • The Irish 2020 quota of 78,052 t was derived from the Western TAC. Up to 47,107 t of this may be fished in EU waters of 2.a and Norwegian waters of 4.a during the periods 1st Jan to 15th Feb and 1st Oct to 31st Dec 2020, up to 6,349 t in Norwegian waters of 2.a and up to 6,494 t in Faroese waters.
  • The Cornwall box is closed to directed trawling and measures to protect the North Sea spawning component remain in place.
Additional:
• An evaluation of long term management strategies for NEA Mackerel was conducted in 2020 following a request from the EU, Norway and the Faroe Islands. A range of harvest rule parameters that are both precautionary in the long term and maximise long term yield were identified. The evaluations also resulted in revised reference point estimates with FMSY estimated to be 0.26, reflecting the increased stock productivity observed over the past 20 years.
  • Annual catches over the past decade have substantially exceeded the advised catch. A succession of above average year classes contributed to keeping SSB above MSY Btrigger since 2008 and fishing mortality has been declining in recent years and is currently below the revised FMSY.
  • Some of the survey data used in the assessment have a relatively short time series and show conflicting trends, contributing to the significant uncertainty in the stock assessment estimates.

Management:
• The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
  • Recent landings have been well below the TAC.
Additional:
• The reduction in advice (-20%) is due to the application of the precautionary buffer.
  • Irish landings of this stock are caught by otter trawlers, as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery, mainly targeting rays.
  • Discarded plaice are considered to have a survivability of approximately 40%. An exemption to the Landing Obligation applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kW or ≤ 24 m) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel (2019/2239) in ICES division 7.a to 7.k. There are no Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
  • The 2020 TAC was 2,003 t with an Irish quota of 225 t. This TAC has not been restrictive in recent years
Additional:
• Currently fishing pressure is well below the FMSY proxy and SSB well above the MSY Btrigger proxy
  • Irish landings of Celtic Sea plaice are taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with whiting and other gadoids, megrim and anglerfish.
  • Discards have increased in recent years and in 2019 28% of the catch was discarded. The majority of discards for this stock are from beam trawlers. Discards of plaice from Irish otter trawls operating in this area range in size between 20-30cm (MCRS 27cm).
  • Discards of plaice are considered to have a survivability of about 40%. Under the Landing Obligation Celtic Sea plaice have a high survivability exemption. This exemption applies to otter trawls; trammel nets; and beam trawls (≤ 221kW or ≤ 24 m) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel (EC 2019/2239).

Management:
• The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
  • In 2019 Ireland had 52% of the landings.
Additional:
• Stock size has shown a continuing upward trend, with SSB above MSY Btrigger since 2013, and F is below FMSY since 2011.
  • Irish landings of this stock are caught as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery, and are mainly landed with Nephrops and haddock.
  • Landings from Irish fleets have decreased in recent years from 315 t in 2018 to 244 t 2019, well below the quota.
  • Discards have increased in recent years, with 46% (by weight) of the catch being discarded in 2019.
  • Discards of plaice are considered to have a survivability of about 40%. Under the Landing Obligation Irish Sea plaice have a high survivability exemption. This exemption applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kW or ≤ 24 m) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel. This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The tac area covers divisions 7.h-k. However, the assessment is conducted using data from 7.j and 7.k only, as there is insufficient landings-at-age data for 7.h. The assessment assumes that data trends in 7.j and 7.k are representative of those in 7.h.
  • The Irish quota has not been restrictive since 2014.
  • A benchmark for the stock is planned for 2021.
Additional:
• Fishing pressure is highly variable but has been above Flim for most of the time-series. Spawning-stock biomass has been below Blim since 2002.
  • Irish landings of this stock are caught as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery, and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish, haddock and whiting.
  • Stock size has shown a continuing downward trend since the 1990s, with spawning-stock biomass (ssb) below Blim since 2002, therefore this stock is considered to have a reduced reproductive capacity.
  • As a result of the documented high survivability of discarded plaice, a high survivability exemption is currently in place. This exemption applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kw or ≤ 24 m) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kw) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel. This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 and Division 5.b.
  • There are no explicit management plans for this stock.
  • The Emergency Measures (EC 43/2009) limits the mesh size of bottom trawls (TR1) in this area to >120 mm.
Additional:
• Irish landings of plaice in this area are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, whiting and megrim.
  • Irish catch rates (LPUE) of plaice declined in the early 2000s and have remained at a low level since the mid 2000s, this is partially due to a change in fishing patterns.

Management:
• The assessment area includes two TAC areas; the first TAC area covers Divisions 2.a, 3.a, and Sub-area 4. The second TAC area covers Division 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14.
  • The TAC for Divisions 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 was reduced in 2020 by 1,433 t.
  • Ireland only has a quota for the latter TAC area (5.b, 6, 12 and 14). The EU quota excludes the 940 t allocation for Norway reflected in the overall TAC making the total value 8,280 t for 2020.
Additional:
• Ireland has not taken its full quota in recent years and the preliminary landings figures for 2020 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the quota.
  • The 2019 quota uptake by Ireland in Sub-areas 5.b, 6, 12 and 14 was 26.2%.
  • The advice for 2021 is 65,687 t; a decrease of 22,406 t from the 2020 advice (-25%), owing to a downward revision of stock spawning biomass and low incoming recruitment.

Management:
• The TACs for data limited stocks included in the Joint statement by the Fisheries Council and European Commission (Council document PECHE 13, 5232/14) will be maintained for a further 4 years (beyond 2018), subject to scientific advice unless the perception of the status of any of these stocks changes significantly during this period (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-6016_en.htm).
  • The TAC covers Sub-areas 7, 8, 9 and 10.
Additional:
• Irish landings of saithe in Sub-area 7 are mainly taken by gillnets, however, in some years considerable by-catches of saithe are landed with hake, whiting and pollack by bottom trawler fleets.
  • Irish landings in 2019 were the lowest observed in the time series. There is little discarding of saithe in Irish fisheries.
  • Preliminary landings figures for 2020 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the quota.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas that cover this stock. Ireland has quota for both. The first TAC area covers Divisions 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14. The second TAC area covers Sub-area 7. Up to 2% of the latter TAC may be fished in Divisions 8.a, b, d and e.
  • The TAC for Divisions 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 was reduced in 2020 by 159 t.
  • Low quota uptake by some countries mean that the current TAC's are well above the reported landings.
  • The 2019 quota uptake by Ireland in Sub-areas 5.b, 6, 12 and 14 was 43%. The 2019 quota uptake by Ireland in Sub-area 7 was higher, with 66% of the quota utilised
Additional:
• Preliminary landings figures for 2020 indicate that uptake for Irish vessels will be well below the Irish quota.
  • Irish landings of pollack are mainly taken by gillnets, however, in some years considerable by-catches of pollack are landed with hake, whiting and saithe by OTB fleets.
  • The Marine Institute is currently engaged in a project aimed at improving the assessment of pollack and gaining more insight into biological aspects of the species. This stock is scheduled will to be benchmarked by ICES in 2021.
  • Commercial landings may not reflect true pollack catches since recreational fisheries are thought to comprise a significant component of total catch. A recent study (Radford et al., 2018) estimated that recreational catches are approximately 3,500 t per year from this stock.
  • Ireland are is currently engaged in an EMFF (DCMAP) funded project aiming to evaluate improve data on recreational fisheries.

Management:
• The areas of the TACs do not correspond to the assessment area.
  • EU TACs for ling in 2020 were: 179 t for EU waters of Sub-area 3, 4,237 t for Sub-area 4, and 12,196 t for Sub-areas 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 12 and 14, with an Irish quota of 898 t.
  • A TAC is negotiated for Norwegian and Faroese vessels fishing in EU waters. In2020, the Norwegian quota for Ling in EU sub-areas 5.b, 6 and 7 was 8,000 t, while the Faroese quota was 200 t for divisions 6.a and 6.b.
  • The EU have a quota for Norwegian waters of Sub-area 4 of 1,350 t.
  • Norway is the main country targeting the stock.
Additional:
• The advice is for an increase in catch. This advice is based on an increasing biomass trend in Sub-areas 4 and 6, however, in Sub-area 7 the biomass trend is decreasing.
  • Discarding is considered to be negligible.
  • International landings for 2019 were 20,188 t with Irish landings of 453 t.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Division 7.a have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and (in 2019) most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are negligible creel fisheries in this area).
  • Irish vessels (>12 m) fishing Nephrops in the Irish Sea are required to use one of four highly selective gears and a cod end mesh size >80mm (S.I. No. 510 of 2016).
Additional:
• Irish landings of Irish Sea Nephrops are taken in a highly targeted fishery; 80% of the landings come from trips that almost exclusively (>90%) land Nephrops.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Division 7.a have been covered by the EU Landing Obligation. Pot, trap and creel and (in 2019) most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are negligible creel fisheries in this area).
  • Irish vessels (>12 m) fishing Nephrops in the Irish Sea are required to use one of four highly selective gears and a cod end mesh size >80mm (S.I. No. 510 of 2016).
Additional:
• Irish landings of Irish Sea Nephrops are taken in a highly targeted fishery; 80% of the landings come from trips that almost exclusively (>90%) landed Nephrops.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies, which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• A separate catch limit for FU16 within the wider TAC for Sub-area 7 has been in place since 2011. This has resulted in very restrictive quotas for some vessels and increases the risk of discarding. Area misreporting was also a problem in the past.
  • The fishery was closed in May 2020, when 80% of the Irish quota was exhausted, and reopened in October.
  • Since March 2018 Irish vessels targeting Nephrops in Sub-areas 6 and 7 may only fish in either of (1) Sub-area 6 and Sub-area 7, excluding FU16, or (2) FU16 of Sub-area 7 (Fisheries Management Notice No. 20 of 2018).
  • A spatio-temporal closure of the Porcupine bank for fisheries was in place between 1 May - 31 July 2010-2012. Since 2013 the period of the closure was reduced to May (this was not linked to scientific recommendations).
  • In 2013 STECF was asked by the Commission for an assessment of management arrangements in place for Nephrops on the Porcupine bank (closed areas and the "of which" clause). STECF stated that the seasonal closure which had been in place since 2010 had afforded protection to the stock. STECF considered that to achieve management objectives in this FU, TAC and other appropriate management measures should be maintained at the FU level.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Sub-area 7 have been covered by the EU Landing Obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2019 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are negligible creel fisheries in this area).
Additional:
• Fluctuations in the recent mean weight estimates meant that ICES use a recent average (2017-2019) in the calculation of the catch advice. The mean weight in the catch declined owing to increased recruitment in the area between 2015 and 2017, but has increased in 2018 and 2019. Increased catches of juvenile Nephrops have been observed on the Spanish trawl survey since 2013.
  • Grade information remains highly important for calculating mean weight in the landings. The proportion of grade data, provided by industry, declined from 49% in 2016 to 31% in 2018, but increased in 2019 to 50% following engagement of a fisheries liaison officer in Ireland.
  • The UWTV abundance estimate increased by 25% in 2020. No MSY Btrigger has been defined for this stock due to the short time series. The lowest abundance observed 722 million individuals could be used as a MSY Btrigger proxy.
  • Nephrops on the Porcupine Bank are fished in deep waters and the grounds occur over a fairly wide area at relatively low burrow abundance (compared to the inshore Nephrops grounds). Productivity of deep water Nephrops stocks are lower than those on the shelf although the individual Nephrops grow to relatively larger size and attain higher market prices.
  • Nearly 90% of the Irish landings of Porcupine Bank Nephrops come from trips where Nephrops was the dominant species, the main bycatch species is anglerfish.
  • A revision in the timing and duration of the closure should be considered. Irish sampling data shows that female Nephrops constitute a higher proportion of the catch between late May (week 22) and early July (week 27) on the Porcupine Bank. A closure during this period would reduce mortality on the female component of the population.
  • Highly variable discarding practices have been observed on individual trips since 2016. The ICES advice assumes that all catches are landed.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Sub-area 7 have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2019 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are negligible creel fisheries in this area).
Additional:
• Abundance estimates from UWTV surveys on the Aran grounds have declined significantly since 2004 and have been at or below MSY Btrigger since 2012. This is a cause for concern but it should be noted that density estimates remain at moderate levels and the stock should have good rebuilding capacity.
  • More than 90% of the Irish landings of Aran grounds Nephrops come from trips where Nephrops was the dominant species, by-catch species include anglerfish, whiting, haddock and megrim.
  • Long term average mean weights in landings and discards are used as the most appropriate values to calculate catch options on, to account for the variation seen over time.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Sub-area 7 have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2019 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are small creel fisheries in this area).
  • The average discard rate by weight in the trawl fishery for FU 19 over the last three years is 26%. This is high relative to other areas because the vessels tend to be small, with limited space and crew, therefore the on-board tailing (keeping only the tail) of the catch is not as prevalent as in other FUs around Ireland.
Additional:
• The substantial decrease in catch advice for 2021 compared to previous years is directly linked to the decreased estimate of stock abundance in 2020.
  • Around 60% of the Irish landings of FU 19 Nephrops come from trips where Nephrops was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with anglerfish, megrim, whiting and haddock.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Sub-area 7 have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2019 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are negligible creel fisheries in this area).
Additional:
• In recent years (2017-2019) Ireland is the main participant in this Nephrops fishery accounting for 67% of the landings.
  • The increase in catch advice for 2021 compared to last year is directly linked to the increased estimate of stock abundance in 2020.
  • Two-thirds of the Irish landings of Celtic Sea Nephrops come from trips where Nephrops was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish, cod and other gadoid species.
  • Recent three-year average for mean weight in landings and discards are used as inputs to calculate catch options. Sampling levels for landings and discards in this stock remain low, which is an added source of uncertainty.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Sub-area 7 have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2019 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are negligible creel fisheries in this area).
Additional:
• In recent years (2017-2019) Ireland is the main participant in this Nephrops fishery accounting for 84% of the landings.
  • Nearly 90% of Irish landings of the Smalls grounds Nephrops come from trips where Nephrops was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with whiting, cod, and anglerfish.
  • In 2019 the recent three-year average for mean weight in landings and discards are used to calculate catch options.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match. The TAC area covers Sub-area 6 and Division 5.b. Division 6.a contains three main fisheries, the North Minch (FU 11), South Minch (FU 12) and Firth of Clyde (FU 13) there are also landings outside these FUs.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Division 6.a have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2019 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation.
Additional:
• Irish landings mainly come from outside Functional Units that are not currently assessed using UWTV surveys.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops trawl fisheries have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability greater than 50% in Sub-area 6.a (Fox and Albalat, 2018 ). This exemption applies to otter trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size of 80-110 mm within twelve nautical miles of the coast (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). There is also a high survivability exemption for creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 6a.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match. The TAC area covers Sub-area 6 and Division 5.b. Division 6.a contains three main fisheries, the North Minch (FU 11), South Minch (FU 12) and Firth of Clyde (FU 13) there are also landings outside these FUs.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Division 6.a have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2019 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation.
Additional:
• Irish landings mainly come from outside Functional Units that are not currently assessed using UWTV surveys.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops trawl fisheries have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability greater than 50% in Sub-area 6.a (Fox and Albalat, 2018 ). This exemption applies to otter trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size of 80-110 mm within twelve nautical miles of the coast (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). There is also a high survivability exemption for creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 6a.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Sub-area 7 have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2019 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are negligible creel fisheries in this area).
  • Some catches reported in other rectangles are were reallocated to FU16, this is no longer an issue.
Additional:
• The ICES advice this year was based on a precautionary 20% reduction on the advice given previously. Recent landings have been above the advised catch level.
  • Nephrops outside the current FUs are not considered as separate stocks but represent small populations of Nephrops outside the identified stock units (FUs). The level of recruitment to these patches is unknown although it is likely that there is some donation of recruits from the major stock units.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• There is no agreed TAC for sea bass in Divisions 6.a, 7.b, and 7.j.
  • A prohibition on landings of sea bass by Irish commercial vessels has been in place in Ireland since 1990 (under Irish statute).
  • A series of measures have been introduced because of the depleted state of the stock. Article 10 of Council Regulation 2020/123 details the most recent measures on sea bass fisheries.
  • Nationally, the Sea Fisheries Maritime Jurisdiction Act 2006 set out fishing restrictions under two statutory instruments:
    • S.I. No. 230 of 2006, prohibits the fishing, landing, transhipping or retaining of sea bass on board an Irish commercial fishing boat; the use of nets; and prescribes an MCRS of 40 cm.
    • S.I. No. 367 of 2007 prohibits sale or offer for sale of sea bass (other than those imported).
Additional:
• The advice for 2021-2023 is 3 t; a decrease of 1 t (-25%) from the previous advice (2018-2020), owing to the application of a 20% precautionary buffer. Official reported landings are extremely low and caught solely by French fishing vessels in Division 7.j.
  • Sea bass stock identity is poorly understood. There are ongoing tagging experiments led by Inland Fisheries Ireland on the western coast of Ireland.
  • Previous tag/recapture studies on sea bass on the western Irish coastline have shown evidence of interconnectivity with the Celtic Sea.

Management:
• There is no TAC for sea bass in divisions 4.b-c, 7.a, and 7.d-h.
  • A series of measures have been introduced because of the depleted state of the stock. Article 10 of Council Regulation 2020/123 details the most recent measures on sea bass fisheries.
  • A prohibition on landings of sea bass by Irish commercial vessels has been in place in Ireland since 1990 (under Irish statute).
  • Nationally, the Sea Fisheries Maritime Jurisdiction Act 2006 set out fishing restrictions under two statutory instruments:
    • S.I. No. 230 of 2006, prohibits the fishing, landing, transhipping or retaining of sea bass on board an Irish commercial fishing boat; the use of nets; and prescribes an MCRS of 40 cm.
    • S.I. No. 367 of 2007 prohibits sale or offer for sale of sea bass (other than those imported).
Additional:
• The advice for 2021 increased by (+2.8%) from the previous advice (2020).
  • The stocks around Ireland and Britain are believed to belong to the same genetic population. Tagging research conducted by the Marine Institute has shown that sea bass may undergo long migrations from Irish coasts into the Celtic Sea and Bristol Channel, returning to the Irish coast.

Management:
• The stock assessment and management area for North Atlantic albacore tuna covers the Atlantic, north of 5°N line, and excluding the Mediterranean Sea.
  • ICCAT recommendation 98-08 limiting fishing capacity to the average of 1993-1995, remains in force. This limits the number of Irish vessels that may fish for tuna to a maximum of 50 vessels.
  • ICCAT recommendation 16-06 sets the objective of maintaining the fishing pressure below FMSY and stock biomass state above BMSY, while maximizing average catch and minimizing inter-annual fluctuations in TAC levels.
  • Any unused portion or excess of the annual adjusted quota may be added to/shall be deducted from, according to the case, the quota 2 years later (adjustment 2 years later, i.e. in 2018 for catches in 2016). The maximum allowed carryover is 25% of the initial quota in those years. ICCAT undertakes to implement additional measures if carried over quota leads to a TAC in excess of 33,600 t.
Additional:
• The stock was assessed in 2020, following the same approach as the previous assessment in 2016. The 2020 assessment uses data up to, and including 2018.
  • In 2019 Irish vessels had a total catch of 3,213 t and landed mainly into France and Spain.
  • The primary Irish fishery is with pair pelagic trawlers in the Bay of Biscay, there can be some late season catches to the south west of Ireland.
  • Observer data suggest that bycatch of sharks, seabirds, turtles and mammals are near zero. Bluefin tuna, and swordfish to a lesser extent, are potential choke species for the fishery.

Management:
• The TAC covers the entire North Atlantic Ocean east of 45°W and also the Mediterranean Sea.
  • ICCAT recommendation 09-06 sets the objective of achieving FMSY and BMSY by 2022 with at least a 60% probability.
