  • In 2006, ICCAT adopted a rebuilding plan for this stock. This plan includes various conservation measures, including a TAC together with extended time/area closures and minimum size. Management measures to reduce fishing mortality were introduced in 2008. These measures included lower TACs, increased control and enforcement measures, particularly within the Mediterranean Sea, and a requirement for all purse seine vessels targeting Bluefin tuna for farming in cages to carry observers on-board. This plan runs until 2022.
  • EU member states' retained recreational catches must be deducted from available quotas. The quota that Ireland has access to is designated for bycatch only, and not for target fisheries.
Additional:
• The stock was assessed in 2020 by means of applying statistical modelling to the available data up to 2018.
  • The ICATT Standing Committee on Research and Statistics, in line with Rec. 18-02, evaluated that fishery indicators did not indicate a reason to alter current management advice (36,000 t).
  • Work on the Management Strategy Evaluation (MSE) by the Standing Committee on Research and Statistics (SCRS) has been compromised by the abnormal circumstances related to COVID-19. The MSE process will not be completed in time to provide TAC advice for 2022-2024 and accordingly, the Committee recommended extending the MSE process for another year.
  • Ireland has no target fisheries. Bycatches in any fishery are subject to an unallocated bycatch quota for EU vessels (68.11 t in 2020). This bycatch allowance may be very restrictive as the stock rebuilds.
  • The Marine Institute commenced a research programme on Bluefin tuna in 2016 in partnership with Stanford University USA, University of Acadia Canada, Trinity College Dublin and ICCAT. A total of 97 Bluefin Tuna were tagged with pop off satellite tags (88) and accelerometer tags (11) from the Donegal coast during years 2016-2020. 2020 is the first year Bluefin have been satellite tagged off the coast of Cork with a total of 7 satellite tags deployed (out of 27 total for 2020) as well as two accelerometers (out of 3 total in 2020). Results suggest a very high survival rate of tagged fish. Tags recovered to date show that fish tend to migrate to the mid-Atlantic for overwintering with some passing through the Bay of Biscay. Several fish have been observed in the Mediterranean at spawning time before subsequently returning to Irish waters a year later. Under the continuing research programme, the Marine Institute and partners plan to apply up to 30 satellite tags and 10 accelerometer tags to Bluefin tuna in 2021.
  • A new management plan for Bluefin tuna in the Mediterranean and East Atlantic, proposed by the ICCAT in 2018 allows for countries with no assigned quota to set up a recreational /sport catch/conventional tag/release fishery. This allows member states to collect scientific data regarding the numbers of BFT in particular areas and their migratory habits. Specifically:
    • Vessels would require specific authorisations
    • Vessels must be operating in the context of a scientific project of a research institute integrated in a scientific research programme.
    • Results would also need to be communicated to the Standing Committee on Research and Science (SCRS of ICCAT) on a yearly basis.
    • Tagging must be performed by trained personnel.
  • In 2019, DAFM announced that applications were being sought from angling vessel owners to participate in this catch and release data collection fishery. 15 vessels made successful applications and were provided with authorisations to catch and release Bluefin tuna in Irish waters. All vessel owners were obliged to attend training provided by the Marine Institute, Inland Fisheries Ireland and the Sea Fisheries Protection Authority. The season was opened for the first time on the 15th of August with a closing date of the 15th of October 2019. Following consultations with DAFM, DCCAE, Marine Institute, IFI and SFPA the season was extended to the 12th of November 2019. A total of 209 BFT were tagged in 2019. For 2020, a further 7 vessels were provided with authorisations, bringing the total vessels engaged in the fishery to 22. The season opened on the 15th of August 2020 and is due to close on the 12th of November 2020. Tagging with conventional tags was carried out on fish taken alongside the vessel before their release and no fish are allowed to be landed. All fishery data required by ICCAT are being collected by the Marine Institute. Up to the end of October 2020, approximately 640 BFT had been tagged.

Management:
• There is no TAC for sprat in Irish waters. TACs are in place in the English Channel and in the North Sea.
  • EU vessels are restricted in the gear they can use to target sprat. Mesh sizes of 16 mm and above are permitted when sprat is the target species.
  • Irish vessels are not subject to any quota for sprat. Vessels >36.58 m (120 ft) are excluded from the 12 nautical mile zone. Vessels >27.43 m and <36.58 m (90 - 120 ft) are excluded from the 3 nm zone.
  • From 1 January 2020, trawlers >18 m LOA were excluded from the 6 nm zone. An exemption from this regulation allowed pelagic vessels >18 m to target sprat inside the 6 nm zone until 31 December 2021, with catches limited to 2,000 t and 1,000 t in 2020 and 2021 respectively. However, this policy directive was subject to a judicial review and is no longer in place from October 2020.
  • Following receipt of Marine Institute advice that fishing for sprat in the Dunmore Box would likely produce by-catches of Celtic Sea Herring, the Minister requested that producer organisations and the NIFF advise their members to refrain from fishing for sprat in the Dunmore Box during the September to March period. No formal preclusion is in place.
Additional:
• No TAC is set for this stock. Although ICES provides a catch advice, there is insufficient information to evaluate stock trends and exploitation, MSY and PA reference points have not been defined. Irish landings of sprat in this area increased to 13,027 t in 2019 (3,580 t in 2018, 4,318 t in 2017.)
  • On average 25 vessels over 10m participated in the sprat fishery annually from 2015-2019. The majority of the catch is taken in 7j (Kerry bays) followed by 7aS (off Dunmore East). The amount of catch taken in 6aS (Donegal Bay) varies between years with 25% coming from this area in 2019. Smaller fisheries take place in 7g and 7b. The fishery is primarily prosecuted in Q4.
  • There appears to be a truncated age structure in the sprat population in this area (0-2 year olds), which may preclude the use of age-based assessment models.
  • The Marine Institute have undertaken observer trips on the Irish sprat fishery since 2011, averaging 2 trips per year (2011-2016). The number of trips in 2017-2019 was increased to 12-15 per year.
  • Over the years 2007-2019, 54 MI observer trips were carried out, there is no record of marine mammal, seabird or sea turtle mortality by fishing activity targeting sprat.

Management: • A (bycatch) TAC of 270 t is available for countries that have a specific spurdog avoidance bycatch programme. Ireland was allocated a quota of 53 t under this TAC.
Additional:
• Spurdog have low productivity and are vulnerable to fishing because they form dense aggregations that can be easily fished. The stock currently appears to be increasing gradually from a low level. Given the longevity of the species recovery will be very slow (decades).
  • A maximum landings size of 100cm was in place in 2009 and 2010 before the TAC was set at zero in 2011. This is no longer in place.
  • The UK ran a pilot spurdog avoidance project from 2013-2016, with some quota allocated to unavoidable bycatch. This was expanded in 2017 to allow other countries to take part. There are specifications referred to in the TAC regulation as to how this programme is to be managed by each country. These specifications include detailed reporting, technical and monitoring requirements. It has not been implemented in Ireland.
  • The Spurdog assessment is scheduled for benchmark by ICES in 2021.

Management:
• Two species of Lophius occur in this area. Black anglerfish (Lophius budegassa) usually make up around 10% of the international landings but in some years this may be as much as 30%. The two species are assessed and managed as a single stock.
  • There are three TAC areas that cover the stock:
    • Union waters of areas 2.a and 4
    • Norwegian waters of area 4
    • Union and international waters of areas 6, 5.b, 12, 14.
  • Ireland only has a quota for the 6, 5.b,12,14 area and generally takes its full quota. France has the largest quota but usually takes less than a third of this. The UK has full quota uptake and is responsible for the vast majority of the international landings.
  • There is a special condition that states that up to 20% of the area 6, 5b, 12, 14 quota may be fished in UK waters of 2a and 4. A similar special condition existed last year but did not apply to Ireland and Spain.
Additional:
• The advice is based on a survey index but the UK part of the survey did not take place in 2020 due to COVID 19 concerns. The advice is normally based on the ratio of the mean index in the last 2 years (2020-21) over the mean of the 3 previous years (2017-19). This year the index ratio is calculated as the 2021 value divided by the mean index value of 2017-19, resulting in a reduction in the advice compared to last year. The index decreased by 35% but the decrease in catch advice was capped at 20% in line with ICES guidance.
  • Irish vessels mainly catch anglerfish in mixed fisheries with various gadoids and megrim near the Stanton Bank; with hake and other gadoids along the continental slope; and with megrim to the south of Rockall. The landings from Rockall (6.b) have gradually increased from almost zero in 2004 and now account for around 30% of the Irish landings of this stock.
  • Discard levels in this stock are estimated to be low (1.6% in 2020).

Management:
• The TAC applies to both species of anglerfish because they are often not separated in the landings. This could lead to over-exploitation of one species and under-exploitation of the other. However, the relative abundance of the two species does not appear to have changed much over time, suggesting that the two species are subject to similar stock dynamics and fishing mortality.
  • There are two TAC areas that cover this stock: area 7 and area 8.a,b,d,e. Up to 10% of the Sub-area 7 TAC may be fished in the United Kingdom, Divisions 8.a,b,d,e, but there currently is no flexibility from 8.a,b,d,e to 7.
Additional:
• The advice for the combined species in the two TAC areas is 52,936 t. This implies a TAC for Sub-area 7 of 41,749 t, assuming the same allocation between the TAC areas as last year. This TAC would result in an Irish quota of 3,019 t.
  • The advice for black anglerfish is based on an IBTS survey index. This survey indicates that the stock is increasing and catch data indicate that the fishing pressure is below FMSY. Therefore, the advice is for an increase in catches compared to the advice for the previous year.
  • The assessment for white anglerfish indicates that the stock is increasing and fished just below FMSY. The catch advice is very similar to the advice for the previous year. There is no increase in the advised catches because last year's estimate of the stock size has been revised downwards with the addition of an extra year of data.
  • In recent years the TAC has been set slightly below the advised catches for the two species combined.
  • France, which has most of the area 7 TAC, only landed around 55% of its allocated quota; Spain and Ireland depend on quota swaps to land their catches.
  • Much of the Irish anglerfish landings come from highly mixed fisheries. They are caught together with megrim, Nephrops, haddock, hake and other species. In some areas anglerfish are specifically targeted, mainly along the edge of the continental shelf.

Management:
• The TAC applies to both species of anglerfish because they are often not separated in the landings. This could lead to over-exploitation of one species and under-exploitation of the other. However, the relative abundance of the two species does not appear to have changed much over time, suggesting that the two species are subject to similar stock dynamics and fishing mortality.
  • There are two TAC areas that cover this stock: area 7 and area 8.a,b,d,e. Up to 10% of the Sub-area 7 TAC may be fished in the United Kingdom, Divisions 8.a,b,d,e, but there currently is no flexibility from 8.a,b,d,e to 7.
Additional:
• The advice for the combined species in the two TAC areas is 52,936 t. This implies a TAC for Sub-area 7 of 41,749 t, assuming the same allocation between the TAC areas as last year. This TAC would result in an Irish quota of 3,019 t.
  • The advice for black anglerfish is based on an IBTS survey index. This survey indicates that the stock is increasing and catch data indicate that the fishing pressure is below FMSY. Therefore, the advice is for an increase in catches compared to the advice for the previous year.
  • The assessment for white anglerfish indicates that the stock is increasing and fished just below FMSY. The catch advice is very similar to the advice for the previous year. There is no increase in the advised catches because last year's estimate of the stock size has been revised downwards with the addition of an extra year of data.
  • In recent years the TAC has been set slightly below the advised catches for the two species combined.
  • France, which has most of the area 7 TAC, only landed around 55% of its allocated quota; Spain and Ireland depend on quota swaps to land their catches (Figure 1).
  • Much of the Irish anglerfish landings come from highly mixed fisheries. They are caught together with megrim, Nephrops, haddock, hake and other species. In some areas anglerfish are specifically targeted, mainly along the edge of the continental shelf.

Management:
• The stock assessment and management units are ICES Sub-areas 6, 7 and 8.
  • A long term management plan was proposed by the Pelagic Advisory Council in 2015 and evaluated by ICES as precautionary. The plan follows the rationale for the TAC setting within the ICES advice framework, but with some additional caution at low stock size.
  • The plan includes closures from the 31st March-31st August in all areas and also inside the Irish 12-mile limit, south of 52°30' from 12th February-31st October to prevent catches of Celtic Sea herring and mackerel.
Additional:
• The full TAC has not been taken since 2012. In 2020 Ireland caught 14,666 t, above the initial quota of 13,235 t but below the adapted quota of 16,519 t.
  • Discard rates have been variable with up to 10% of the international catch discarded. Most of this is from demersal fisheries.
  • Since 2015, Denmark and UK have only caught a minor proportion of their quota.

Management:
• The assessment area covers 7.e-k, with inclusion of catch from the south Irish Sea (7.a; ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3). This does not correspond to the TAC management area of 7.b-c, 7.e-k, 8, 9 and 10; Union waters of CECAF 34.1.1.
  • The 2020 reallocation of 71 t accounted for 93% of Irish Sea (Division 7.a) landings and 15% of Celtic Sea (Divisions 7.b-k) landings.
  • Since 2005, ICES rectangles 30E4, 31E4, and 32E3 have been closed during the first quarter as part of the Celtic Sea Conservation area.
  • Since June 2020, a number of additional technical measures were introduced in parts of the Celtic Sea, including raised footropes and changes to mesh sizes, with the aim of reducing by-catch of cod in fisheries targeting other species.
  • The TAC is exclusively for bycatches of cod in fisheries for other species. No directed fisheries for cod are permitted under this quota.
Additional:
• There is a tendency for the assessment to result in overestimates of biomass and underestimates of fishing mortality which may indicate model or data issues. The estimate of F in 2019 has been revised upwards in the 2021 assessment compared to the assessment conducted in 2020.
  • Most Irish catch is taken as a minor bycatch throughout the Celtic Sea. This makes it difficult to control the fishing mortality on the stock in mixed fisheries.
  • In recent years ICES has provided a technical service on "unavoidable bycatches" of cod in the Celtic Sea based on a mixed fisheries analysis. It is likely that cod will continue to be the primary "choke" species for most Celtic Sea fleets in 2022.

Management:
• A revised management plan has been in place since 2016, for which ICES evaluated the harvest control rule in 2016 and concluded that it is precautionary.
  • Ireland has a share of the EU quota but does not actively take part in the fishery. Occasional minor catches are a result of bycatch from pelagic fisheries.
  • Bycatch of coastal cod and golden redfish, both of which are unsustainably fished, is a concern in fisheries targeting Arctic cod.
Additional:
• Stock size is considered to be well above the long-term average, although it continues to decrease from a peak in 2013.
  • Fishing pressure has been increasing since the mid-2000s, and is now at FMSY. There has been no strong recruitment since the 2007 and 2008 year classes.
  • Under the management plan, the TAC is calculated as the average catch predicted for the coming 3 years using a defined target level of exploitation, set according to rules around the spawning-stock biomass (SSB) in the first year of the forecast.

Management:
• Quota is exclusively for bycatch in fisheries for other species.
  • Division 6.a cod falls under a quota exchange mechanism related to the Landing Obligation, through which up to 6% of national quota is made available to other Member States who lack quota.
  • The TAC Area covers Division 6.a, EU and international waters of 5.b east of 12° 00' W. The assessment covers Division 6.a only and landings in the past have been adjusted to include substantial area misreporting estimates for landings reported in 4 but thought to be taken in 6.a.
Additional:
• The 2020 ICES advice for this stock is biennial and is relevant for 2021 and 2022.
  • The stock collapsed in the early 1980s, with SSB dropping from 40,000 t to below 3,100 t in 2006, with no indications of recovery despite significant management measures.
  • There is no targeted fishery for cod in Division 6a. Landings are from bycatch in the mixed bottom trawl fishery targeting haddock, saithe, hake, anglerfish and megrim. ICES has provided a technical service for cod in Division 6.a which states that: "For cod in Division 6.a, catches in 2022 are estimated to be between 1,319 t and 2,362 t, assuming that the fishing mortality on cod changes by the same proportion as the changes advised for saithe or haddock. Under the scenario resulting in lower catch, spawning-stock biomass (SSB) in 2023 is expected to increase by 17% while the higher catch option is expected to result in a decrease in SSB of 25%."
  • The stock assessment was benchmarked in 2020. This resulted in a change of the assessment method, the inclusion of revised catch (mostly discards) data from 2003 onwards, and updated biological parameters. The impact of this was to upscale SSB, F and recruitment but the overall stock status and perception of the stock has not changed. Although a significant proportion (> 40%) of total landings of Division 6.a cod are misreported to the North Sea (Sub-area 4), there is uncertainty around the true proportion.
  • There is increasing evidence that cod in the north of 6.a are in fact part of the North Sea population. This will be investigated in future benchmarks.

Management: • The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6.b, EU and international waters of 5.b west of 12°00' W and to 12 and 14. The TAC applies to EU vessels only and not the international fishery at Rockall.
Additional:
• The ICES advice issued in 2020 is relevant for 2021, 2022 and 2023.
  • Total landings for 2020 (the most recent available data point) were estimated to be 42 t, the majority is taken by Scottish vessels.
  • Irish landings of Rockall cod are taken as a minor bycatch in the fishery targeting haddock; they are also landed with megrim, saithe and anglerfish.
  • Irish LPUE showed large reductions from the 1990s to historic lows in recent years. Scottish LPUE and survey data shows some increase in abundance in the last 3-4 years but the stock is likely to be significantly lower than was observed in the 1990s.

Management:
• The TAC Area covers Division 7.a, which corresponds to the assessment area, however Irish landings taken or reported from 33E2 and 33E3 (off Waterford & Wexford), are transferred into the Celtic Sea assessment (Division 7.e-k).
  • The 2020 reallocation of 71 t accounted for 93% of Irish Sea (Division 7.a) landings and 15% of Celtic Sea (Divisions 7.b-k) landings. The TAC management area covers all of ICES Division 7.a.
  • The TAC is exclusively for by-catches. No directed fisheries are permitted under this quota.
  • This stock is considered to be a target stock in the Western Waters MAP regulation ((EU) 2019/472) but given the state of the stock no directed fisheries are permitted.
  • All Irish TR2 vessels targeting Nephrops in 7.a must use highly selective gears i.e. SELTRA trawl, large mesh (300mm) square mesh panels or sorting grid as a condition of national license obligations.
Additional:
• Previous assessments showed signs of stock recovery around 2016, and the TAC was increased in 2018. However, this perceived recovery did not persist as the expected proportions of older fish were not observed in the survey or catches over time.
  • The update assessment this year show that stock biomass in 2021 is the lowest in time series.
  • In the past cod were mainly taken as a bycatch in the Nephrops fisheries. In 2020, 40% of landings are from vessels targeting demersal fish.
  • An EU funded tagging study which concluded in 2019, has indicated some outward migration of mature cod into the Celtic Sea. This needs to be further investigated to determine stock assessment implications.

Management:
• A long-term management strategy was agreed by the European Union, the Faroe Islands, Iceland and Norway in 2016. ICES has evaluated the strategy in 2016 and found it to be precautionary.
  • Since 2014, there have been difficulties in reaching a sharing agreement for the blue whiting stock and total catches have exceeded advice.
  • In 2021, the catch is estimated at 1,242,727 t (based on declared quotas and expected uptake), substantially in excess of the catch advice of 929,292 t.
  • Ireland has a share of the EU quota, in Sub-areas 1-7, Divisions 8.a, 8.b, 8.d, 8.e and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • A separate EU quota exists for 8.c, 9 and 10. There is no Irish quota in these areas.
  • The EU TAC may be adjusted subject to transfers in the EU-Norway agreement.
Additional:
• Stock size has been declining since 2017 but remains above MSY Btrigger. Following three consecutive years of below average recruitment, recruitment in 2020-21 is estimated to have increased.
  • The long-term management strategy was evaluated in 2016 and did not take into account consistent deviations from the plan catch advice. Therefore, the current implementation of the long-term management strategy may no longer be precautionary.

Management:
• The stock area consists of Divisions 7.b,c,e-k and two ICES rectangles in the south of Division 7.a (33E2 and 33E3) which are reallocated to Division 7.g. This differs to the TAC area, 7.b-k, 8, 9 and 10.
  • ICES division 7.d is not included in the assessment area for the whiting 7.b-k stock.
  • Whiting in 7.d are included in the North Sea MAP (EU regulation 2018/973)
Additional:
• The stock assessment was inter-benchmarked in 2021 leading to a delay in the advice until October 2021. The model input data were updated with additional discard data, re-estimated weights-at-age, and a revision to the allocation of sampling across catch. Reference points were also updated.
  • Ireland accounts for around 45% of the whiting landings and is the only country with a directed whiting fishery in the Celtic sea. The majority of Irish landings are from trips where whiting was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are landed with haddock, hake, megrim, anglerfish and Nephrops.
  • Mixed-fisheries advice will be provided in the Celtic Seas fisheries overview later in the year.
  • Discards have declined in recent years from 28% of the catch in 2017 (4,505 t) to 18% (1,266 t) in 2020 . The majority of discards occur above the minimum landing size.

Management:
• The assessment area is 6.a while the TAC management area covers ICES sub-area 6 and UK and international waters of 5.b and international waters 12 and 14.
  • The 2021 TAC was set at 937 t, an EU quota of 352 t, with an associated Irish quota of 299 t, exclusively for bycatches.
Additional: <ul><li> Ireland accounts for around 45% of the whiting landings and is the only country with a directed whiting fishery in the Celtic sea. The majority of Irish landings are from trips where whiting was the dominant species. The remainder are taken in a more mixed fishery and are landed with haddock, hake, megrim, anglerfish and Nephrops.

Management:
• ICES provides triennial advice for this stock (2022-24).
  • TAC covers ICES Sub-areas 6 and UK and international waters of Division 5.b and international waters of 12 and 14. Therefore, the TAC cannot effectively manage catches in Division 6.b (Rockall) specifically.
  • TAC is exclusively for bycatches; no targeted fisheries are permitted.
Additional: <ul><li> Mixed-fisheries advice will be provided in the Celtic Seas fisheries overview later in the year.

Management: • The stock area does not include landings taken or reported in 33E2 and 33E3, these ICES rectangles accounted for an average of 34% of the ICES Division 7.a landings over the last five years. The TAC management area covers all of Division 7.a.
Additional: <ul><li> Discards have declined in recent years from 28% of the catch in 2017 (4,505 t) to 18% (1,266 t) in 2020 . The majority of discards occur above the minimum landing size.

Management:
• The stock area consists of 7.b,c,e-k and two rectangles in the south of the Irish Sea, (ICES Division 7.a, rectangles 33E2 and 33E3). This differs to the TAC area, 7.b-k, 8, 9 and 10.
  • The reallocation of landings from 33E2 and 33E3 has generally increased since introduced in 2006. The 2020 reallocation of 554 t was down on that of 2019 (760 t), and accounted for 7% of Division 7.b-k landings and 43% of Irish Sea landings (Division 7.a).
  • The TAC has been very restrictive since 2010, resulting in high discarding. International discarding of catch has averaged 44% over the last 5 years (2016 to 2020).
Additional:
• Restrictions owing to the Covid-19 pandemic did not affect scientific surveys, while at-sea fishing and port sampling were initially impacted in the first half of the year. Port sampling was sufficient through the second half of the year, while an at-sea self-sampling programme supported data collection during this time. As a result, the assessment is considered representative of the stock.
  • The advised catch for 2022 is 13% lower than that for 2021 owing to lower recruitment in 2019 and 2020 and the associated reduction in the forecast stock size.
  • Celtic Sea haddock are caught in mixed fisheries, primarily with whiting, megrim, anglerfish, Nephrops and other species. They are rarely specifically targeted but are widely distributed, making it difficult to control fishing mortality on the stock.
  • Discarding of the stock has been high and continued so in 2020 (35% of catch).
  • The zero catch advised for Celtic sea cod and associated low quotas since 2019 will result in cod continuing to be a choke species for all demersal fleets.

Management:
• ICES advice was split across three TAC areas. The Irish quota is from the TAC covering 6a and United Kingdom and international waters of 5b. The 2021 TAC was set at 4,767 t with an Irish quota of 648 t.
  • From 2015 to 2019 the Irish fleet caught its full quota, this was not the case in 2020.
Additional:
• Most of the Irish landings of haddock in Division 6.a come from trips that target haddock. The remainder are taken from a more mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish and other gadoid species. A targeted seine fishery west of Donegal Bay normally accounts for 10-20% of the landings.
  • The TAC for this stock is linked to the North Sea and is negotiated as part of an EU, UK and Norway agreement.
  • Advice has increased notably for the last three years owing to strong incoming recruitment in 2019 and 2020. Irregular strong recruitments have been a feature of the stock dynamics in the past, resulting in a saw tooth SSB time profile.

Management:
• There is no internationally agreed TAC for haddock in Division 6.b. Since 2004 an autonomous TAC has been set for EU fleets operating in Division 6.b and Sub-areas 12 and 14.
  • Part of Division 6.b falls (since 1999) within international waters fished by non EU vessels (mainly Russian).
  • Following the NEAFC agreement in March 2001, NEAFC has maintained an area closure to all fishing except long-lining in the SW corner of the Rockall Bank, this continued in 2021. Data are inadequate to fully evaluate the impact of this measure on the stock status.
  • The Irish fleet has caught the full quota since 2015, except in 2020.
Additional:
• Most of the Irish landings of Rockall haddock come from trips where haddock was the dominant species. They are mainly landed with megrim, saithe and anglerfish.
  • Since 2014 seiners have reported landings of haddock in Division 6.b.
  • Advice for 2022 is down by 6.6% on 2021 advice due to a downward revision in stock size estimates.
  • In the past the Irish haddock fishery has operated on the bank both within and beyond 12 miles of Rockall.

Management:
• The stock area of Division 7.a does not include Irish landings taken or reported in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3, which are reallocated from Division 7.a to Division 7.g.
  • This reallocation (from 2 rectangles from the Irish Sea to the Celtic Sea) has increased since first introduced in 2006, peaking in 2017.
  • The 2020 reallocation of 554 t accounted for 43% of Irish Sea (Division 7.a) landings and 8% of Celtic Sea (Divisions 7.b-k) landings. The TAC management area covers all of ICES Division 7.a.
Additional:
• The assessment shows stock size to be at a high level since the mid-2010's and fishing mortality to be low over the same period.
  • Irish landings under the Irish Sea haddock quota are mostly taken in a targeted fishery, with approximately 72% of landings coming from trips where haddock was the dominant species landed. The majority of these trips are in the south of Division 7.a in ICES rectangles 33E2 and 33E3 which are not included in this stock assessment.
  • The advice for 2022 is 18% lower than that for 2021 owing to lower incoming recruitment.

Management:
• Since 2016, ICES gives one advice for the combined area 6.aN, 6.aS, and 7.b-c. ICES still considers two separate stocks exist, but it is not currently possible to segregate them in commercial catches or surveys. The 56°N boundary between 6.aS/7.b-c and 6.aN is not biologically meaningful. Created in 1981, it corresponds roughly to the boundary of the Irish and UK fishery patrol zones, or "EEZs". The boundary cuts through both the summer feeding grounds and the winter spawning grounds, and thus the fishing grounds also.
  • Since 2015 all targeted herring fishing is prohibited in the part of the ICES zones subject to this TAC between 56°N and 57°30'N, with the exception of a six nautical mile limit measured from the baseline of the United Kingdom's territorial sea.
  • In 2016, a scientific monitoring fishery (4,840 t) was considered appropriate by ICES to allow the collection of samples for the two stocks and to continue the time series.
  • In 2021, a TAC of 4,840 t was agreed and was split for 5.b, 6.b and 6.aN (3,480 t, 72%) and 6.aS and 7b-c (1,360 t, 28%).
  • Irish quota in 6.aS, 7.b-c is allocated to vessels in 4 different size categories.
  • The Irish herring fishery in 6.a opened on 1st November 2021.
  • Irish and Dutch vessels are not allowed to fish herring inside the UK (Scottish) 6-12 nautical mile limits, including the outlying Hebridean Islands. German and French vessels have access to herring fishing between 6 and 12 nautical miles in Scottish waters in most areas, though not the mainland limits east of the Butt of Lewis.
Additional:
• In 2021, in a technical service, ICES has provided forecasts on the development of herring (Clupea harengus) in divisions 6.a and 7.b-c (West of Scotland, West of Ireland), with zero-catch TAC, with partial (1540 t), and with full (4840 t) uptake of the current monitoring TAC, under two different uptake scenarios for the monitoring TAC in 2021. All scenarios show an increase in spawning-stock biomass (SSB) in 2022 (17% and 21%), and a small (4% and 5%) decrease in SSB in 2023.
  • This combined stock is due for benchmarking in 2022, with the primary goal of once again separating the assessments of the 6.aS, 7.b, 7.c and 6.aN, 5.b, 6.b stocks. This work will largely depend on the recently completed genetic stock identification project, which will be used to split the Malin Shelf Herring Acoustic Survey index.

Management:
• The Celtic Sea Herring Management Advisory Committee was established in 2005 to provide Industry input to the management of the Irish Celtic Sea herring fishery.
  • Council set a TAC of 869 t based on the catch level considered appropriate by ICES to allow the continued collection of samples. The Irish quota for 2021 is 750 t.
  • Spawning Box A will be closed as part of the triennial spawning box closures that are enshrined in EC legislation.
  • The fishery in Division 7.aS is confined to vessels of <17 m LOA.
  • The UK, Netherlands, France and Germany can fish for herring in the Irish territorial limits from 6-12 nm, however, in recent years they have not fished in this area.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to individual vessels on a weekly basis in two pools, one for the main fishery and one for the sentinel fishery in Division 7.aS.
  • The TAC is set by calendar year but the assessment is carried out for the period 1st April - 31st March.
  • When less than 10 % of the total catches by live weight are below the minimum conservation reference size of 20 cm, the MCRS shall not apply.
Additional:
• There was very low uptake of the monitoring TAC in 2020.
  • Recruitment has been below average since 2013. Due to the current low SSB the incoming recruitments for 2021 and 2022 are expected to be low.
  • The SSB has been below Blim since 2016. There are no catch scenarios that will rebuild the stock above Blim by 2023.
  • The 2020 acoustic survey estimate was the second lowest in the time series after 2019.
  • Once again, the addition of the latest year of data to the assessment revised the SSB downwards and the fishing mortality upwards.
  • Genetic work on stock identification of the Irish Sea and Celtic Sea herring is on-going. Tools to identify fish from each stock have been developed but have yet to be deployed.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.aN.
  • There are two closed areas in operation to protect the spawning stock during part of the spawning season and to prevent exploitation of juveniles. These measures were introduced during the period of the industrial fishery in the Irish Sea (1969 - 1979). The area off County Louth and County Down is closed from the 21st September - 31st December and the Douglas Bank area, east of the Isle of Man is closed from 21st September until 15th November.
  • Vessels of less than 40 feet in length may fish within the Down-Louth seasonal closed box, but only using driftnets of mesh size ≥ 54 mm.
  • Republic of Ireland vessels are not permitted to fish herring in any part of the 0-12 nautical mile limits off England, Wales, Scotland or east of the Isle of Man. Republic of Ireland vessels are permitted to fish in waters between 6-12 nautical miles, west of the Isle of Man.
Additional:
• SSB has been above the reference points since 2006 and F has been below the reference points since 2007.
  • Catches were stable from 2005-2017. In 2018-2020, the catch increased due to an increase in TAC. Ireland caught close to their full quota in 2018 - 2020.
  • The assessment is carried out on a mixed stock and may overestimate the Irish Sea stock due to the presence of herring from other stocks.
  • Genetic work on stock identification of the Irish Sea and Celtic Sea herring is on-going. Tools to identify fish from each stock have been developed but are yet to be deployed.

Management:
• A long term management strategy (LTMS) was agreed by the EU, the Faroe Islands, Iceland, Norway, and Russia in 2018.
  • ICES considers that the HCR proposed for the LTMS is consistent with the precautionary approach.
  • Since 2013, there has been no agreement by the Coastal States on TAC sharing and the management plan has not been followed. This has led to unilaterally set quotas which together are higher than the TAC indicated by the management plan.
  • In 2021, the sum of the declared national quotas is 881,097 t which is above the ICES advice of 651,033 t.
  • The Irish quota is allocated to a small number of vessels on a lottery basis.
  • EU access to the Norwegian sector where the most fishable aggregations occur is negotiated on a yearly basis. The Irish quota is not useable without EU access to the Norwegian EEZ.
Additional:
• The stock has increased slightly, following a steady decline since 2008, SSB is estimated to be above MSY Btrigger in 2021.
  • Fishing mortality has increased since 2015 and is estimated to be above FMSY in 2020.
  • The advice is based on the target fishing mortality in the long-term management strategy, but it does not take into account the deviations from the plan as evident from the sum of declared unilateral quotas.
  • The 2016-year class is expected to dominate the catches in 2022 and the subsequent year classes recruiting to the fishery are estimated to be weak.

Management:
• The assessment area overlaps with four TAC areas but Ireland only has quota for the 6, 7, 5.b, 12 and 14 TAC area (shown in the pie chart). Several inter-area flexibilities are allowed within the TAC areas.
  • About two-thirds of the landings in the TAC area are taken in Irish waters; however, Ireland only has a 5% TAC share.
  • The EU multiannual plan (MAP) for stocks in the Western Waters and adjacent has been agreed by the EU for this stock (EU, 2019). This plan is not adopted by Norway and UK; thus, it was not used as the basis of the advice for this shared stock.
  • Norway takes around 4% of the landings from their own waters although they don't set a quota for their own waters or include hake in coastal states negotiations.
Additional:
• The spawning-stock biomass (SSB) increased considerably from 2006 to 2016 and fluctuated at a high level since. Fishing mortality (F) decreased markedly between 2005 and 2012, and has been stable around FMSY since then.
  • The advice for 2022 is 27% lower than the advice for 2021 this is because the updated assessment revised down the SSB estimates significantly compared to last year's assessment. This is owing to the uncertainties in the assessment which is length based and relies on multiple surveys that do not cover the entire range of this widely distributed stock.
  • Most Irish trawlers do not seem to target hake but take them as a bycatch in mixed fisheries with anglerfish, megrim, haddock and whiting. There are targeted Irish gillnet and seine fisheries for hake in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• The TAC only applies to EU waters. There are occasional fisheries outside the TAC area that are not limited by the TAC.
  • Since 2005, ICES advice for the Western Stock has included Division 8.c, although the EU continues to set a separate TAC for Division 8.c.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may be fished in United Kingdom and EU waters of Divisions 2.a and 4.a before 30th June and counted against the North Sea Horse Mackerel quota.
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel provided that, in combination with provisions for other bycatch species, the total does not exceed 9% of the quota.
Additional:
• The 2021 assessment shows the same trend as the previous assessment, but rescales the absolute level of SSB and F, with a downward revision in spawning-stock biomass and an upward revision in F.
  • In the past, the stock and fishery have been dependent on occasional high recruitments. Recruitment estimates for 2014-2018 were the highest observed since 2008. Recruitment estimates have decreased in 2019 and 2020.
  • SSB has been below Blim (834, 480 t) from 2014-2020. SSB is currently just above Blim.
  • The Pelagic Advisory Council have proposed a rebuilding plan for this stock. This was reviewed by ICES in 2021 and was found to be precautionary in the long term. It shows potential for SSB to be above Bpa for three consecutive years over the ten-year time frame specified in the plan. The plan has not been used by ICES as the basis for the advice because it has not been agreed by all relevant management authorities.
  • Fishing mortality has been above FMSY (0.074) since 2008 but in 2020 F was estimated to be just below FMSY at 0.071.

Management:
• The stock distribution area is Divisions 4.b-c, 7.d and also 3.a and 4.a in quarters 1 and 2.
  • The agreed TAC covers 4.b-c and 7.d. There is no TAC covering Norwegian waters or the fisheries in Divisions 3.a and 4.a (quarters 1 and 2).
  • Up to 5% of the quota may consist of bycatches of boarfish, haddock, whiting and mackerel provided that, in combination with provisions for other bycatch species, the total does not exceed 9% of the quota.
  • Quota uptake has increased in recent years as the TAC has been reduced. The largest proportion of catch is taken in Division 7.d where a large proportion of the catch consists of juvenile fish.
Additional:
• Advice for this stock is biennial.
  • The stock is considered to remain at a low level.
  • The stock was benchmarked in 2017 and an abundance index based on groundfish surveys in the North Sea was developed. Consequently, the stock is now in category 3 and the index is used to provide catch advice.
  • Since 2012, catches from Division 7.d have accounted for over 80% of the total catch.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas covering the assessment area. Ireland only has quota for the TAC in area 7. Up to 5 % of the area 7 TAC may be fished in 8.a,b,d,e, there is currently no flexibility from 8.a,b,d,e to 7.
  • The TACs cover two megrim species (megrim L. whiffiagonis and four-spot megrim L. boscii). There is no catch advice for four-spot megrim. This species normally constitutes less than 5% of total landings.
Additional:
• Most Irish landings are taken as a by-catch in mixed fisheries and are landed with anglerfish, Nephrops, haddock, whiting, hake and other species. A small number of trips appear to specifically target megrim.
  • The advice implies an Irish quota for 2022 of approximately 2,844 t. (assuming the same approach to four-spot megrim catches and the same allocation between area 7 and 8.a,b,d,e as recent years).
  • The landings are usually lower than the TAC, mainly due to low uptake by France and Spain. In some years, the quota for Ireland has been restrictive.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas, the first covers the United Kingdom and Union waters of 4 and United Kingdom waters of 2.a. The second covers Subarea 6 and United Kingdom and international waters of 5b; international waters of 12 and 14. Ireland has no quota in the TAC area 2.a and 4.
  • There are special conditions allowing quota flexibilities between TAC areas; 20% of the 4 and 2.a quota may be fished in United Kingdom, Union and international waters of 6a north of 58°30'N and 25% of the 6 and 5.b quota may be fished in United Kingdom and Union waters of 2.a and 4.
  • For assessment purposes, megrim in 4.a and 6.a are considered a single stock; with megrim in 6.b a separate stock. The assessment areas are therefore incompatible with the TAC areas.
  • Official Landings in areas 6 are well below the TAC (43%); uptake by France is low at 8% and Ireland utilises its full quota allocation.
Additional:
• Megrim landings in 6.a are taken as a by-catch in mixed fisheries primarily landed with haddock, other gadoids and anglerfish. Irish Landings in 2020 were 249 tonnes; representing a slight decrease compared to recent years.
  • Irish discards are primarily from bottom otter trawls targeting mixed demersal fish with a mesh size 100-119mm.
  • The state of the stock has not changed substantially since last year; fishing mortality has remained below FMSY since 2002, and biomass has been above MSY Btrigger for the entire time series.

Management:
• The TAC for this stock covers Subarea 6 and United Kingdom and international waters of 5b; international waters of 12 and 14.
  • A separate assessment is carried out for Megrim in 6.a and 4.a. The stock at Rockall (6.b) and on the northern shelf (6.a4.a) are currently fished sustainably; however, management of two stocks under a single TAC could lead to over-exploitation of one stock.
  • There are special conditions allowing quota flexibilities between TAC areas; 20% of the 4 and 2.a quota may be fished in United Kingdom, Union and international waters of 6a north of 58°30'N and 25% of the 6 and 5.b quota may be fished in United Kingdom and Union waters of 2.a and 4.
  • Official Landings in areas 6 are well below the TAC (43%); uptake by France is low at 8% and Ireland utilises its full quota allocation.
Additional:
• This stock was benchmarked in 2021 and the assessment category was changed from 3 to 2; this meant that MSY advice could be provided.
  • Most Irish landings in Subarea 6 are taken south of Rockall at depths below 200m in a fishery targeting anglerfish. Some catches of megrim also occur in the fishery targeted at haddock closer to Rockall in shallower water.
  • Ireland had the highest catch in 2020 followed by the UK and Spain, with the majority coming from demersal otter trawls.
  • Fishing mortality has been stable in recent years and remains below FMSY. Stock biomass appears stable and above BMSY.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.a.
  • The TAC is set at 768 t. The EU component is 578 t and the Irish quota allocation is 104 t.
Additional:
• The stock is now estimated to be above MSY Btrigger after a period of better recruitment and low fishing mortality.
  • Discard data is not included in the assessment but shows an increase in recent years from 3.5% (2016-2018) to 10% (2018-2020). If this increase in discarding continues, it might be recommended to include discards in the assessment.
  • Irish landings of Irish Sea sole are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting rays and plaice in the St. George's Channel and to a lesser extent also in the Nephrops fishery. Most landings are from beam trawlers but an increasing proportion of landings are from the otter trawl fleets.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Divisions 7.b and 7.c.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent landings have been close to the TAC prior to 2020 when landings were low.
Additional: • Irish landings of West of Ireland sole are mainly taken as a bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting Nephrops and the other bottom trawl fisheries that occur in relatively shallow water (less than 200m) of area 7.b.

Management:
• The stock and management units are both ICES Division 7.f and 7.g.
  • The Irish quota is very restrictive; Ireland applies minimal quotas for sole during most months.
Additional:
• The advice for 2022 is slightly lower the advice for 2021, because the large 2016-year class has been reduced in abundance through fishing and the biomass is expected to decrease in 2022.
  • Discarding is estimated to be 106 t in 2020 which accounts for 7% of overall catch.
  • Irish landings of Celtic Sea sole are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries targeting Nephrops and in mixed beam trawl fisheries off the south coast.

Management:
• The TAC and assessment area covers Division 7.h-k.
  • The stock is managed by TAC and recent Irish landings have been below the quota.
Additional:
• This stock was benchmarked in 2020 and the previous assessment which covered only 7.j was no longer considered an appropriate basis for management advice.
  • Sole are mainly taken in mixed otter trawl fisheries by Irish vessels off the southwest and are landed with anglerfish, megrim and gadoid species.
  • Discarding is considered to be negligible (< 1 t in 2020).

Management:
• The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6, 12, 14 and EU and international waters of Division 5.b.
  • The TACs for data limited stocks included in the Joint statement by the Fisheries Council and European Commission (Council document PECHE 13, 5232/14) will be maintained for a further 4 years (beyond 2018), subject to scientific advice unless the perception of the status of any of these stocks changes significantly during this period (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-6016_en.htm).
Additional: • The minimum mesh size of bottom trawls (TR1) and seines targeting demersal fish in the part of this area where sole are most likely to be caught, to >120 mm which is too large to target sole.

Management:
• There is currently no agreed long-term management strategy involving all nations fishing this stock.
  • Historically, the TAC has been divided into a North Sea TAC (EU and Norway), a Western TAC (EU, Norway and Faroes), a Southern TAC (EU) and a NEAFC TAC (Coastal States, Iceland and Russia). However, there has been no sharing agreement involving all fishing parties since 2008 and the sharing agreement in place between the EU, Norway and the Faroes since 2014 has not been continued in 2021 with Norway and the Faroes declaring increased quotas for 2021. The remaining parties declared unilateral quotas such that the total expected catch for 2021 is approximately 1,199 kt. The advised catch for 2021 is 852 kt.
  • The Irish 2021 quota of 60,847 t was derived from the Western TAC and may be fished in UK waters of 4.a during the periods 1st Jan to 14th Feb and 1st Aug to 31st Dec 2021.
  • The Cornwall box is closed to directed trawling and measures to protect the North Sea spawning component remain in place.
Additional:
• A number of above average year classes between 2000 and 2010 resulted in an increased stock size and an expanded distribution. Recent recruitment is estimated to be weaker and, combined with high catches (consistently above advice), SSB has been falling since 2014, although it remains above MSY Btrigger. Fishing mortality has been below FMSY since 2011 but is rising and is just below FMSY in 2020.
  • An evaluation of long-term management strategies for NEA Mackerel was conducted in 2020 following a request from the EU, Norway and the Faroe Islands. A range of harvest rule parameters that are both precautionary in the long term and maximise long term yield were identified. The evaluations also resulted in revised reference point estimates with FMSY estimated to be 0.26, reflecting the increased stock productivity observed over the past 20 years.

Management:
• The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
  • Recent landings have been well below the TAC.
Additional:
• The reduction in advice (-20%) is due to the application of the precautionary buffer.
  • Historically, Irish landings of this stock are caught by otter trawlers, as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery. In 2020 landings from otter trawls decreased from 5 to 3 tonnes.
  • Discarded plaice are considered to have a survivability of approximately 40%. An exemption to the Landing Obligation applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kW or ≤ 24 m) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel (EC 2020/2015) in ICES division 7.a to 7.k. There are no Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
  • The 2021 TAC was 1,911 t with an Irish quota of 240 t. This TAC has not been restrictive in recent years.
Additional:
• Currently fishing pressure is well below the FMSY proxy and SSB well above the MSY Btrigger proxy
  • Irish landings of Celtic Sea plaice are taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with whiting and other gadoids, megrim and anglerfish.
  • Discards have increased in recent years and in 2020 40% of the catch was discarded. The majority of discards for this stock are from beam trawlers. Discards of plaice from Irish otter trawls operating in this area range in size between 20-30cm (MCRS 27cm).
  • Discards of plaice are considered to have a survivability of about 40%. Under the Landing Obligation Celtic Sea plaice have a high survivability exemption. This exemption applies to otter trawls; trammel nets; and beam trawls (≤ 221kW or ≤ 24 m) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel (EC 2020/2015).

Management: • The TAC and the assessment area are the same.
Additional:
• Stock size increased after 2013 and is above MSY Btrigger with fishing mortality below FMSY since 2011.
  • Irish landings of this stock are caught as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery, and are mainly landed with Nephrops and haddock.
  • Landings from Irish fleets have decreased in recent years from 315 t in 2018 to 177 t in 2020, well below the quota.
  • Discards have increased in recent years, with 45% (by weight) of the catch being discarded in 2020.
  • Discards of plaice are considered to have a survivability of about 40%. Under the Landing Obligation Irish Sea plaice have a high survivability exemption. This exemption applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kW or ≤ 24 m) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel (EC 2020/2015). This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The TAC and assessment area covers 7.hjk and the TAC is exclusively for by-catch.
  • The Irish quota has not been restrictive since 2014.
Additional:
• The stock was benchmarked in 2021, and advice is now produced using a trends based assessment using a new combined survey index, and a SPiCT model to estimate proxy MSY reference points.
  • On the relative scale the biomass is estimated to be above the B/BMSY reference point since 2004 and has remained stable in recent years. The estimated fishing mortality has been estimated to be below F/FMSY and is at the lowest in the time series.
  • Irish landings of this stock are caught as a minor bycatch in a mixed fishery and are mainly landed with megrim, anglerfish, haddock and whiting.
  • As a result of the documented high survivability of discarded plaice, a high survivability exemption is currently in place. This exemption applies to beam trawls (≤ 221kW or ≤ 24 m) within 12nm of the coast, and towing for less than 90 minutes; and beam trawls (>221kW) using flip-up rope or benthic release panel (EC 2020/2015). This is unlikely to affect Irish fisheries as there are few Irish beam trawls operating in this area.

Management:
• The TAC area covers Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 and Division 5.b.
  • There are no explicit management plans for this stock.
Additional:
• Irish landings of plaice in this area are mainly taken as a minor bycatch in mixed fisheries and are mainly landed with anglerfish, whiting and megrim.
  • Irish catch rates (LPUE) of plaice declined in the early 2000s and have remained at a low level since the mid 2000s, this is partially due to a change in fishing patterns with less trawling in inshore areas where plaice occur.

Management:
• The assessment area includes two TAC areas; the first TAC area covers Divisions 2.a, 3.a, and Sub-area 4. The second TAC area covers Division 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14.
  • Ireland only has a quota for the latter TAC area (5.b, 6, 12 and 14). The TAC for Divisions 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14 was reduced in 2021 by 2,105 t.
Additional:
• Ireland has not taken its full quota in recent years. The 2020 quota uptake by Ireland in Sub-areas 5.b, 6, 12 and 14 was 33%.
  • The advice for 2022 is 49,614 t; a decrease of 16,073 t from the 2021 advice (-24%), owing to low incoming recruitment.

Management:
• The TACs for data limited stocks included in the Joint statement by the Fisheries Council and European Commission (Council document PECHE 13, 5232/14) will be maintained for a further 4 years (beyond 2018), subject to scientific advice unless the perception of the status of any of these stocks changes significantly during this period (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-15-6016_en.htm).
  • The TAC covers Sub-areas 7, 8, 9 and 10.
Additional:
• Irish landings of saithe in Sub-area 7 are mainly taken by gillnets, however, in some years considerable by-catches of saithe are landed with hake, whiting and pollack by bottom trawler fleets.
  • Irish landings in 2019 were the lowest observed in the time series with a slight increase in 2020 landings. There is little discarding of saithe in Irish fisheries.

Management:
• There are two TAC areas that cover this stock. Ireland has quota for both. The first TAC area covers Divisions 5.b and Sub-areas 6, 12 and 14. The second TAC area covers Sub-area 7. Up to 2% of the latter TAC may be fished in Divisions 8.a,b,d,e.
  • Low quota uptake by some countries mean that the current TAC's are well above the reported landings.
  • The 2020 quota uptake by Ireland in Sub-areas 5.b, 6, 12 and 14 was 50%. The 2020 quota uptake by Ireland in Sub-area 7 was higher, with 77% of the quota utilised.
Additional:
• Irish landings of pollack are mainly taken by gillnets, however, in some years considerable by-catches of pollack are landed with hake, whiting and saithe by OTB fleets.
  • Commercial landings may not reflect true pollack catches since recreational fisheries are thought to comprise a significant component of total catch. A recent study (Radford et al., 2018) estimated that recreational catches are approximately 3,500 t per year from this stock.
  • Ireland is currently engaged in an EMFF (DCMAP) funded project aiming to improve data on recreational fisheries.

Management:
• The areas of the TACs do not correspond to the assessment area.
  • EU TACs for ling in 2021 were: 175 t for EU waters of Sub-area 3, 3,813 t for Sub-area 4, and 18,356 t for Sub-areas 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 12 and 14, with an Irish quota of 1,301 t.
  • A TAC is negotiated for Norwegian and Faroese vessels fishing in EU waters. In 2021, the Norwegian quota for Ling in EU sub-areas 5.b, 6 and 7 was 0 t, while the Faroese quota was 0 t for divisions 6.a and 6.b.
  • The EU quota for Norwegian waters of Sub-area 4 is 900 t.
Additional:
• The advice is for a decrease in catch. This is because of the precautionary buffer being applied to this stock for the first time.
  • The average discard rate in the last three years is 4.4%.
  • International landings for 2019 were 20,480 t and preliminary landings for 2020 were 15,257 t. Irish landings of ling in 2020 were 508 t.
  • The stock name has been changed from Ling in subareas 6-9, 12, and 14 and in divisions 3.a and 4.a in 2021.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Division 7.a have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2020 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are negligible creel fisheries in this area).
  • Irish vessels (>12 m) fishing Nephrops in the Irish Sea are required to use one of four highly selective gears and a cod end mesh size >80mm (S.I. No. 510 of 2016).
Additional:
• Irish landings of Irish Sea Nephrops are taken in a highly targeted fishery; 90% of the landings come from trips targeting Nephrops.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Division 7.a have been covered by the EU Landing Obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2020 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation (there are negligible creel fisheries in this area).
  • Irish vessels (>12 m) fishing Nephrops in the Irish Sea are required to use one of four highly selective gears and a cod end mesh size >80mm (S.I. No. 510 of 2016).
Additional:
• Irish landings of Irish Sea Nephrops are taken in a highly targeted fishery; 90% of the landings come from trips targeting Nephrops.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies, which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048 & EU 2019/2239). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• A separate catch limit for FU16 within the wider TAC for Sub-area 7 has been in place since 2011. This has resulted in very restrictive quotas for some vessels and increases the risk of discarding. Area misreporting was also a problem in the past.
  • The Irish fishery was closed from May 2021, when 69% of the Irish quota was exhausted, and reopened in October.
  • A spatio-temporal closure of the Porcupine bank for fisheries was in place between 1 May - 31 July 2010-2012. The period of the EU regulatory closure was reduced to only one month (May) after 2013 and is now included in the technical measures regulation EU 2019/1241.
  • Since March 2018 Irish vessels targeting Nephrops in Sub-areas 6 and 7 may only fish in either of (1) Sub-area 6 and Sub-area 7, excluding FU16, or (2) FU16 of Sub-area 7 (Fisheries Management Notice No. 20 of 2018).
  • In 2013 STECF was asked by the Commission for an assessment of management arrangements in place for Nephrops on the Porcupine bank (closed areas and the "of which" clause). STECF stated that the seasonal closure which had been in place since 2010 had afforded protection to the stock. STECF considered that to achieve management objectives in this FU, TAC and other appropriate management measures should be maintained at the FU level.
Additional:
• The mean weight for this stock has been fluctuating strongly since 2000 due to changes in recruitment patterns. For this reason, a three-year average (2018-2020) weight in the landings was considered the most appropriate basis in the calculation of catch scenarios.
  • In 2020, due to COVID-19, at-sea sampling was not possible. An at sea self-sampling programme was initiated in quarter 4 which provides samples of catches that were used to derive mean weights. This change is considered to have had minimal impact on the quality of the assessment.
  • The UWTV abundance estimate decreased by 19% in 2021. No MSY Btrigger has been defined for this stock due to the short time series. The lowest abundance observed 722 million individuals in 2014 could be used as a MSY Btrigger proxy.
  • Nephrops on the Porcupine Bank are fished in deep waters and the grounds occur over a fairly wide area at relatively low burrow abundance (compared to the inshore Nephrops grounds). Productivity of deep water Nephrops stocks are lower than those on the shelf although the individual Nephrops grow to relatively larger size and attain higher market prices.
  • Nearly 90% of the Irish landings of Porcupine Bank Nephrops come from trips where Nephrops was the dominant species, the main bycatch species is anglerfish.
  • Historic Irish sampling data shows that female Nephrops constitute a higher proportion of the catch between late May (week 22) and early July (week 27) on the Porcupine Bank.
  • Highly variable discarding practices have been observed on individual trips since 2016. The ICES advice assumes that all catches are landed.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048, EU 2019/2239, EU 2020/2015). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management: • The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
Additional:
• Abundance estimates from UWTV surveys on the Aran grounds have declined significantly since 2004 and have been at or below MSY Btrigger since 2012. The abundance in 2021 was the lowest observed in the time series which is a cause of concern.
  • More than 90% of the Irish landings of Aran grounds Nephrops come from trips where Nephrops was the dominant species, by-catch species include anglerfish, whiting, haddock and megrim.
  • Long term average mean weights in landings and discards are used as the most appropriate values to calculate catch options on, to account for the variation seen over time.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048, EU 2019/2239, EU 2020/2015). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • The average discard rate by weight in the trawl fishery for FU 19 over the last three years is 30%. This is high relative to other areas because on-board tailing (keeping only the tail) of the catch is not as prevalent as in other FUs around Ireland.
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.

• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match. The TAC area covers Sub-area 6 and Division 5.b. Division 6.a contains three main fisheries, the North Minch (FU 11), South Minch (FU 12) and Firth of Clyde (FU 13) there are also landings outside these FUs.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Division 6.a have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2020 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation.
Additional:
• Irish landings mainly come from outside Functional Units that are not currently assessed using UWTV surveys.
  • The sum of the single stock projected landings advice for all functional units in 6 is 11,862t. This is a 20.6% reduction on the landings advice given last year and the 2021 TAC of 14,945t.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops trawl fisheries have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability greater than 50% in Sub-area 6.a (Fox and Albalat, 2018 ). This exemption applies to otter trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size of 80-110 mm within twelve nautical miles of the coast (EU 2020/2015). There is also a high survivability exemption for creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 6a.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match. The TAC area covers Sub-area 6 and Division 5.b. Division 6.a contains three main fisheries, the North Minch (FU 11), South Minch (FU 12) and Firth of Clyde (FU 13) there are also landings outside these FUs.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Division 6.a have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2020 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation.
Additional:
• Irish landings mainly come from outside Functional Units that are not currently assessed using UWTV surveys.
  • The sum of the single stock projected landings advice for all functional units in 6 is 11,862t. This is a 20.6% reduction on the landings advice given last year and the 2021 TAC of 14,945 t.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops trawl fisheries have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability greater than 50% in Sub-area 6.a (Fox and Albalat, 2018 ). This exemption applies to otter trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size of 80-110 mm within twelve nautical miles of the coast (EU 2020/2015). There is also a high survivability exemption for creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 6a.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match. The TAC area covers Sub-area 6 and Division 5.b. Division 6.a contains three main fisheries, the North Minch (FU 11), South Minch (FU 12) and Firth of Clyde (FU 13) there are also landings outside these FUs.
  • Since 2016, fisheries catching Nephrops in Division 6.a have been covered by the EU landing obligation. Pot, trap and creel and in 2020 most trawl fisheries had a high survivability exemption under the Landing Obligation.
Additional:
• Irish landings mainly come from outside Functional Units that are not currently assessed using UWTV surveys.
  • The sum of the single stock projected landings advice for all functional units in 6 is 11,862 t. This is a 20.6% reduction on the landings advice given last year and the 2021 TAC of 14,945 t.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops trawl fisheries have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability greater than 50% in Sub-area 6.a (Fox and Albalat, 2018 ). This exemption applies to otter trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size of 80-110 mm within twelve nautical miles of the coast (EU 2020/2015). There is also a high survivability exemption for creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 6a.

Management:
• The current TAC area and stock assessment area do not match.
  • In the past some catches reported in other rectangles are were reallocated to FU16, this is no longer an issue.
Additional:
• The ICES advice last year was based on a precautionary 20% reduction on the advice given previously. Recent landings have been above the advised catch level.
  • Nephrops outside the current FUs are not considered as separate stocks but represent small populations of Nephrops outside the identified stock units (FUs). The level of recruitment to these patches is unknown although it is likely that there is some donation of recruits from the major stock units.
  • Under the Landing Obligation Nephrops fisheries in Sub-area 7 have a high survivability exemption, based on studies which showed a survivability of about 64% (BIM, 20172). This exemption applies to bottom trawls (OTT, OTB, TBS, TBN, TB, PTB, OT, PT, TX) with a mesh size ≥ 100 mm or with a mesh size 70-99 mm in combination with highly selective gear options such as: square mesh panels, seltra panel, sorting grid or separation panel (2019/7048, EU 2019/2239, EU 2020/2015). A high survivability exemption also applies to creel caught Nephrops in Sub-area 7.

Management:
• There is no agreed TAC for sea bass in Divisions 6.a, 7.b, and 7.j.
  • A series of measures have been introduced because of the low stock size. The most recent measures on sea bass fisheries are set out in Regulation (EU) 2021/92 (amended by Article 3 of Council Regulation 2021/1239). Only catch and release recreational fisheries are allowed in January, February and December, a bag limit of two fish per day was put in place between March and November.
  • The minimum size of European seabass retained by recreational fisheries is 42 cm.
  • A prohibition on landings of sea bass by Irish commercial vessels has been in place in Ireland since 1990 (under Irish statute).
  • Nationally, the Sea Fisheries Maritime Jurisdiction Act 2006 set out fishing restrictions under two statutory instruments:
    • S.I. No. 230 of 2006, prohibits the fishing, landing, transhipping or retaining of sea bass on board an Irish commercial fishing boat; the use of nets; and prescribes an MCRS of 40 cm.
    • S.I. No. 367 of 2007 prohibits sale or offer for sale of sea bass (other than those imported).
Additional:
• The advice provided for 2021-2023 was 3 t; a decrease of 1 t (-25%) from the previous advice (2018-2020), owing to the application of a 20% precautionary buffer. Official reported landings are extremely low and caught solely by French fishing vessels in Division 7.j.
  • Sea bass stock identity is poorly understood. There are ongoing tagging experiments led by Inland Fisheries Ireland on the western coast of Ireland.
  • Previous tag/recapture studies on sea bass on the western Irish coastline have shown evidence of interconnectivity with the Celtic Sea.

Management:
• There is no TAC for sea bass in divisions 4.b-c, 7.a, and 7.d-h.
  • A series of measures have been introduced because of the low stock size. The most recent measures on sea bass fisheries are set out in Regulation (EU) 2021/92 (amended by Article 3 of Council Regulation 2021/1239). Only catch and release recreational fisheries are allowed in January, February and December, a bag limit of two fish per day was put in place between March and November.
  • The minimum size of European seabass retained by recreational fisheries is 42 cm.
  • A prohibition on landings of sea bass by Irish commercial vessels has been in place in Ireland since 1990 (under Irish statute).
  • Nationally, the Sea Fisheries Maritime Jurisdiction Act 2006 set out fishing restrictions under two statutory instruments:
    • S.I. No. 230 of 2006, prohibits the fishing, landing, transhipping or retaining of sea bass on board an Irish commercial fishing boat; the use of nets; and prescribes an MCRS of 40 cm.
    • S.I. No. 367 of 2007 prohibits sale or offer for sale of sea bass (other than those imported).
Additional:
• The stock is below MSY Btrigger in 2021 and the advised fishing mortality for 2022 is below FMSY due to application of the ICES advice rule.
  • The increase in advice for 2022 of 10.8% relative to 2021 is mainly due to an increase in spawning-stock biomass and the slightly higher fishing mortality implied by the advice rule.
  • The stocks around Ireland and Britain are believed to belong to the same genetic population. Tagging research conducted by the Marine Institute has shown that sea bass may undergo long migrations from Irish coasts into the Celtic Sea and Bristol Channel, returning to the Irish coast.

Management:
• The stock assessment and management area for North Atlantic albacore tuna covers the Atlantic, north of 5°N line, and excluding the Mediterranean Sea.
  • ICCAT recommendation 98-08 limiting fishing capacity to the average of 1993-1995, remains in force. This limits the number of Irish vessels that may fish for tuna to a maximum of 50 vessels.
  • ICCAT recommendation 16-06 sets the objective of maintaining the fishing pressure below FMSY and stock biomass state above BMSY, while maximizing average catch and minimizing inter-annual fluctuations in TAC levels.
  • Any unused portion or excess of the annual adjusted quota may be added to/shall be deducted from, according to the case, the quota 2 years later (adjustment 2 years later, i.e. in 2018 for catches in 2016). The maximum allowed carryover is 25% of the initial quota in those years. ICCAT undertakes to implement additional measures if carried over quota leads to a TAC in excess of 33,600 t.
Additional:
• The stock was last assessed in 2020, following the same approach as the previous assessment in 2016. The 2020 assessment uses data up to, and including 2018. ICCAT usually set a 3-year constant annual TAC. The next stock assessment is planned for 2023.
  • In 2020 Irish vessels had a total catch of 2938 t and landed mainly into France and Spain.
  • The primary Irish fishery is with pair pelagic trawlers in the Bay of Biscay, there can be some late season catches to the south west of Ireland.
  • Irish observer data suggest that bycatch of sharks, seabirds, turtles and mammals are near zero. Bluefin tuna and swordfish are potential choke species for the fishery and the Irish fleet are known to avoid such catches.

Management:
• The TAC covers the entire North Atlantic Ocean east of 45°W and the also the Mediterranean Sea.
  • ICCAT recommendation 09-06 sets the objective of achieving FMSY and BMSY by 2022 with at least a 60% probability.
  • In 2006, ICCAT adopted a rebuilding plan for this stock. This plan includes various conservation measures, including a TAC together with extended time/area closures and minimum size. Management measures to reduce fishing mortality were introduced in 2008. These measures included lower TACs, increased control and enforcement measures, particularly within the Mediterranean Sea, and a requirement for all purse seine vessels targeting Bluefin tuna for farming in cages to carry observers on-board. This plan runs until 2022.
  • Ireland has no target fisheries. Bycatches in any fishery are subject to an unallocated bycatch quota for EU vessels (68.11 t in 2021). This restrictive bycatch allowance may make blue fin a potential choke species in other pelagic fisheries especially as the stock rebuilds.
  • In 2021, 21 charter angling vessels have been authorised to participate in the Irish catch, tag and release programme.
  • EU member states' retained recreational catches must be deducted from available quotas. The quota that Ireland has access to is designated for bycatch only, and not for target fisheries.
Additional:
• The stock was last assessed in 2020 by means of applying statistical modelling to the available data up to 2018.
  • The ICATT Standing Committee on Research and Statistics, in line with Rec. 18-02, evaluated that fishery indicators did not indicate a reason to alter current management advice (36,000 t).
  • Work on the Management Strategy Evaluation (MSE) by the Standing Committee on Research and Statistics (SCRS) has been compromised by the abnormal circumstances related to COVID-19.
